fields.headline: Fawlty Towers named 'top TV show of all time'
fields.standfirst: BFI top 100
fields.trailText: John Cleese's run-ins as cantankerous hotel boss Basil Fawlty have made Fawlty Towers the greatest British TV show of all time, according to a British Film Institute poll published today.
fields.body:
John Cleese's run-ins as cantankerous hotel boss Basil Fawlty have made Fawlty Towers the greatest British TV show of all time, according to a British Film Institute poll published today.

Gritty 60s drama Cathy Come Home finished runner-up in the poll of 1,600 figures from the TV industry - including programme-makers, TV executives and critics - who took part. The list of classics features another Cleese contribution at number five with Monty Python's Flying Circus, whose surreal sketches changed the shape of British comedy.

Pioneering sci-fi series Doctor Who, which ran regularly from 1963 to 1989 and caused generations of children to cower behind the sofa on Saturdays, finished third. Another children's show, Blue Peter, finished in sixth position. It is one of two programmes to make it into the list which began in the 50s and are still going strong today - the other, This Is Your Life, came in at number 85.

No 90s creations made it into the top 10, with the highest rated series from the past decade, Absolutely Fabulous, managing number 17. The most recent TV show to score highly in the poll was Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?, which figured at number 23.

Coronation Street is the top soap at number 40, but its arch-rival, EastEnders, fails to get a mention in the entire top 100. The earliest programme to make it into the list is the BBC production Nineteen Eighty-Four, which was made back in 1954.

Newcomer Channel 4, formed 18 years ago, managed to squeeze into the BFI list with six programmes, while three-year-old Channel 5 failed to get a mention.

Presenter Michael Parkinson - whose long-running chat show finished in eighth place - announced the results of the poll today. He said: "The particular significance of this list of programmes is that it reflects the votes of the television industry, those involved in programme-making, and they can be a tough audience to satisfy."

Voters were also asked to name their top overseas programme, with radio psychiatrist Frasier - screened in the UK by Channel 4 - taking the top slot.

fields.headline: Spanish
fields.standfirst: Spanish language websites for children and adults alike
fields.trailText: Spanish language websites for children and adults alike
fields.body:
BBC Education

****

Aimed at: GCSE students

Liven up your exam revision at this site, which offers tips on exam technique, revision advice and sample reading and writing tests. Though there are new weekly features, it is not clear how often the rest is updated.

Verb Conjugator

***

Aimed at: adult learners

If you've forgotten the indicative third-person singular of corregir, type in the infinitive and this unimaginative, no-nonsense site will fully conjugate it. Most is in Spanish so make sure you know Spanish grammatical terms.

Diccionario Anaya

****

Aimed at: everyone

User-friendly and efficient, this advanced dictionary translates words from Spanish to English or vice-versa, and gives examples of use and etymology. Definitions are in Spanish, so A-level or higher level students will gain most. It's worth clicking on to the Vox Dictionary homepage, which provides comprehensive information and advice on Spanish dictionaries.

Study Spanish

*****

Aimed at: everyone

Clear explanations, exercises and a printer-friendly format version will help you teach Spanish, test yourself or brush up using verb drills and vocabulary games. With a huge range of sections from "travel helper" to "idioms" and useful links for cultural information, this is a comprehensive and meticulous site useful for teachers and students.

Lecturas paso a paso

****

Aimed at: readers

This Spanish site from the Centro Virtual Cervantes presents extracts from novels, changed "periodically", at three levels. Texts come with pre- and post-reading activities to aid comprehension, and difficult vocabulary is in hypertext linked to clear explanations and illustrations.

El idioma espanol

****

Aimed at: everyone

Updated daily, this Spanish site brings you the latest news on the Spanish language, with well-selected links to articles on literature, Spanglish and general themes and debates. Could be useful for teachers and A-level students as a starting point for cultural discussions.

Spanish Booksellers

***

Aimed at: book-buyers

Spanish-language books, including translations into Spanish, are organised by subject matter and sold at below list prices, orderable online. Good search facilities, book recommendations and plot summaries.

Si, Spain

***

Aimed at: everyone

If you need to check on the facts, use this no-frills, multi-lingual site produced by the Spanish Ministry of Foreign Affairs to access information on all aspects of Spanish culture, history and politics, as well as useful lists of sites for those travelling to Spain.

Teaching materials

***

Aimed at: primary teachers

The National Advisory Centre on Early Language Learning provides detailed descriptions of well-selected, primary-age learning materials, with links to publishers.

You can find more Spanish sites at Education Unlimited netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Marks & Spencer unveils chain of discount stores
fields.trailText: Marks & Spencer, the high street retailer renowned for its traditional approach, is to make a radical break with its past by opening a chain of discount stores.
fields.body:
Marks & Spencer, the high street retailer renowned for its traditional approach, is to make a radical break with its past by opening a chain of discount stores.

The stores, called Marks & Spencer Outlet, will sell unsold stock at a 30%-50% discount, as M&S continues its image overhaul. The first three outlets will open in Kent, Cheshire and West Lothian before Christmas, with plans to open nine more next year.

"We want to protect the brand at a key time for us," said an M&S spokesperson. "We need to move products on and keep the stores fresh by clearing stock more effectively. We did not want to send the clothes to factory outlets, as we want to monitor the brand at all times."

M&S plans to update its ranges on a more regular basis, creating large amounts of surplus stock which will be shifted to the cut-price stores. The spokesperson said the sites are likely to appeal to younger age groups, but advertising will not focus on them. The new Autograph brand has been interpreted as an attempt to court younger shoppers.

Industry observers said the move was not a surprise, as rivals such as Gap and Next have been using discount stores for several years. The outlets are seen as a vital means of generating sales at a time when plummeting margins and discount wars are damaging retail profits.

"It does not detract from the M&S brand at all," said Mike Godliman of retail consultants Verdict Research. "In fact I am surprised that they have not done it before. It shows that M&S are moving with the times and are becoming a modern company."

However, the stock market is refusing to give the company the benefit of the doubt. The shares fell 5p to 209p, against a year high of 402p.

fields.headline: An open letter to Channel 4
fields.standfirst: Catherine Hanley pens an open letter to Channel 4's Saturday morning cricket magazine, the Cricket Roadshow
fields.trailText: Dear Cricket Roadshow,
fields.body:
Dear Cricket Roadshow,

So, the season is drawing to its end, and we've seen the last of your programme for another year. I've enjoyed it: you've managed to produce an admirable mix of match coverage, interviews and news items. I do, however, have one question regarding the show - where are all the women?

I'm not, of course, talking about the ubiquitous Sybil Ruscoe, a well- respected sports presenter who does a fine job. It's good to see a woman co-presenting a cricket programme at last - even if one could quibble that all the male presenters are ex-players, so it might be nice to see a woman with a playing pedigree. But that's not my complaint.

No, what I'm talking about is something different, which falls into two parts. Firstly, there is virtually no recognition on your show that women's cricket even exists. Oh, there's the occasional nod in that direction, such as the feature on Matthew and Julie Cassar, but this was more in the nature of a light entertainment piece than a serious attempt to focus on women's cricket. Where are the reports on women's international cricket? Where are the references to the women's domestic game? Sadly lacking, I'm afraid.

My second point is one which is perhaps less obvious on the screen, but to my mind it is an even more serious oversight. Every so often on your programme you feature a masterclass, in which professional players offer advice to youngsters on various aspects of their game. This is a laudable idea: as a viewer I enjoy seeing the players of today passing on some tips to the cricketers of tomorrow. But I ask again - where are all the girls? There are plenty of development schemes and girls' teams around, and surely it wouldn't be too difficult to find a few.

Look, imagine you're a young girl who is passionate about cricket. You switch on Cricket Roadshow every Saturday morning to catch up on the latest news and views, and what do you see? A programme presented mainly by men, reporting on men's cricket, where men offer advice to boys in order to improve their game. What would your thoughts be?

Encouraging more girls to play cricket can only be beneficial to the game, so the onus is on high-profile shows like yours to keep the ball rolling. I realise that women's cricket has a fair way to go to achieve parity with the men's game, but as a major focal point for most cricket-loving youngsters in this country, you really ought to get your act together and start to portray girls playing cricket as the norm. So I urge you: be the first out of the blocks. Forge the way ahead and other shows will surely follow.

I'm not asking you to change the world - just to make the first step. It might only be a first step, but at least it would be a step in the right direction.

fields.bodyText: Dear Cricket Roadshow, So, the season is drawing to its end, and we've seen the last of your programme for another year. I've enjoyed it: you've managed to produce an admirable mix of match coverage, interviews and news items. I do, however, have one question regarding the show - where are all the women? I'm not, of course, talking about the ubiquitous Sybil Ruscoe, a well- respected sports presenter who does a fine job. It's good to see a woman co-presenting a cricket programme at last - even if one could quibble that all the male presenters are ex-players, so it might be nice to see a woman with a playing pedigree. But that's not my complaint. No, what I'm talking about is something different, which falls into two parts. Firstly, there is virtually no recognition on your show that women's cricket even exists. Oh, there's the occasional nod in that direction, such as the feature on Matthew and Julie Cassar, but this was more in the nature of a light entertainment piece than a serious attempt to focus on women's cricket. Where are the reports on women's international cricket? Where are the references to the women's domestic game? Sadly lacking, I'm afraid. My second point is one which is perhaps less obvious on the screen, but to my mind it is an even more serious oversight. Every so often on your programme you feature a masterclass, in which professional players offer advice to youngsters on various aspects of their game. This is a laudable idea: as a viewer I enjoy seeing the players of today passing on some tips to the cricketers of tomorrow. But I ask again - where are all the girls? There are plenty of development schemes and girls' teams around, and surely it wouldn't be too difficult to find a few. Look, imagine you're a young girl who is passionate about cricket. You switch on Cricket Roadshow every Saturday morning to catch up on the latest news and views, and what do you see? A programme presented mainly by men, reporting on men's cricket, where men offer advice to boys in order to improve their game. What would your thoughts be? webTitle: Hague launches onslaught against big government

fields.headline: Hague launches onslaught against big government
fields.standfirst: Mark Tran reports on William Hague's launch of the Tories' mini manifesto
fields.trailText: Mark Tran reports on William Hague's launch of the Tories' mini manifesto.
fields.body:
William Hague today promised to set Britain free from big government, big bureaucracy and Brussels, as he launched the Conservative Party's pre-manifesto document in a desperate attempt to erode Labour's comfortable lead in the polls.

In sketching the outlines of Believing in Britain, Mr Hague said that the Tories' new social agenda was based on "one very simple, very Conservative principle: Freedom."

Mr Hague's speech rehashed tenets held dear by Conservatives, minimum government, low taxes and cutting regulation.

But the Tory leader may have promised more than he can deliver when he said that the Tories will reduce "the burden of tax and spend more on public services."

On Europe, he pledged to stop Britain drifting into a European "superstate."

The pre-manifesto document included a promise to enshrine in legislation the ring fencing of powers in certain policy areas, such as taxation and defence, which could not be ceded to Europe.

Today's document, which will form the basis of the party's election manifesto proper, also promised a range of new rights for parents in the schooling of their children, as well as a radical revamp of higher education.

It set out Mr Hague's ambition to establish Britain as a world-class centre for the new economy.

Introducing the document, Mr Hague sought to paint his party's policies toward Europe as a defence of Britain's national identity.

"Extraordinarily, the Conservatives will be the only major party fighting the next election determined to stop the surrender of our most precious right as a country - the right to govern ourselves," said Mr Hague.

The pre-manifesto document said that a Tory government would amend domestic law to include "reserved powers" - preventing European Union law from overriding the will of parliament in areas where it did not voluntarily transfer powers to the EU.

A Conservative administration would also seek to ensure that any future government which wished to surrender any of Parliament's rights and powers to Brussels would first have to secure the electorate's approval in a referendum.

The document warned: "Conservatives strongly support the enlargement of the EU and regard it as a high priority.

"With the prospect of such enlargement, the EU has reached a fork in the road. Down one route lies a fully integrated superstate, with nation states and the national veto disappearing.

"This is the route down which Britain is gradually drifting. The alternative route, our route, is to a Europe of nations combining in different combinations for different purposes and to a different extent, a network Europe."

Mr Hague's speech came at a time when the Tories have lost their summer bounce against the Labour government.

With its public spending review in mid-July and the NHS plan that followed, Labour has recaptured control of the political agenda and is back above 50 per cent support for the first time since April.

The Conservatives meanwhile have fallen four points in a month and are back below 30 per cent.

As for Mr Hague, who invited ridicule with his admission that he drank 14 pints a day as a lad, he is once again sinking fast: the proportion of voters who are unhappy with him exceeds the proportion that is happy by 25 percentage points.

The Tory's mini manifesto

fields.headline: Gout? But I haven't touched port in years
fields.standfirst: It is an illness that has tormented luminaries from Samuel Johnson to Pavarotti. But why me, asks the Guardian's food editor,  Matthew Fort
fields.trailText: It is an illness that has tormented luminaries from Samuel Johnson to Pavarotti. But why me, asks the Guardian's food editor, Matthew Fort.
fields.body:
I didn't think much of it at first: a vague discomfort in the ankle, just part of the general crumbling of middle age. Then came a low-awareness pain that became increasingly acute over a couple of days, until I began to hobble about like a war veteran, trying to be as stiff-upper-lipped as possible - which isn't very. When it comes to tolerance of pain, I am not up there in the Captain Oates league. So I made a doctor's appointment for a few days later, the earliest that the surgery could fit me in.

Then I went to lunch at my brother's house, and the amateur diagnosis took a turn for the dramatic. "For God's sake, Matty," he cried. "You must go to the doctor immediately. It could be a thrombosis." He is something of an expert on the subject of thrombosis, having had a suspected one himself. In fact, he's had so many suspected thises and thats that he make Matthew Norman look an amateur in the hypochondria stakes. But when he started up on a blood-curdling description of "deep-vein investigation" or some such phrase - "the most unbelivably painful experience" - even my sangfroid began to ebb, and I raced to the surgery to beg mercy from whichever GP was on duty.

Mercy she brought me. Dr Cabot doesn't stand for much nonsense, but her dismissal of the fears of conditions unknown to medical science is tempered with good humour. It was no thrombosis for me, no deep-vein business either. "Gout," she said. "Almost certainly gout."

I didn't know whether to pass out with relief or embarrassment. Gout! I mean, gout, the affliction of port-swilling old fogies. Gout, the scourge of yesteryear. Gout, noted by Hippocrates before Christ was born. Gout, first named so by de Vielehardouin in the 13th century. Gout, the affliction of Sam Johnson, Benjamin Franklin, Pitts both Elder and Younger, Orson Welles and Luciano Pavarotti. What could be sadder than sharing an ailment with Luciano Pavarotti? No one has owned up to having gout for years. Anyway, I haven't touched a drop of port for, oooh, an age.

For those who aren't familiar with this condition of ancient pedigree, let me explain. When proteins break down in the body, they create uric acid, which is expelled via the kidneys. Gout arises when levels of uric acid in the bloodstream rise too high, although we "don't fully understand the exact mechanics", according to www.arthritislink.com.

If you have high uric acid levels for any length of time, it leads to deposits of sodium urate crystals in certain joints. Those relating to the foot are favoured. Toes are a particular speciality. Knees and elbows can't be ruled out. When these crystals achieve critical mass, they rub against the tender parts of the joint. Hence the swelling, hence the pain. Hence the trip to the doctor. Hence the programme of capsules of Indomethacin, king of the non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs the size of horse pills that remove the pain in pretty short order.

Having established the causes and the immediate cure, it makes sense to look at the causes of the causes - that is, what makes your uric acid rise up against you. Depending on which website you consult, gout, it seems, is anything between eight and 20 times more common in men than women, with Maoris and Pacific islanders being particularly susceptible for some reason. But women don't get away scot free, particularly after the menopause. Menstruating women naturally have low levels of uric acid.

I suppose I shouldn't be too surprised in my line of work. Writing about food involves eating it pretty continually, and anyway, I am dedicated to my job. Who wouldn't be? My high levels of uric acid were first pointed out to me 25 years ago. The only surprising thing is that it's taken this long for me to reap, if not the whirlwind, then the dust devil of dietary indiscipline. Being a tad overweight hasn't helped. "Gout is linked to obesity," says www.arthritislink.com rather fiercely. I take issue with that obesity bit. (Oh, come on, 15st when I should be 14 isn't that bad, is it?)

Like so many afflictions these days, diet weighs in to point up an inherited predisposition to gout, as Seneca observed in the third century, and is yet another of the failings for which we can blame our forebears. However, it is possible that I have not helped matters by adopting a diet that includes as much shellfish, offal and red wine as possible, to which I would add herrings and sardines as often as possible. Yes, herrings and sardines.

It is a disturbing fact of dietary nostrums that so many of the foods that we are recommended to eat for our health also have the capacity to do us damage. Herrings and sardines may well be rich in health-enhancing omega oils, but at the same time they are packed with pesky little jumping jacks called purines, part of the DNA present in many foods to varying degrees. It is purines that set your uric acid levels leaping. Avoid purine-rich food and drinks, so the argument goes, and you stand a good chance of not being stricken by gout.

This doesn't quite mean that you should abstain altogether from booze, shellfish, offal, herrings or sardines (or anchovies, or pulses, if you believe the American authorities). It does mean a thoughtful reduction in the consumption of all these things, along with drinking lots of water to keep the kidneys up to the mark. I could do it by taking pills such as Allopurinol for the rest of my life, but routine prophylactic treatment of any condition on the the grounds that you might get it again does not strike me as a serious runner. Ergo, moderation, moderation, moderation.

Well, up to a point. Two units of alcohol twice a week strikes me as moderation taken to extremes. So perhaps I should be on the lookout for another twinge sometime. But I am comforted by the fact that I will be in good company.

Steer clear of

The following have a high purine content (of more than 150g) and should therefore be avoided:

Fish and seafood: sardines, herring, mussels.
Meat: heart, meat extract, yeast.

Avoid if possible

A fairly high purine content (75-150):

Fish and seafood: haddock, cod, mackerel, trout, scallops, salmon.
Meat: goose, grouse, bacon, liver, kidney, turkey, veal, venison, game, mutton leg.

Eat in small amounts

With a purine content of up to 75, these can be eaten in small amounts:

Fish and seafood: oysters, lobster, plaice, halibut,crab, bass, roe, shrimp.
Meat: beef, brains, mutton chop, ham, chicken, pork, tongue, tripe, rabbit, duck.
Other: peas, kidney beans, lentils, mushrooms, spinach.

Eat as much as you like of

There are no restrictions on the following, which have insignificant purine content:

Cereals, breads, dairy products, eggs, fats, fruits, nuts, sugar and sweets, cod liver oil, halibut oil, most vegetables (but see above), tea, coffee, fruit juices.

 This information has been adapted from Kelley's textbook of rheumatology.

fields.headline: Boire ou conduire?
fields.standfirst: The death toll on French roads remains high - 116 dead on one long weekend in August alone. Why?
fields.trailText: The death toll on French roads remains high - 116 dead on one long weekend in August alone. Why?
fields.body:
La saison estivale qui vient de s'achever a été endeuillée, cette année encore, par un grand nombre d'accidents de la route mortels. Certes, l'on note une légère amélioration par rapport à l'année dernière. Pourtant, les chiffres sont éloquents: ainsi, lors du week-end du 15 août, qui s'étalait sur 5 jours, 1 393 accidents corporels, 116 tués et 2 004 blessés ont été recensés. Du vendredi 30 juin au dimanche 2 juillet, week-end des premiers départs en vacances, 85 personnes ont trouvé la mort sur le réseau routier français.

La France est l'un des pays européens qui connaît le plus d'accidents de la route. Et pourtant, d'après un sondage, 74% des Français s'estiment bons conducteurs! Pour un grand nombre d'entre eux, le mauvais conducteur, c'est l'autre.

La première cause d'accident, selon 82% des sondés, c'est l'alcool. Vient ensuite la vitesse excessive (62%) puis le non-respect des priorités et des distances (40%).

Nous avons demandé à trois jeunes Français ce qu'ils pensaient de ce véritable fléau:

Que pensez-vous du nombre d'accidents de la route cet été?

Jean-Laurent, 21 ans, étudiant en histoire: Tous les ans, c'est la même chose. Les gens ne font pas attention, ils sont inconscients. Ils sont pressés d'arriver à destination et ne dorment pas. Ils croient que la route, c'est facile, mais en fait, c'est hyper dangereux.

Virginie, 19 ans, vendeuse: Les gens devraient faire plus attention sur la route, prendre le temps de se reposer et surtout, rouler moins vite.

Ghislain, 19 ans, lycéen: C'est scandaleux qu'une vingtaine de personnes meurent sur la route en une seule journée ! Et pourtant, ça n'a pas l'air de servir de leçon aux autres conducteurs!

À votre avis, quelles sont les principales causes de ces nombreux accidents et carambolages?

Jean-Laurent: Tout le monde peut avoir un accident, même le pilote le plus chevronné, en raison de la vitesse, de la fatigue, et, trop souvent hélas, de l'alcool. Il faut rester vigilant à chaque instant, ce qui est pratiquement impossible, surtout sur les longs parcours.

Virginie: Les gens sont fous, ils roulent tous vite, ils se croient en sécurité dans une voiture, alors qu'en fait, ils se trouvent dans un cercueil roulant! Et puis, il y a l'alcool! Vous en connaissez beaucoup qui ne boivent pas au cours d'une soirée?

Ghislain: Y en a combien qui se sont fait buter par des mecs bourrés qui se foutent bien de celui qui arrive en face? Des tonnes! Ces chauffards, qui picolent ou qui roulent comme des tarés, ce sont des criminels!

Que faire pour réduire le nombre des accidents de la route?

Jean-Laurent: Plus de répression et plus de flics sur les routes. On ne les voit pas assez, sauf pour les grands départs en vacances ou les week-end où, là, ils nous font tout un tollé. Ça devrait être tout le temps comme ça.

Virginie: Les gendarmes devraient tre plus présents et faire plus de contrôles, à la sortie des boîtes par exemple! Ils devraient être vraiment vaches avec ceux qui sont en état d'ébriété ou qui roulent comme des dingues. D'ailleurs, il faudrait brider le moteur des voitures. La limitation de vitesse est à 130km/h, je ne vois pas pourquoi certains bolides peuvent aller jusqu'à 200 km/h!

Ghislain: Mettre les boules à tous ceux qui font des infractions: des amendes plus lourdes, de la taule pour ceux qui provoquent des accidents graves, et insister sur la prévention quand on passe son permis, pour responsabiliser les jeunes et leur faire prendre conscience des dangers et des risques qu'ils encourent.

Qui conduit le mieux, les hommes ou les femmes?

Jean-Laurent: Les femmes sont plus prudentes, elles roulent doucement et font plus attention car elles ont peur.

Virginie: Les mecs maîtrisent mieux les bagnoles que les femmes, qui sont souvent plus distraites. Moi, je n'ai pas de voiture et heureusement, car je suis un danger public sur la route. On devient un conducteur responsable au bout de plusieurs mois, pas après 20 heures de cours.

Ghislain: Les nanas ont moins d'accidents car elles sont plus prudentes, et froussardes. Elles se saoulent moins aussi, ce qui joue en leur faveur.

Glossaire/Glossary

une bagnole = une caisse (fam.) a car
être bourré = être saoul (fam.) to be very drunk
un chauffard a roadhog
chevronné experienced
les chiffres sont éloquents the figures speak for themselves
un état d'ébriété a state of drunkenness
se faire buter (fam.) to get killed
un fléau a plague
picoler (fam.) to booze
un taré (very fam.) a mad person

Vous en connaissez beaucoup qui ne boivent pas au cours d'une soirée? Ghislain: Y en a combien qui se sont fait buter par des mecs bourrés qui se foutent bien de celui qui arrive en face? Des tonnes! Ces chauffards, qui picolent ou qui roulent comme des tarés, ce sont des criminels! Que faire pour réduire le nombre des accidents de la route? Jean-Laurent: Plus de répression et plus de flics sur les routes. On ne les voit pas assez, sauf pour les grands départs en vacances ou les week-end où, là, ils nous font tout un tollé. Ça devrait être tout le temps comme ça. Virginie: Les gendarmes devraient tre plus présents et faire plus de contrôles, à la sortie des boîtes par exemple! Ils devraient être vraiment vaches avec ceux qui sont en état d'ébriété ou qui roulent comme des dingues. D'ailleurs, il faudrait brider le moteur des voitures. La limitation de vitesse est à 130km/h, je ne vois pas pourquoi certains bolides peuvent aller jusqu'à 200 km/h! Ghislain: Mettre les boules à tous ceux qui font des infractions: des amendes plus lourdes, de la taule pour ceux qui provoquent des accidents graves, et insister sur la prévention quand on passe son permis, pour responsabiliser les jeunes et leur faire prendre conscience des dangers et des risques qu'ils encourent. Qui conduit le mieux, les hommes ou les femmes? Jean-Laurent: Les femmes sont plus prudentes, elles roulent doucement et font plus attention car elles ont peur. Virginie: Les mecs maîtrisent mieux les bagnoles que les femmes, qui sont souvent plus distraites. Moi, je n'ai pas de voiture et heureusement, car je suis un danger public sur la route. On devient un conducteur responsable au bout de plusieurs mois, pas après 20 heures de cours. Ghislain: Les nanas ont moins d'accidents car elles sont plus prudentes, et froussardes. Elles se saoulent moins aussi, ce qui joue en leur faveur. fields.headline: Augenzeuge
fields.standfirst: Dr Eduard Egarter Vigl, pathologist, is preserving the body of a 5,000-year-old ice man
fields.trailText: Dr Eduard Egarter Vigl, pathologist, is preserving the body of a 5,000-year-old ice man
fields.body:
Seit ich 1997 gefragt wurde, ob ich an der Konservierung von "Ötzi" mitarbeiten möchte, wechseln meine Gefühle ständig. Anfangs standen Unsicherheit und Sorge im Vordergrund, man könnte etwas Falsches tun, was später nicht mehr rückgängig zu machen ist. Immerhin ist der Eismann über 5000 Jahre alt. Je sicherer ich mir war, daß unser Team gute Arbeit leistet, desto mehr gewann in mir das Interesse an der Biologie die Oberhand. Wenn ich diesen 5000 Jahre alten Körper vor mir habe, spüre ich auf einmal Ehrfurcht vor dem Alter meines "Patienten". Es ist fast schon so, daß ich eine Art Vertrautheit mit Ötzi empfinde. Vor allem, wenn ich spät abends noch zu einem Kontrollbesuch ins Museum gehe.

Im Konservierungsteam arbeiten außer mir ein weiterer Arzt und drei Techniker, die an 365 Tagen im Jahr rund um die Uhr auf Abruf bereitstehen. Mich hat man damals wohl als Experten ins Boot geholt, da ich als Pathologe mit toten Körpern zu tun habe. Nur ist das natürlich etwas völlig anderes. Ötzi ist aus medizinischer und historischer Sicht von unschätzbarem Wert. Und deshalb ist die Arbeit unseres Teams auch mit großer Verantwortung verbunden. Wer sonst hat schon mit einer so alten Mumie zu tun? Trotzdem haben wir immer auch Sorgen, irgend etwas könnte schiefgehen. Bisher hat es sich als das beste Rezept erwiesen, auf kleinste Veränderungen an Ötzi zu reagieren. Der Eismann ist bei gleich bleibender Temperatur und Luftfeuchtigkeit in einer Kühlkammer im Archäologiemuseum in Bozen, Südtirol, untergebracht. Treten Probleme auf, müssen wir sofort analysieren, woher sie kommen und wie man sie lösen kann. Schließlich soll Ötzi der Nachwelt noch lange erhalten bleiben.

die Oberhand gewinnen to get more important than anything else

ins Boot holen to ask someone to take part in something

konservieren to conservate

Neuland betreten to do sth. new

rund um die Uhr all day and night

unschätzbar not possible to evaluate

fields.headline: What a grey day
fields.trailText: The days of covering up grey hair were coming to an end today, as hair care specialists L'Oreal Paris launched a new product aimed at celebrating greyness.
fields.body:
The days of covering up grey hair were coming to an end today, as hair care specialists L'Oreal Paris launched a new product aimed at celebrating greyness.

Called Grey Chic, it was launched by silver-haired actress Honor Blackman, a former Bond girl, and model Jibby Beane, the muse for fashion designer Vivienne Westwood.

The product, a rinse, is the first that does not try to cover up women's grey hair, said a spokeswoman for L'Oreal Paris.

"Women often try to cover up the odd grey hair but there comes a time when most of the hair goes grey and women don't want to cover it completely.

"The new product is aimed at making grey hair look at its absolute best. We are celebrating greyness," she said.

There are 6.8 million British women with grey hair, estimates L'Oreal.

 Women aged between 55 and 75 represent 19 per cent of the UK population.

 The age at which hair starts to lose its pigment is believed to be genetically predetermined.

 As we age, hair follicles diminish in size, producing finer hair.

 Mature hair has a shorter growth cycle which means hair cannot grow as long.

 Grey or white hair is in fact colourless or non-pigmented. Pigment cells located at the base of the hair follicle produce the dominant colour of youth. As we age the pigment cells die and colour is lost - a process that takes between 10 and 20 years.

 Grey or white hair tends to be very absorbent and can pick up smoke and car exhaust fumes which turn the hair an unattractive yellow.

 The average total number of hairs on the scalp is between 100,000 and 150,000.

 We shed 100-150 hairs a day.

 The over-50s have 80 per cent of the nation's wealth.

fields.headline: Bush makes major league gaffe
fields.standfirst:
Special report: the US election race
Slate guide to Bushisms
fields.trailText: Presidential candidate says he regrets being overheard insulting journalist.Special report: the US election race
fields.body:
US candidate George W Bush, who had promised to bring a new tone of civility to politics, made a disparaging remark about a reporter from The New York Times yesterday - only for it to be picked up by a live microphone.

The Republican presidential nominee was unaware that is microphone was live when he leaned over to Dick Cheney at a Labour Day rally and said, "There's Adam Clymer, major league asshole from the New York Times."

Mr Cheney responded, "Oh yeah, he is, big time."

Both men thought their remarks were off-mike.

When asked about the comment at a brief airport news conference in Allentown, Pennsylvania, late Monday, Mr Bush said, "I regret that a private comment I made to the vice-presidential candidate made it through the public airways."

Asked if he felt he owed Clymer an apology, Bush did not answer directly, only saying, "I regret everybody heard what I said."

Karen Hughes, Bush's spokeswoman, said that the remarks were "a whispered aside to his running mate. It was not intended as a public comment."

Mr Clymer said: "I'm disappointed in the governor's language." However, Mr Cheney refused to discuss it. "The governor made a private comment to me. It was a private comment, and I don't plan to say anything about it," he told reporters later in Chicago.

fields.headline: Blair heads for world summit
fields.standfirst: Official UN millennium summit site
fields.trailText: Prime Minister Tony Blair flies to New York today to join the biggest gathering of world leaders yet held - for the United Nations' millennium summit.
fields.body:
Prime Minister Tony Blair flies to New York today to join the biggest gathering of world leaders yet held - for the United Nations' millennium summit.

He is set to join more than 150 other heads of state or government at the meeting, designed to shape the organisation for the next century. Mr Blair will jet out from London this afternoon, to join fellow Commonwealth leaders for a dinner tonight, hosted by South African President Thabo Mbeki. The premier will be accompanied by wife Cherie and three-month-old baby son Leo for the family's first official visit abroad together since his birth.

The Prime Minister will tomorrow make a speech to the summit, focusing on peacekeeping, particularly in the light of Britain's experiences in the former Yugoslavia and Sierra Leone.

The Government published a joint document with the Liberal Democrats yesterday calling for the UN to set up a special staff college to train UN peacekeeping leaders, possibly in Britain, and for there to be a more rigorous mandate for them, allowing robust rules of engagement.

During his three-day visit, Mr Blair is also expected to have private talks with Russian President Vladimir Putin, US President Bill Clinton and Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak. The Prime Minister is also expected to meet Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat, at a key time in the Middle East peace process, and hold talks with fellow EU leaders including Germany's President Gerhard Schroeder.

Mrs Blair is expected to take part in a legal seminar and to fulfil other private engagements. It is not known whether baby Leo will accompany her on any of her visits.

webTitle: Early risers marvel at new dawn

fields.headline: Early risers marvel at new dawn
fields.trailText: The most dangerous word in cricket is "unprecedented". The moment you suggest something has never happened before, someone will announce not only that it has but that it were all a damn sight better in them days too.
fields.body:
The most dangerous word in cricket is "unprecedented". The moment you suggest something has never happened before, someone will announce not only that it has but that it were all a damn sight better in them days too.

Well, the scenes at the Oval yesterday were as near to unprecedented as makes no difference. Here at last was the Amazing Millennium Experience that London was promised. England not merely beat West Indies, they crushed them.

Only a handful of people in the ground had witnessed England win a series against West Indies before: Henry Blofeld, Tony Cozier and Bill Frindall for sure; a few greybeards in the crowd, no doubt. Six of the England team were not even born 31 summers ago. Nor, gratifyingly, were many of the spectators.

As Nasser Hussain lifted the Wisden Trophy, kids - repeat, English schoolboys - were playing makeshift games on the Oval outfield with bags and Thermos flasks as wickets. This is what boys are meant to do. And no one chased them off.

They had to go a long way back to find room. The whole of the field south of the square was covered in humanity, and some supporters had to try to squint at the presentation from the Vauxhall End. No one could recall a crowd anything like this. Traditionally the fifth day of a Test match - no matter how excitingly poised - is played out in a near-empty stadium. Tickets are never sold in advance.

This time, to unanimous astonishment, the crowds began forming outside shortly after 7am. Before the start they were massing five abreast on the Harleyford Road. By midday the gates were shut, making the match an official sell-out for the fifth successive day.

Something similar was witnessed at Headingley two years ago when England beat South Africa. Never mind that the victory was tainted by appalling and conceivably corrupt umpiring. Ten thousand turned up on the last day to watch half an hour's cricket - which was amazing even if admission was free.

And yesterday cannot entirely be put down to the cheap rates either: a tenner admission, free for children and seniors (a reaction to the criticism about high cup-final prices). People were hungry, no, starving, even ravenous for success. The English had not fallen out of love with cricket: they had just grown contemptuous of the national team.

Headingley 1998 aside, one of the few men on the ground who could remember winning anything was John Major - and that was 1992, and received with less unanimous acclaim than this result.

But it's amazing what the anticipation of victory can do. The famously officious Surrey stewards barred the entrances - with some glee, I thought. Touts offered £10 tickets for £60 but even they were struggling to get a supply. Hundreds of plaintive victims stood outside the gates as though they had missed the last helicopter out of Saigon. "But my mother knew Jack Hobbs," wailed one victim.

Congestion was eased when the empty hospitality boxes were opened and made available to the Great Unwashed, who rushed in and committed the ultimate corporate-day-out solecism: THEY WATCHED THE CRICKET. The Revolution will be like this.

There are famous pictures from 1953, when Denis Compton and Bill Edrich were cheered off by a vast throng (all wearing jackets and ties). England had just clinched the Ashes for the first time in a mere 20 years. That win came very early on the last day and there is no record of a full house.

In 1926, England's previous home Ashes win, and 1938, when Len Hutton scored his record-breaking 364, the Oval Test did not even go to the fifth day. OK, let's say it. Unprecedented.

fields.headline: Anger at Pitt's bullish remarks
fields.trailText: Brad Pitt became the latest US actor to weigh in on matters Irish.
fields.body:
Some unionists in Northern Ireland are so inured to it now they were laughing it off yesterday. Others, though, were fulminating against Hollywood once more.

Brad Pitt became the latest US actor to weigh in on matters Irish.

In an interview with Esquire, Pitt said: "As with anything, it comes down to a few bad people. But I want to know why the British empire is promoting this pain. Why can't the empire right its wrong?"

Pitt, who sparked controversy with his sympathetic portrayal of an IRA man in Alan Pakula's 1996 film The Devil's Own, had spent several months in Belfast trying to perfect his accent for the role. He has since visited Northern Ireland several times.

The Democratic Unionist party's Jim Shannon, a member of the assembly's arts and culture committee, labelled Pitt's comments deeply offensive.

But critics say he will surely never get it so wrong as Mickey Rourke did over his 1987 film A Prayer for the Dying.

Rourke, who had Irish grandparents, was once reported to have admitted to having given large sums to the IRA, but later threatened to sue over the allegations.

He has since visited Northern Ireland several times. The Democratic Unionist party's Jim Shannon, a member of the assembly's arts and culture committee, labelled Pitt's comments deeply offensive. But critics say he will surely never get it so wrong as Mickey Rourke did over his 1987 film A Prayer for the Dying. Rourke, who had Irish grandparents, was once reported to have admitted to having given large sums to the IRA, but later threatened to sue over the allegations.

fields.headline: 19-year Greenham Common campaign to end
fields.standfirst: From missiles to memorial
fields.trailText: Peace campaigners will finally leave Greenham Common this week after exactly 19 years of continuous presence at the site.
fields.body:
Peace campaigners will finally leave Greenham Common this week after exactly 19 years of continuous presence at the site.

But they are already laying down plans for a memorial to commemorate their battle against the nuclear weapons which were once based there.

The missiles finally left the Berkshire common in 1991, though many protesters stayed on until the perimeter fences of the old base were taken down earlier this year.

Today the last caravan belonging to the Greenham Common Women's Peace Camp will leave for good, 19 years to the day after the protesters arrived.

Some of the buildings have been let to businesses and the control tower, which once followed the movements of missile-laden aircraft, has been earmarked for a visitor centre.

The rest of the site has been returned to common land and the camp's Commemorative Fund Appeal Collective is busy co-ordinating plans for a memorial area, which will include a ring of Welsh stones, sculptures and a special garden.

Fund spokeswoman Sarah Hipperson said: "I'm glad we can leave on a positive note and I feel this next stage is also historically important.

"We need to leave something there that will be a reminder to all peace-loving people. The name Greenham Common is synonymous with the resistance against nuclear weapons."

Greenham Common was requisitioned for use as an air base in 1941 and from 1968 onwards was occupied by the US Air Force. The site gained notoriety in 1980 when the Americans were allowed to store 96 cruise missiles there - a decision which caused such concern to a group of women from Wales that they travelled to the site and chained themselves to the fence.

After the missiles were removed, the women stayed to ensure the land was handed back to the people. It was finally sold to the Greenham Common Trust in 1997 and much of the land was then passed back to the local council for just £1.

The Peace Camp women will mark their departure today with a day-long picnic. The group eventually hopes to bury a time capsule at the site.

webTitle: Tesco and Sainsbury to lead net food retail

fields.headline: Tesco and Sainsbury to dominate net food sales
fields.trailText: Tesco and J Sainsbury will dominate internet food retailing, according to an independent report, although they could price their stores out of the market.
fields.body:
Tesco and J Sainsbury will dominate internet food retailing, according to an independent report, although they could price their stores out of the market.

A study by e-commerce consultancy E-insight says Tesco will incur losses and investment costs of £400m, and Sainsbury £160m, before their ventures become profitable in 2005.

But price competition could damage offline store sales. Tesco is expected to emerge as the market leader in a sector that will be worth £30bn by 2008, with the operation making £500m profit.

E-insight chief executive Alan Taylor said: "The key marketing issue is how do you pursue an aggressive pricing strategy and keep out start-ups without creating differential pricing. They will be aware of the competition and price products accordingly, creating different sub-branded products which will be promoted in a different way."

Mr Taylor brushed off suggestions that it will be hard to entice supermarket customers to the web. He believes the stores will use aggressive discounting tactics to hold on to customers and lock out rival start-ups.

"We have analysed around 30 product categories for e-retailing," he said. "Clearly there is a higher e-relevance for computers and it is much lower for fresh foods. But it is better for goods such as toiletries or a jar of Nescafe. You don't need to touch a packet of Pampers in order to buy it."

Carolyn Bradley, chief executive of Tesco.com, said the supermarket was already making profit from its online grocery service, with has access to 90% of the UK population. The Tesco.com advertising account is held by Lowe Lintas, although many potential customers are targeted in-store.

"The traffic in our stores is a huge market for us Ð we can really sell the benefits," said Bradley. "We also use a lot of direct mail through our club card programme. We especially target working couples and young families, for whom time is of the essence."

Sainsbury expects internet shopping service Sainsbury To You to reach 60% of the UK by April. It will be accompanied by a concerted marketing campaign. The serviceÕs direct advertising is handled by BHWG, while the main ad account is with M&C Saatchi.

"We will be concentrating on the usual avenues such as press ads and inserts in regional magazines, and there is a clear focus behind the marketing strategy," said a Sainsbury spokesperson. "We will be targeting specific customers, including people whose time is restricted because of their job. So we will be distributing leaflets on station concourses to get commuters involved."

The spokesperson said home shopping was an important venture but it would account for only 5% of the grocery market over the next five years, adding that the store will remain focused on supermarket shoppers.

fields.headline: 'We're not becoming a PR agency'
fields.standfirst: Peter York tells Claire Cozens why he sold SRU
fields.trailText: Peter York tells Claire Cozens why he sold SRU
fields.body:
Peter York is very keen to stress that he is not moving into PR. "If you've done a bit of journalism everyone assumes you must be moving into PR," he says. "We're absolutely not becoming a PR agency and we're not turning into Brunswick. We will remain SRU, but we will be owned by the Brunswick Group. It's quite different."

Well that clears that one up. York - or Peter Wallis as he is known at SRU - will continue to run the strategic consultancy he set up in 1973. There, he will continue to advise a wide range of major corporations, government bodies and institutions on everything from investor relations and mergers and acquisitions to branding. Contrary to reports, the company will remain in its Clerkenwell offices and will not be housed in Brunswick's offices in Lincoln's Inn Fields.

The decision to sell SRU was motivated, rather, by a desire to expand the company. As Brunswick already has a number of European offices, it was, says York, a natural fit. The two companies have found themselves working together on mutual clients over time and have, he says, worked well together.

"We chose Brunswick for one very simple reason: it's top banana in its field," says York. "In the City it's the number one corporate brand by a mile."

He will not confirm that the company plans to move into Europe, saying the ink on the deal is barely dry, but adds: "The fact that Brunswick has offices in Europe means it would make eminent sense for us to move there."

fields.headline: Minister criticises BBC1 after ratings flop
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Chris Smith launched a thinly disguised attack on the quality of BBC1 programmes yesterday, as it emerged that the channel last week scored its worst Friday night ratings in five years.
fields.body:
Chris Smith launched a thinly disguised attack on the quality of BBC1 programmes yesterday, as it emerged that the channel last week scored its worst Friday night ratings in five years.

Giving his first public reaction to the radical changes to the corporation's television channels outlined by the director general, Greg Dyke, the culture secretary warned the BBC not to be drawn into a battle for viewers that would lead to poor-quality programmes.

Last month, Mr Dyke revealed plans to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm and to invest £95m more in BBC1 next year, with the lion's share directed at new drama to be screened in the slot vacated by the news. He insisted the plan was to increase ratings for news programmes, but many observers believe he wants to shore up BBC1's viewing figures as competition intensifies.

Mr Smith, speaking at the launch of the Community Channel, a charity service on Sky Digital, said that the new money should be spent on high quality programmes, and not just shows that would attract high ratings.

"I do not want to lose the sense of BBC1 having a wide variety and different types of programmes," he added. "Some will be popular, some more challenging. It needs to be eclectic, inclusive, rather than a niche channel."

The BBC's dilemma was illustrated last Friday, when BBC1 scored an average audience share of 18.9.%, the lowest Friday night since March 1995.

A BBC spokeswoman said Mr Smith's comments echoed Mr Dyke's comments last month. "All of that is entirely consistent with what Greg was saying. BBC1 should be about a wide range of programmes, and getting the balance right.We need to have big hits more consistently, and we are investing the money to do that."

webTitle: Greenham Common: from missiles to memorial

fields.headline: Greenham Common: from missiles to memorial
fields.standfirst: 19-year Greenham campaign to end
fields.trailText: • Greenham Common has been, for most of its history, a valuable piece of common land and a shared sustainable resource for local farmers and residents.
fields.body:
 Greenham Common has been, for most of its history, a valuable piece of common land and a shared sustainable resource for local farmers and residents.

 The Common was taken over by the military in 1941 and used as an airbase.

 It was prominent in the glider-based offensive launched in 1945, and it was at Greenham that Dwight D Eisenhower made his famous "eyes of the world" speech.

 Around 1947 the military left the Common for a brief time, but the onset of the Cold War brought it back into military occupation.

 The 1980s saw the arrival of cruise missiles and the site became a world famous icon for protests against nuclear weapons.

 By 1990 the cruise missiles had gone and in 1992 Greenham Common Airbase was declared redundant for military purposes. The fate of Greenham Common hung in the balance.

 Concerned local people, aware that the common could be sold for housing and lost forever to the local community, formed Greenham Common Trust.

 The Trust purchased the former airbase in March 1997. The common is now being restored for the people of Newbury to enjoy again, and a business park is being created for the benefit of the local community.

webTitle: Leader: EU need to involve citizens

fields.headline: Ask the people
fields.standfirst: The EU gives too little weight to consentSpecial report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: An anxious autumn is in prospect for the European Union as hard choices loom on a wide range of fronts. Denmark's knife-edge, possibly precedent-setting September 28 referendum on joining the euro comes in the context of the common currency's continuing market weakness and ever noisier laments from Germany over the imminent demise of the mark.
fields.body:
An anxious autumn is in prospect for the European Union as hard choices loom on a wide range of fronts. Denmark's knife-edge, possibly precedent-setting September 28 referendum on joining the euro comes in the context of the common currency's continuing market weakness and ever noisier laments from Germany over the imminent demise of the mark. With the "wise men" appointed to investigate Jörg Haider's malign machinations due to report within the week, Austria is threatening all manner of communal disruption should the French presidency decline to lift EU sanctions. Not much further down the road are big decisions on manpower and money for the much-trumpeted, so far non-existent Euro-army. Then comes the Nice summit in December where entrenched differences over EU integration, majority voting, and a charter of Euro-citizens' rights lie like barely concealed landmines beneath the Riviera sand.

To all this autumnal angst was added at the weekend the unexpected suggestion that the ambitious expansion of the EU, the jewel in EC president Romano Prodi's wobbly crown, should, in Germany at least, be put to the test in a popular referendum. Unexpected in partic ular because the proposer of this radical notion was none other than the (German-born) EU commissioner for enlargement, Günter Verheugen. Foreign ministers meeting in Evian were quick to pour cold water. The idea had no official standing, spluttered Joschka Fischer, Bonn-Berlin's answer to Robin Cook. Mr Verheugen should refrain from expressing personal views, suggested an irked Erkki Tuomioja, the Finnish foreign minister (apparently expressing a personal view). Mr Prodi got on the blower, too. It was just a "small misunderstanding", he explained later, after a friendly chat with Mr Verheugen. EU applicant countries should be reassured. There was no question of consulting the German public or anyone else; enlargement was on course.

They still do not get it, do they, these gyrating guardians of Europe's grand design? For Europe to work, it - crucially - needs whole-hearted public support. It needs democratic involvement. Enlargement is everybody's concern. We are in favour. Yet if the Germans want a national debate and a vote (having been denied one on the euro), let them have it. Democracy is messy, Mr Prodi, and anxiety-inducing. But far better that than apathy and alienation.

webTitle: MEP to face inquiry over euro

fields.headline: MEP to face inquiry over euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The European parliament is to launch an inquiry into the finances of a Tory MEP who is raising money to help secure a no vote in the Danish euro referendum.
fields.body:
The European parliament is to launch an inquiry into the finances of a Tory MEP who is raising money to help secure a no vote in the Danish euro referendum.

The investigation was requested by the leader of the Labour group in the assembly, who wants to know more about the fundraising activities of Daniel Hannan, MEP for south-east England.

Mr Hannan is reported to have raised £100,000 to encourage the Danish people to say no to the single currency.

Nicole Fontaine, president of the parliament, yesterday authorised a full investigation into the matter after the Labour leader, Simon Murphy, demanded to know "whether there has been improper use of European parliamentary facilities and European taxpayers' money" by Mr Hannan.

The British Conservative leader, William Hague, has already faced calls to dissociate himself from Mr Hannan, a leader writer for the Daily Telegraph, who at the weekend addressed the annual congress of an ultra-nationalist Danish party which supports repatriation of refugees.

The inquiry will oblige Mr Hannan to declare every Denmark-related donation he has received and to list all his travel and entertainment expenses.

Mr Murphy insists that all this must be done before the Danish referendum is held on September 28.

While Labour has not made any direct accusations against Mr Hannan, the fact that he is to be investigated is embarrassing to Conservative central office.

European MPs benefit from first-class office and staff resources in both Brussels and Strasbourg, paid for by European and British taxpayers. They are required to declare financial donations in a public register but the present procedure is not particularly rigorous and MEPs are only required to update it on an annual basis.

Edward MacMillan-Scott, leader of the Tory MEPs, said: "I am perfectly satisfied that Daniel Hannan has been scrupulous in the way he has carried out this operation."

fields.headline: Pensioner's currency rivals euro
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: The euro is about to be challenged by an Italian pensioner who has won a legal battle to circulate his own currency, the simec.
fields.body:
The euro is about to be challenged by an Italian pensioner who has won a legal battle to circulate his own currency, the simec.

Giacinto Auriti, 77, has persuaded neighbours in Guardiagrele village to dump the Italian lira and now he wants the whole euro-zone to follow suit. The simec is credited with a local boom which has caught the imagination of the Northern League, a northern Italian nationalist political party.

Police confiscated the currency last month after complaints from shopkeepers, but a court has cleared Mr Auriti of fraud and abuse of the financial system, allowing his experiment to resume.

The retired college professor recently persuaded neighbours and more than 40 retailers to sign up by offering an unbeatable deal. The simec was pegged to equal the lira, but he handed over twice as many simecs for every lira received.

Residents in Guardiagrele, deep in Abruzzo countryside, have queued up to swap currencies and double their spending power.

Retailers who accept simecs benefit from the spending splurge and then visit Mr Auriti to convert the simecs back into lire. The shopkeepers who lost business by opting out complained to police.

The currency has generated an estimated £1.7m in turnover and Mr Auriti reckons it will go national and then international. "I understand that a lot of people believe I'm crazy but I have my own theory to prove," he said.

Crazy was an understatement, said tax police investigators, after discovering his secret: the simec was being funded from his savings.

"We are at a complete loss on how to deal with this case because the currency is not counterfeit and Mr Auriti, far from making money, is losing his considerable family fortune," said Colonel Sante Mappa.

Mr Auriti insisted the simec was rooted in economic sense. A feud with Italy's central bank partly motivated his initiative.

"Money belongs to citizens because they are the ones who are producing consumer goods in the first place," he said.

An MP for the Northern League, Mario Borghezio, said the party was "very interested" in replicating Guardiagrele's monetary policy.

fields.headline: EU enlargement row deepens
fields.standfirst:
Germany denies plans to stall entry of new members to the union

www.guardianunlimited.co.uk/eurocommission
fields.trailText: Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, yesterday hastened to stamp out speculation that his government might be plotting to delay the next round of European Union enlargement.
fields.byline: John Hooper  in Berlin and  Ian Black  in  Brussels
fields.body:
Germany's chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, yesterday hastened to stamp out speculation that his government might be plotting to delay the next round of European Union enlargement.

But even as he did so, he and his foreign minister succeeded in dampening the expectations of the candidate nations.

The EU commissioner for enlargement affairs, Günter Verheugen, who is German, appeared to suggest in an interview published at the weekend that his country should hold a referendum on the admission of the Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland.

The idea is political and diplomatic dynamite - all the more so coming from a member of Mr Schröder's Social Democratic party who, until last year, was the number two at the foreign ministry.

Many Germans fear enlargement could lead to an influx of cheap labour and a loss of jobs. So a vote could well go against the EU's plans and the campaign leading up to it could unleash the ugliest sort of populism from the right.

German misgivings about enlargement are a potential sticking point in its relations with London, where rapid expansion of the union is regarded as a priority.

But addressing German ambassadors gathered in Berlin, Mr Schröder insisted that speedy expansion remained the "central task" of his government's foreign policy.

Because of the way they were used by the Nazis in the 1930s, referendums are banned by Germany's constitution. The foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, said the idea of changing it to keep out new EU members was "totally unacceptable".

In Brussels, the European Commission insisted that Mr Verheugen's comments had been taken out of context and that he remained committed to the enlargement process. But there was anxiety that his remarks would fuel suspicions in candidate countries at the ever-slipping timetable for the process to get under way.

The EU has not set a date for their entry. The leading candidates have said they will be ready from the start of 2003 and EU has said it can take in additional members from then.

Yesterday Mr Schröder appeared to muddy the waters by saying: "Each candidate [nation] decides through its own efforts, when it - from that point in time on - achieves membership".

Mr Fischer said the first new members should join by 2005 at the latest. That appeared to set back the target date by two years.

But the German government is not alone in thinking that 2005, or even later, would be a more realistic date given the complexity of the accession negotiations and the lack of public support for the project.

A revised target date opens the door for further delays. Earlier this year, the chancellor's office appealed for a conference to discuss the "big issues"of EU organisation raised by enlargement. Britain believes such a conference should be launched after the next batch of new members are admitted.

Mr Schroder said yesterday that it should open in 2004.

Mr Verheugen's gaffe highlighted the commission's lack of coordination. Most damaging of all was the insistence by the commission president, Romano Prodi, that he knew nothing about the interview.

Mr Verheugen caused double discomfort by warning that Germany, the largest and richest member of the EU, must "not repeat the mistake we made with the euro" which, he said, was "introduced behind the backs of the population".

After the launch of the single currency, enlargement is the EU's main priority for years to come. Failure could mean a redivision of Europe along cold war lines and be a major blow to the credibility of the union.

webTitle: Prison staff jailed for cell attack

fields.headline: Prison staff jailed for cell attack
fields.standfirst: Special report: Prisons
fields.trailText: Three prison officers were yesterday jailed for a vicious premeditated attack on an inmate which a judge branded an abuse of trust.
fields.body:
Three prison officers were yesterday jailed for a vicious premeditated attack on an inmate which a judge branded an abuse of trust.

The officers, who cannot be named for legal reasons, kicked and punched Timothy Donovan, a convicted murderer, in his cell at Wormwood Scrubs prison, west London, two years ago. One stood on the victim's face to prevent him escaping, Blackfriars crown court heard.

Donovan was then handcuffed and spent 14 days in solitary confinement after one of the officers claimed Donovan had attacked him.

The men, now sacked from the prison service, were charged after fellow officers reported the attack. A jury found them guilty in July and yesterday Judge Charles Byers sentenced the three to 12, 15 and 18 months imprisonment.

Judge Byers said: "Not only did you abuse the trust and authority placed in you, but clearly your behaviour disgusted colleagues who saw what was going on in that cell.

"No one who heard those colleagues give evidence could have failed to notice the shock they felt by what they witnessed.

"During the course of that incident, not only did you let yourselves down but also the public and the prison service."

Unlock, the national association for ex-offenders, praised the prison service and the courts for not "sweeping [the attack] under the carpet" but warned that the officers could face a difficult life behind bars.

They would probably have to serve their sentences on special segregated wings with sex offenders and other inmates at risk from fellow prisoners, said Bobby Cummines, Unlock's deputy chief executive. "The prison sentence should send a message to those who practise gratuitous violence on prisoners."

Neil Smith, the Prison Officers Association solicitor who represented the officers, said an appeal against the convictions had already been lodged.

Martin Narey, the director-general of the prison service, welcomed the sentences and warned the "small minority" of prison officers who abused inmates to take "careful note".

"There is no place for staff who assault prisoners and those found guilty of doing so, whether at court or in internal proceedings, will be sacked," he said.

The judge ordered that a fourth officer, Amarjit Singh Jittlar, be acquitted after the jury failed to reach a verdict on a charge of assault. He is still suspended pending a decision on whether he should face an internal disciplinary hearing.

webTitle: Leader: Mo Mowlam to step down at next election

fields.headline: Mo says it's time to go
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: She wants to pursue another career. At 50, she has several years left of her working life and wants to do something different before she retires. She hopes to give time to such interests as poverty, the resolution of conflict and international affairs. Downing Street says it is just a career change, nothing more dramatic than that. The prime minister has a high regard for her abilities and is sure she still has a massive contribution to make.
fields.body:
She wants to pursue another career. At 50, she has several years left of her working life and wants to do something different before she retires. She hopes to give time to such interests as poverty, the resolution of conflict and international affairs. Downing Street says it is just a career change, nothing more dramatic than that. The prime minister has a high regard for her abilities and is sure she still has a massive contribution to make.

So much for the civilities. The reality may be a little different. Mo Mowlam is a middle-ranking cabinet minister. She has been in government for less than three and a half years. Yet yesterday her announcement that she would give up her seat and her government job at the next election provoked much the same kind of loving public salute as was given a mile or two down the road to the final London appearances of Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh. That is because Dr Mowlam is not just any old politician. She is seen as somebody special.

And that in a sense has been part of the problem. Despite the tributes from Downing Street and the public avowals of loyalty from Mo, there must be a strong suspicion that this leave-taking would not have occurred had things not come badly unstuck since the prime minister prised her out of the Northern Ireland Office. The very qualities which have made her the nation's favourite politician have left some of her colleagues uneasy and apprehensive. Mo is unplanned and unspun. She tends to say what she thinks just as it comes into her head. She is also unusually gutsy, as she showed through her serious illness. That was what made her such a smart choice for Northern Ireland. You only had to see her crossing the road to realise that here was a cabinet minister who was human being first and politician second. Unionist politicans distrusted her, seeing her as too friendly to republicans, but much of the public in Northern Ireland took her to their hearts just as she took them to hers. If you wanted a walking embodiment of a peace process, she was it.

But political leadership nowadays is also about watchfulness and coordination, and Mo Mowlam is too unguided for that. The openness, spilling at times into indiscretion, which delighted the crowd had colleagues hopping about in anxiety. Because of unionist reluctance to deal with her, some crucial negotiations were entrusted to other hands. At one crucial moment in Belfast, she had been left behind in London. In time, the conviction grew that a new approach was needed. That most unMowlamesque of operators, Peter Mandelson, was put in her place. She was given instead not a big department like health, as she had hoped, but a role as cabinet enforcer which marginalised her. Though Downing Street has always denied it, she increasingly came to feel she was being devalued behind her back. The high office for which she once hoped receded out of sight.

Though there may be surreptitious relief at the top that she will not be there to worry about for much longer, her decision to go will trouble her party. It removes a redoubtable woman from the commanding heights of government, where women are few. It suggests (and this may play especially badly with Labour's women supporters) that someone run by her heart as well as her head, who likes to be straight, who lacks any obvious talent for dissimulation, is seen as a bit of a misfit. Certainly there have been times when she has not been an easy colleague for Tony Blair and his entourage. They may find, though, that this comes to be seen as more of a judgment on them than it is on her.

Yet yesterday her announcement that she would give up her seat and her government job at the next election provoked much the same kind of loving public salute as was given a mile or two down the road to the final London appearances of Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh. That is because Dr Mowlam is not just any old politician. She is seen as somebody special. And that in a sense has been part of the problem. Despite the tributes from Downing Street and the public avowals of loyalty from Mo, there must be a strong suspicion that this leave-taking would not have occurred had things not come badly unstuck since the prime minister prised her out of the Northern Ireland Office. The very qualities which have made her the nation's favourite politician have left some of her colleagues uneasy and apprehensive. Mo is unplanned and unspun. She tends to say what she thinks just as it comes into her head. She is also unusually gutsy, as she showed through her serious illness. That was what made her such a smart choice for Northern Ireland. You only had to see her crossing the road to realise that here was a cabinet minister who was human being first and politician second. Unionist politicans distrusted her, seeing her as too friendly to republicans, but much of the public in Northern Ireland took her to their hearts just as she took them to hers. If you wanted a walking embodiment of a peace process, she was it. But political leadership nowadays is also about watchfulness and coordination, and Mo Mowlam is too unguided for that. The openness, spilling at times into indiscretion, which delighted the crowd had colleagues hopping about in anxiety. Because of unionist reluctance to deal with her, some crucial negotiations were entrusted to other hands. At one crucial moment in Belfast, she had been left behind in London. In time, the conviction grew that a new approach was needed. That most unMowlamesque of operators, Peter Mandelson, was put in her place. She was given instead not a big department like health, as she had hoped, but a role as cabinet enforcer which marginalised her. Though Downing Street has always denied it, she increasingly came to feel she was being devalued behind her back. The high office for which she once hoped receded out of sight. Though there may be surreptitious relief at the top that she will not be there to worry about for much longer, her decision to go will trouble her party. It removes a redoubtable woman from the commanding heights of government, where women are few. It suggests (and this may play especially badly with Labour's women supporters) that someone run by her heart as well as her head, who likes to be straight, who lacks any obvious talent for dissimulation, is seen as a bit of a misfit. Certainly there have been times when she has not been an easy colleague for Tony Blair and his entourage. They may find, though, that this comes to be seen as more of a judgment on them than it is on her.

fields.headline: Hague will 'privatise' universities
fields.standfirst:
Hague offers sale of TV airwaves to finance endowments to replace state-funding of colleges

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: William Hague will today prompt new accusations that he is embarking on a Thatch-erite tilt to the right when he outlines Tory plans to end state funding of universities.
fields.body:
William Hague will today prompt new accusations that he is embarking on a Thatch-erite tilt to the right when he outlines Tory plans to end state funding of universities.

Speaking at the launch of the Tories' pre-election manifesto, Mr Hague will declare that a Tory government would fund universities by handing over billions of pounds raised in government auctions.

The money, similar to the £20bn raised in the recent mobile phone licence auction, would be used to set up a series of endowment funds for individual universities across Britain. The universities would not be allowed to touch the capital, but they would be allowed to use the interest "to make whatever financial arrangements they like".

The money would replace the hundreds of millions of pounds provided by the state each year through the higher education funding council. A typical university, with a total income of £200m a year, receives about £50m from the council.

Mr Hague believes that his proposal, entitled Recovering Excellence, would give British universities the financial freedom to restore their reputation as the finest higher educational institutions in the world. His proposals would allow universities to set their own pay rates "to attract the world's best academics and researchers" - but they would not be allowed to set their own rate for tuition fees.

The Tories hope to put each university in Britain on the sort of financial footing enjoyed by Oxford and Cambridge colleges which benefit from huge endowments. Apart from endowments and state money, universities raise the rest of their funding through tuition fees for overseas and British students, research projects and private sector links.

The proposal - in the man-ifesto, entitled Believing in Britain - says: "Britain's best universities used to be the best in the world. Our most advanced educational institutions must recover their excellence."

However, Mr Hague's proposal is likely to provoke claims that the Tories want to create a two-tier university system. Under his plans, universities would have to apply for an endowment which would mean that top tier institutions, such as Oxford and Cambridge, would stand a good chance of securing the first endowments.

A Tory spokesman denied the proposals would create a new tier of elite universities. "We would be very careful to make sure that there is a broad cross section of universities in the first wave," he said. "We would want to have universities with a strong arts background along with science- based institutions."

Mr Hague's controversial proposal is designed to take the election battle directly onto Labour territory. Private polling by the two parties consistently show that the government enjoys a strong lead over the Tories in education after the prime minister's pledge to place "education education education" at the top of his agenda.

Mr Hague hopes that his plan will indicate that the Tories are determined to inject serious money into education, but in a way which will show the Thatcherite torch is still burning. The Tory document says that the eventual sell-off of today's television airwaves - when digital television cov ers the whole country - could raise up to £50bn for the university endowments scheme.

"Endowments are a sensible, prudent use of future one-off capital receipts, such as future radio spectrum auctions, analogue TV switch-off and privatisations," the document says. "They represent better value for money than simply putting those receipts into paying off government debt because, invested in universities, they would generate a better return than the rate of interest on government debt."

Educationists are likely to express fears that leaving university funding to the vagaries of the market could provide an unstable base for institutions to plan their future.
