She voted against the cut in benefits to lone parents and was a strong critic of the Nato action in Kosovo and the Anglo-American bombing raids on Iraq. Ms Wise also won respect as one of the most long-standing and energetic members of the Commons health select committee. As deputy chairwoman, Ms Wise in 1998 attacked successive British governments for shipping child migrants to distant parts of the empire in a long-suppressed experiment in social engineering. "What happened was a crass abuse of power," she said. The Labour MP Alice Mahon, one of Ms Wise's closest political friends, last night described her as "a legend in her own lifetime" who was never afraid to stand up to the Labour government. "Audrey never forgot her working class roots," Ms Mahon said, recalling Ms Wise's pride at being elected president of the shop workers' union Usdaw in 1991. "She was never afraid to oppose the Labour government, but was simply passionate about the Labour party. It was her life. Honest, clever and tenacious, Audrey Wise represented everything I value in the Labour movement. She was a dear friend and I will miss her dreadfully."

fields.headline: Police row over travellers' rave
fields.trailText: Police have come under fire for alleged inaction over an illegal three day rave attended by more than 2,000 travellers.
fields.body:
Police have come under fire for alleged inaction over an illegal three day rave attended by more than 2,000 travellers.

As council staff met last night to discuss the extent of the damage caused by the rave, police denied allegations that they failed to disperse the party-goers because of a lack of resources.

Angry residents and councillors in Tolworth, south-west London, accused officers of keeping a low profile when the travellers flocked to Tolworth Court Farm on Friday evening. By Saturday night seven stages were blaring out music on the site, owned by Kingston-upon-Thames council.

Dave Rogers, vice chairman of the Police Federation, said: "Officers felt they were undermanned. Only 15 officers were on duty. Whether there should have been more numbers is up for debate."

A Scotland Yard spokesman denied a lack of resources had caused officers to maintain a low profile.

"We do have powers to go in and disperse people, but it was decided that it might have caused more public order problems," he said.

"If a decision had been made to remove people, appropriate resources would have been made available. The decision was not resource based."

However, Keith Witham, a Conservative councillor, said the police response had been inadequate and had failed residents, some of whom had booked into hotels to escape the noise.

"The noise carried for miles and residents have had to put up with hell all weekend. I'm absolutely seething the police were not able or willing to use their powers to protect residents," he said.

Police made three arrests over the weekend, two for drug-related offences.

Bob Smart, chief environmental officer for the council, said the main powers for seizing equipment and dealing with illegal raves rested with police and not local authorities.

He said: "When the numbers became more manageable on Sunday we went in with police and spoke to the travellers who said they would turn the music off by 8pm." Press Association

webTitle: A new way to break the ice at the local

fields.headline: A new way to break the ice at the local
fields.trailText: It is the perfect tipple for the overheated beer drinker seeking more than just liquid refreshment - a superchilled lager served with a frozen head.
fields.body:
It is the perfect tipple for the overheated beer drinker seeking more than just liquid refreshment - a superchilled lager served with a frozen head.

Thanks to a casual suggestion by a PhD student on placement, brewers Bass have developed the first sub-zero draught lager, which comes topped with an inch of ice crystals. And while beer purists may shiver at the prospect, the brewery is confident it will be able to tempt British pub-goers away from their traditional preference for warm ale.

Much of the pleasure from a pint of Arc lager may be in the pouring. Before enjoying a drink of the chilly lager top, drinkers are treated to a serving display worthy of a cocktail waiter.

The revolutionary process begins with the empty pint glass being placed on a specially designed rotating font and sprayed with a blast of chilled water.

The lager is served at a temperature of -2C (28F), and stored at high pressure to keep it from freezing solid. When the drink is poured from the pump the pressure is released and a blast of ultrasonic waves triggers the formation of ice crystals around the beer's gas bubbles.

To date Arc has been launched only in two pubs, in north London and Watford, but the brewery claims the beer gained the highest approval rating of any of its products in taste tests.

"We knew we had something revolutionary when the lager scored exceptionally well in market research - 75% of participants said they would definitely buy this product," said David Griffiths, the new product development manager at Bass.

But not all beer-lovers are convinced. Iain Loe, research manager at the Campaign for Real Ale, believes drinkers will soon tire of what he calls a marketing gimmick.

"At the temperatures at which they are talking of serving it you won't be able to taste anything," he says. "Beers, be they ales or lagers, should be served cool, but never iced. Certainly not in a way where they could almost be served on a stick."

Arc lager will be launched nationwide later in the autumn.

In the meantime, drinkers will have to content themselves with adding their own ice cubes.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Man killed in mosque row
fields.body:
Man killed in mosque row

A man was stabbed to death after a row believed to have been over his nomination as secretary of a mosque in Middlesbrough. Ali Rahman, 30, a part-time university student and taxi driver, was discovered with chest wounds on Sunday night. Police are questioning two men.

Cold comfort for chemists

Sales of powerful cold and flu remedies hit a record £438m last year according to a report in the trade magazine The Grocer. It says that many people now consider that taking time off work for a cold is no longer an option and demand the strongest remedies for speedy relief.

Grey squirrels face cull

Hundreds of grey squirrels are to be culled in the Tyne Valley, and Derwent Valley in Co Durham. Their booming population threatens endangered red squirrels by competing for food and passing on a lethal virus, parapox.

TV advert to attract nurses

A £13,000 TV advertising campaign to attract staff is being planned by the East Kent hospitals trust. Hilary Brian, recruitment manager of the trust, which manages five hospitals, said: "The campaign only has to recruit five former nurses and midwives to be effectual and we're hoping there will be many more than that."

fields.headline: Referee accuses FA of discrimination
fields.trailText: A leading Asian football referee has claimed he was racially discriminated against by the Football Association and Football League when he was sacked.
fields.body:
A leading Asian football referee has claimed he was racially discriminated against by the Football Association and Football League when he was sacked.

Gurnam Singh, who began refereeing professional matches in 1989, alleged at an employment tribunal in Birmingham yesterday that he was dismissed because of his race. His claim is being supported by the commission for racial equality.

Mr Singh, 46, from Wolverhampton, who is also an accountant, claimed he was discriminated against despite achieving higher merit ratings than some of his white colleagues who were kept on.

It is the first time a match official has launched a race discrimination action against the FA and the league.

Mr Singh said yesterday : "I just want some kind of justice. They are making me out to be a bad referee and I just want to set the record straight.

"Although it is inevitable that I would encounter some sort of discrimination from the football terraces, I did not think I would receive it from the authorities themselves."

Mr Singh's claim hinges on his performances in the Football League, which are graded by clubs after each game. The performances are also verified by an independent assessor, usually a former referee.

The league claims Mr Singh's marks were consistently low over several years, which forced the FA to remove him from its register in May last year. "There was no indication this was coming," said Mr Singh. "I feel totally disenchanted."

Manjit Panesar, representing Mr Singh, said he was the most highly marked referee to be removed from the list at any time. In the 1994-95 season, he had come top of the referees' merit list with an average mark of 7.31 out of 10. But despite his experience he was given significantly fewer Division One games.

The tribunal was told that during the 1994-95 season a meeting was held to nominate referees for Premiership matches. As discussions progres sed Ken Ridden, of the national review body, which carries out independent assessments of referees, was alleged to have said of Mr Singh: "We don't want people like him in the Premier League."

Mr Panesar said that because of non promotion, Mr Singh had been denied an opportunity to apply to Fifa- the governing body for world football - to referee international fixtures.

Favourable reports about his refereeing were received from the managers of Manchester City, Sheffield United, Tranmere Rovers and Shrewsbury Town, the tribunal heard.

A written note from Graham Taylor, the former England manager, said he felt that Mr Singh was competent and made no more or fewer mistakes than his colleagues.

The case is being contested by the FA, the Football League, the Premier League and the national review body.

The hearing continues.

webTitle: Cocaine smuggler challenges deportation as breach of human rights

fields.headline: Cocaine smuggler challenges deportation as breach of human rights
fields.trailText: A Ghanaian convicted cocaine importer has launched a high court challenge to the decision to deport him to his home country, claiming it would violate his right to family life under the European convention on human rights.
fields.body:
A Ghanaian convicted cocaine importer has launched a high court challenge to the decision to deport him to his home country, claiming it would violate his right to family life under the European convention on human rights.

Ernest Doku, who was granted parole in June after serving four and a half years of a 12-year sentence, argues that the move would breach his human rights by separating him from his British wife and son, and from his two British daughters from an earlier relationship.

Yesterday his counsel, Cherie Booth QC, failed to persuade a high court judge to release Doku on bail pending his application for judicial review early next month. His case is expected to be one of the first challenges to come to court after the Human Rights Act comes into force on October 2, incorporating the European convention into English law.

Following a trial at Isleworth crown court, west London, in December 1995, Doku was convicted of being knowingly concerned in the importation of five kilograms of cocaine. He was jailed for 12 years and his deportation was recommended.

He was granted parole in June but he continues to be held at the Verne prison, Portland, Dorset, while the papers for his deportation are being processed.

For about 10 years before he came to the UK in 1976, Doku, 64, worked as a barrister for the Ghanaian ministry of justice. He married his British wife, Suzie, who lives in Wembley, north London, three years after arriving in the UK. Their son, Ernest, is at university. His daughters are in their 20s.

Doku, who has a masters degree in social sciences and international relations, established a successful business exporting commodities and building materials to Ghana. He was granted indefinite leave to remain in the UK in 1983.

Ms Booth told Mr Justice Jackson that Doku had been a model prisoner, and had successfully completed a programme that helps prisoners develop a sense of self-respect and responsibility. He had since helped other prisoners complete the programme.

But the judge refused him bail, saying there was a risk of absconding, particularly if the decision in a similar case to be heard shortly before his own went against him.

The courts are bracing themselves for a raft of claims under the Human Rights Act, with immigration and deportation predicted to be a fertile area.

Under the convention, the right to family life is not absolute. The state may legiti mately interfere with it for a number of reasons, including "for the prevention of disorder or crime". But the state must not go further than is necessary to achieve that aim.

The European court of human rights in Strasbourg held in one case that there was no violation where the applicant brought his deportation on himself by breaching immigration controls.

webTitle: Police chief accused of sexual assaults

fields.headline: Police chief accused of sexual assaults
fields.trailText: One of Britain's most senior police officers is accused of sexually assaulting a woman in a darkened office during a series of incidents which left her and a female colleague feeling "frightened, abused and vulnerable " .
fields.body:
One of Britain's most senior police officers is accused of sexually assaulting a woman in a darkened office during a series of incidents which left her and a female colleague feeling "frightened, abused and vulnerable " .

The deputy chief constable of Surrey, Ian Beckett, 54, allegedly put his hand inside one victim's underwear, groped the breast and bottom of another and made lewd remarks about knickers, Southwark crown court heard yesterday.

The jury was told that Mr Beckett was "unable to control his sexual behaviour" and thought he could get away with his conduct towards the two civilian workers because he was second in command of the force and contemplating promotion.

Mr Beckett, of Chertsey, Surrey, is accused of four indecent assaults on two women - given the names Miss X and Miss Y as they cannot be named for legal reasons - between December 14 and Christmas Eve, 1998.

He has denied the charges, claiming the allegations are lies and fantasy.

"He took advantage of his position of seniority," Sallie Bennett-Jenkins, prosecuting, said. "These assaults were committed in the belief the victims would never be able to complain. He was a man who abused his position of authority to carry out sexual assaults of increasing gravity."

The women were allegedly attacked on December 14 1998 at Surrey's headquarters, Mount Browne, near Guildford. Miss X told the court yesterday that she was summoned into Mr Beckett's office, where he told her that the then chief constable of Surrey, Ian Blair, had been tipped by a newspaper to succeed Sir Paul Condon as head of the Metropolitan Police.

She said they agreed Mr Blair, now deputy commissioner of the Met, would apply for the post, a move which would leave Mr Beckett in charge of Surrey.

"I got up to go and walked towards the door," said Miss X. "At that point he moved ahead of me as if to open the door. In fact, he locked the door, and because it was daylight, he switched the lights off. I was very frightened.

"He was facing me and he put both his arms around me. My body was in contact with his. I said 'Mr Beckett, the chief constable is likely to walk in, you know he is. This is stupid'.

"He just smiled, let me go and unlocked the door. Afterwards I thought about what happened. I became very, very angry that he had threatened me. His behaviour worried me considerably."

Miss Bennett-Jenkins said Mr Beckett targeted Miss X again on Christmas Eve and is alleged to have rung her the day before to ask if she would wear red knickers for him.

On Christmas Eve, he called Miss X into his office and asked whether she had recovered from a recent illness.

"He hugged her," said Miss Bennett-Jenkins. "He pinned her arms and put his left hand up her skirt. She said 'no, please, I have no energy to fight you'. The defendant said 'let me touch you'."

Mr Beckett allegedly put his hand inside Miss X's under wear and assaulted her. She protested again.

"He let her go and wished her a happy Christmas," said Miss Bennett-Jenkins. "Understandably she found this attack intolerable in the extreme."

The court heard that after the first incident Miss X spoke to the chief constable, Mr Blair and said she felt physically vulnerable around Mr Beckett.

He allegedly warned her to think carefully before making any formal allegations because it was "a big step to take".

Miss X decided to pursue the complaint but her appointment with a senior personnel officer was not until January 5, 1999. Unknown to her, another woman had also accused Mr Beckett of assaulting her on December 14.

The woman was in the assistant chief constable's office when Mr Beckett allegedly approached and said: "You know I have always been fond of you."

Miss Bennett-Jenkins added: "As she walked towards the door he put his hand on her bottom, open handed underneath her buttock, almost between her legs."

Mr Beckett is accused of assaulting Miss Y again a week later. On this occasion, Miss Bennett-Jenkins said, she was sitting at her desk when he crossed the room and "without hesitation put his hand on her breast and kissed her on the lips." Miss Y immediately knocked his arm away.

Mr Beckett was suspended on January 8 1999.

He is said to have told investigators Miss Y might have been motivated by revenge because he had reprimanded some staff over the sending of an obscene email which depicted a snowman with an erection.

The case continues.

webTitle: Leader: Was Picasso's painting style due to his suffering from migraines?

fields.headline: What the painter saw
fields.standfirst: Picasso's vision? Or merely his migraine?
fields.trailText: Reports that Picasso painted the way he did not so much out of choice as because of the fractured vision which afflicts some migraine suffererers need to be treated with caution. Even if we suppose such a connection to be the case, or are finally convinced by comparisons between the view of the world as seen by sufferers of migraine during an attack and paintings by Picasso which appear to display the same characteristics, we should be careful what significance we attribute to it. (Was Braque similarly afflicted?)
fields.body:
Reports that Picasso painted the way he did not so much out of choice as because of the fractured vision which afflicts some migraine suffererers need to be treated with caution. Even if we suppose such a connection to be the case, or are finally convinced by comparisons between the view of the world as seen by sufferers of migraine during an attack and paintings by Picasso which appear to display the same characteristics, we should be careful what significance we attribute to it. (Was Braque similarly afflicted?)

There may be some temptation among those for whom the art of the 20th century has always been a headache to believe its whole perplexing course might have been altered by a couple of aspirin. Apart from misunderstanding the nature of migraine this would, even more grossly, be to misunderstand the complexity of artistic creativity. A headache is not a substitute for inspiration.

Dr Ferrari, of the medical centre at Leiden university, who has made the interesting observations about migraine and Picasso, is by no means the first to attempt to diagnose a medical or physical condition contributing to the creation of famous works of art. Patrick Trevor-Roper, in the articles gathered in his book The World Through Blunted Sight (1970), made fascinating and persuasive suggestions about a connection between sight defects and the work of a number of painters. He suggested, for example, that forms of astigmatism may have produced the elongated figures of El Greco or the broad spread of Holbein's portraits; that cataracts may have determined Monet's choice of colours; and that the lack of detail in late Titian may have been due to presbyopia, the loss of focus with age. These theories are intriguing, and in Professor Trevor-Roper's words, none the worse for airing, but in the end there is no easy diagnosis and therefore no easy cure for art. Headache or not, we should be thankful for that.

Apart from misunderstanding the nature of migraine this would, even more grossly, be to misunderstand the complexity of artistic creativity. A headache is not a substitute for inspiration. Dr Ferrari, of the medical centre at Leiden university, who has made the interesting observations about migraine and Picasso, is by no means the first to attempt to diagnose a medical or physical condition contributing to the creation of famous works of art. Patrick Trevor-Roper, in the articles gathered in his book The World Through Blunted Sight (1970), made fascinating and persuasive suggestions about a connection between sight defects and the work of a number of painters. He suggested, for example, that forms of astigmatism may have produced the elongated figures of El Greco or the broad spread of Holbein's portraits; that cataracts may have determined Monet's choice of colours; and that the lack of detail in late Titian may have been due to presbyopia, the loss of focus with age. These theories are intriguing, and in Professor Trevor-Roper's words, none the worse for airing, but in the end there is no easy diagnosis and therefore no easy cure for art. Headache or not, we should be thankful for that.

webTitle: Doctors' warning on head lice chemicals

fields.headline: Doctors' warning on head lice chemicals
fields.trailText: Doctors yesterday warned of "alarming" evidence that parents were risking head lice becoming immune to chemical treatments by regularly using insecticides on their children's hair in the mistaken belief that this can stop them getting nits.
fields.body:
Doctors yesterday warned of "alarming" evidence that parents were risking head lice becoming immune to chemical treatments by regularly using insecticides on their children's hair in the mistaken belief that this can stop them getting nits.

In a public education campaign at the start of the school year, the Doctor Patient Partnership, an arm of the British Medical Association, published a poll showing nearly 50% of 1,000 adults surveyed thought head lice could be dangerous if not treated. In fact head lice do not usually cause health problems.

"Alarmingly, almost 30% think regularly using chemical treatments will ensure that children do not catch head lice," the partnership said.

The poll by NOP Solutions found 70% of people incorrectly thought head lice jumped from one head to another, when in fact they crawled across as heads come into contact.

One in five mistakenly believed that a person with head lice should see a doctor, and one in six people over 65 thought head lice thrived only in dirty hair. The misconceptions were addressed in 300,000 leaflets distributed to GP surgeries throughout the UK.

Nigel Hill, a medical entomologist at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said: "One of the problems surrounding the issue of head lice is a lack of understanding by the public and many health professionals."

Simon Fradd, chairman of the DPP, said: "Accepting the fact that head lice are likely to happen to your children or grandchildren is an important first step towards managing the problem effectively."

fields.headline: Second homes blamed for 'ghost towns'
fields.standfirst: Cornwall MP calls for tax to curb holiday cottage boom
fields.trailText: It is a picture postcard example of Cornwall's appeal to visitors: a small town of steep winding streets, bristling with signs of its medieval, Tudor and Victorian past.
fields.body:
It is a picture postcard example of Cornwall's appeal to visitors: a small town of steep winding streets, bristling with signs of its medieval, Tudor and Victorian past.

Fowey, with a population just over 2,100, overlooks a beautiful estuary where sailing boats nestle under wooded hills and the autumn regatta is a popular occasion. It hosts an annual festival in honour of the area's most famous author, Daphne Du Maurier.

Yet according to the local MP, Colin Breed, 30% of the homes in Fowey are second homes. "In January and February at the weekend the whole place is quite decimated."

Mr Breed, the Liberal Democrat spokesman on agriculture and rural affairs, stoked the debate on second homes yesterday when he launched a discussion document calling for an end to 50% council tax rebates on them and urging that councils be able to force people buying houses they were not going to live in the whole time to ask for special planning permission.

The document said the "increased immigration of wealthy and more affluent people" had forced house prices up and cut the amount of affordable housing to local people. Lembit Opik, the Lib Dem MP for Montgomeryshire, added: "We don't want the countryside to become a dormitory for the weekend."

The party is considering a new form of "tied housing" where, like the farmworkers' cottages of old, rural houses are set aside for teachers or other key workers who otherwise could not afford to move to desirable areas.

Estate agents in Fowey yesterday were not sure that restrictions were necessary yet. Chris Parsons, a partner in May, Whetter and Grose, said: "There is a hard core of local people who would like to stay in town and buy a house and cannot afford the property prices we now have here.

"But there is so little employment locally that it is likely they would have to go out of the county anyway." He did not think the proportion of second homes had changed significantly for years.

"I suppose if we reached the point where 40-50 % were holiday homes, we might need to consider restrictions."

A three-bedroom property on the waterfront could now fetch £300,000 or more, and 70% of his buyers were from the home counties. But they were not generally buying properties previously occupied by locals.

Estate agent Max Harrower, of Fowey River, also denied things had changed much in recent years. "A lot of people coming here are providing income for people locally. People come back here and say it has not been spoilt commercially. It is a natural place for some to come down and spend a few weeks a year and perhaps do a bit of holiday letting."

Restormel district council disputed Mr Breed's figure, and said the true percentage of holiday homes in Fowey was nearer 15%.

Some fashionable spots on Cornwall's north coast have an even higher proportion of second homes. As many as 70% of properties in Treyarnon Bay, near Padstow, may be holiday homes, says John Weller, prospective Tory parliamentary candidate for north Cornwall, and leader of Restormel district council.

English councils, like those in Wales, should have the discretion to charge full council tax, he said. "No one who is well enough off to come to live in such a beautiful place would not want it to regenerate itself."

Such a change could bring Cornwall county council an extra £5m for education and social services. If the government did not introduce new powers in the expected rural white paper, Tories in the west country would want it in their party manifesto for the next general election, he said. "It is not a party political thing. Most people find it realistic."

There are thought to be about 250,000 second homes in England and Wales. Ministers have been hinting at action, but Michael Meacher, the environment minister, who owns a second home in Gloucestershire, was accused last year of threatening to start a "class war" when he suggested that they should be banned in some areas.

fields.headline: Woodhead put to the test
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead calls for a "fresh look" at A-level standards. That's fine, but it depends who's doing the looking.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead (Putting the stress on excellence, September 4) calls for a "fresh look" at A-level standards. That's fine, but it depends who's doing the looking.

The Standards Over Time study was supposed to solve this problem, but that didn't collapse just because of a shortage of scripts. Woodhead was unhappy with the Ofsted representative, and personally replaced him. He then argued with Nick Tate over the committee's conclusions, so that they were unable to produce an agreed report.

It would be a start to have the Ofsted analysis on which Woodhead's current opinions are based. Two years running the parliamentary select committee has criticised his willingness to pronounce without supportive evidence. We have the assurance of Estelle Morris that "there is a long-standing convention that HM Inspectors' advice and comment on educational standards is in every case underpinned by inspection evidence." And yet somehow, in your lavish coverage of his outburst, we didn't get the analysis that would justify the headline, or the questioning which might probe its absence. Maybe next time, eh?


Paul Francis
Much Wenlock, Shropshire

 Your interview with Chris Woodhead was more notable for his outburst of polemic than substance. The only evidence presented to support his bogus claims that A-levels are too easy is a continued rise in the number and quality of grades from candidates and the fact that in each of his recent annual reports the quality of teaching is improving. In HMCI's bizarre logic improved teaching and improved performance by pupils equals falling standards.

Teachers have rarely been awarded praise by the HMCI but their achievement and that of their students at both GCSE and A-level must not be tarnished by a man who is an addict to self-publicity.


Phil Willis MP
Liberal Democrat shadow secretary for education and employment

 No doubt new world records will be set in the Sydney Olympics. As more and more athletes can now run the 100 metres in under 10 seconds, will Chris Woodhead be observing that the 100 metres is getting easier?


Kevin Cowen
Kidderminster, Worcs
KCowen@kidderminster.ac.uk

 As someone who is of the same generation as Mr Woodhead, I question how a person whose usage of language and grammar are so poor can presume to criticise others. The quote given on your front page did little to enhance his standing in my eyes. Does anyone know if Mr Woodhead gained a pass in English literature and/or grammar at O and A level?
Kathleen Hines
Washington, Tyne and Wear
Kathleen@hines996.freeserve.co.uk

 Paraphrasing Mr Woodhead, we can't have a situation where a Chief Inspector of Schools is kept on longer and longer and at greater annual public expense, but who has ended up knowing no more than people did in the dark ages when he began his first flirtation with teaching.


John Coopey
Kendal, Cumbria

 The first day of the new school year and the Guardian has a report on Woodhead's views on the front page and an interview (with photograph) on page 8. What are you trying to do? Drive teachers to cancel their subscriptions to your paper?

Personally, I would be a lot more interested in Darren Tackle's views on education. I'm sure they would be better informed.


SH Lupton
Prestwich, Manchester
shlpictures@eggconnect.net

fields.headline: Mind your language
fields.trailText: My experience as a patient treated by Asian doctors has shown them to be both competent and caring, while their command of colloquial English was superior to that of most EU immigrants.
fields.body:
My experience as a patient treated by Asian doctors has shown them to be both competent and caring, while their command of colloquial English was superior to that of most EU immigrants. Maybe when Dr Genthe (Letters, September 4) has practised in the UK a little longer he will learn to relate better to the actual socio-cultural make-up of present day Britain and adopt a less narrow-minded attitude.


John Parry
Secretary, European Multicultural Foundation

A few years ago I was regularly visiting hospital and was seen by registrars from a wide variety of ethnic and geographical origins. The Asian ones posed little problem, but the culture gap with the one Australian I saw was quite unbridgeable.


John R Batts
Banbury, Oxon
johnbatts@banbury19. freeserve.co.uk

fields.headline: A service in crisis
fields.trailText: Congratulations on raising the important issue of recruitment and retention problems in the public sector. These difficulties will get worse over the next 20 years with an increasing ageing workforce and a significant reduction in the number of young people in the labour market
fields.body:
Congratulations on raising the important issue of recruitment and retention problems in the public sector (Leader, September 4). These difficulties will get worse over the next 20 years with an increasing ageing workforce and a significant reduction in the number of young people in the labour market. Action is needed now to address current and future problems and the government must start by presenting more positive images of the public sector. It is obvious that continually criticising public servants impacts directly on morale and service quality which in turn leads to them openly complaining about their own work environment to colleagues, friends and, more importantly, their own children. Many of us now discourage our children from pursuing a career in public service. As the public sector fights to attract young people in an increasingly competitive labour market, the government must review its presentation of the value of public service .We need an attitudinal shift from our ministers.


Terry Gorman
President, Society of Chief Personnel Officers in Local Government
terry.gorman@nottscc.gov.uk

 The health of any nation is measured by the strength of its public services. There is indeed a recruitment crisis in the public sector and we should all be worried about this. As your leader points out, part of the blame lies with governments of all colours who have misled potential recruits into believing that by definition the public sector is wasteful, inefficient and resistant to change. What makes things worse is that in local government at least, there is also a crisis of retention, with far too many experienced and knowledgeable older workers leaving to take early retirement. Our research shows that ill health, possibly brought on by the stress induced by massive and constant change, is a major reason. Council workers we have talked to want to stay in local government, as long as councils can be more flexible in the way they employ and manage their people. We (ie local government, government and the public) need to change our attitudes and give them some support.


Paul Masterman
Head of public sector recruitment, TMP Worldwide, Birmingham
pmasterman@tmpw.co.uk


 Would those employers complaining about a skills shortage be the same downsizing, core/periphery, hire and fire employers who don't train people?


Bryan Sadler
Lancaster
bryan@bhsadler.free-online.co.uk

fields.headline: More ethical dilemmas
fields.trailText: Your report that New Labour is about to drop any commitment to an "ethical dimension" to UK foreign policy sends yet another depressing message about the cynicism and opportunism of Britain's main political parties.
fields.body:
Your report that New Labour is about to drop any commitment to an "ethical dimension" to UK foreign policy (Labour drops 'ethical' tag, September 4) sends yet another depressing message about the cynicism and opportunism of Britain's main political parties.

Time and again, ethical and environmental aims are sacrificed for short-term economic or political advantage. New Labour has found it only possible to be "ethical" if there are no competing demands for government backing, for example arms sales or contracts to build huge dams. Our political system is increasingly value-free and geared to promoting economic growth above human rights and environmental protection.

In the long-run, the stability and sustainability of the world's environment and political system depends on human values and ethical concerns being at the heart of government decisions. Foreign policy "realists" (or cynics) forget this fact at their peril.

Peter Hain pleads that the Labour government should "be judged by our record", whether there is any explicit promise to behave ethically or not. Friends of the Earth would be happy if that test was applied by the public. We still await, for example, the government's final decision on whether or not to give insurance backing to the building of the Ilisu Dam. Some decisions cannot be ducked forever, nor obscured behind a fuzz of warm rhetoric.


Tony Juniper
Policy and campaigns director, Friends of the Earth

 Poor old Robin Cook! It had been a millstone round his neck, you see... I feel sorry for him. Now at least we can sell arms to whoever we want to and no jumped up human rights people can throw "ethical foreign policy" in his face. Could New Labour get any more boring in their depressing predictability?


Chris Welch
Sheffield

webTitle: Some answers to that age old question of faith

fields.headline: Some answers to that age old question of faith
fields.trailText: I am one of the credulous, soft-headed people you refer to by implication - one of your older readers who still has a strong and lively faith, and this despite years of subjection to the religion-bashing of some of your contributors.
fields.body:
I am one of the credulous, soft-headed people you refer to by implication (Leader, September 4) - one of your older readers who still has a strong and lively faith, and this despite years of subjection to the religion-bashing of some of your contributors.

There are many reasons why people leave the organised church at any age. Conventional church attendance is likely to dwindle as those who have no strong commitment of faith find other things to do. We who remain will not be shaken by your patronising caricature of us.

The comments you make about the findings of this research imply an accepted stereotype of older people who happen to be people of faith as gullible, uneducated, fearful of death, lacking in opportunities for social contact and life choices. Is this how you see us?


Gillian Collins
Sittingbourne, Kent
gillian.collins@virgin.net


 Your otherwise challenging leader suggests that to be better educated is to be less faithful. Do you have evidence for this - or is it merely an educated guess?


Rt Rev Dr John Saxbee
Bishop of Ludlow


 The Christian church is as committed to "life" as any of the older people in today's society. The Christian faith is primarily about this life, and the love, hope, justice and community that make it more abundant. It may be that some Christians stress the "insurance policy approach" but most of us are much more interested in life here and now. Which other organisation is so committed to those outside it, especially the poor and needy, both at home and abroad?

Was the hint of glee in your remark about "terminal demographic decline" another example of the Guardian's arrogance with respect to religious faith? Your analysis is remarkably Eurocentric; the Christian church is growing globally, among the young as well as old. Believe me, we'll be here long after you've gone.


Rev David Haslam
London
davidhaslam@easynet.co.uk


 Is it any wonder we become faithless? I live in an historic conservation village. In order to raise income the vicar and his parochial church council have agreed to the erection of a mobile phone aerial on the tower of the 11th century church and a noisy base station in the churchyard over some graves. This regardless of any threat to the wellbeing of those living close by.

Christ whipped buyers and sellers from the temple: modern Christians invite them in.


Jackie Lloyd
Dunchurch, Warwickshire
JACLLO1@rugbycoll.ac.uk


 I don't recall ever before having read anything quite so patronisingly and offensively ageist as your leader.

However, as I'm a regular go-to-meeting Quaker and will be 80 next year, I suppose that your clever young leader writer would expect me to say that.


Ernest Hall
Clacton-on-Sea, Essex
ernesthall@beeb.net

However, as I'm a regular go-to-meeting Quaker and will be 80 next year, I suppose that your clever young leader writer would expect me to say that. fields.headline: Proof of the pudding
fields.trailText: Catherine Flury would have done well to read my piece on Yorkshire puddings before writing to say that I "had it wrong".
fields.body:
Catherine Flury would have done well to read my piece on Yorkshire puddings before writing to say that I "had it wrong" (Letters, September 2). "Early Yorkshire puddings were... made in a vast rectangular tin and cut into squares to be served," I wrote. Yet, "originally Yorkshire puddings were never little individual puddings," lambasts Ms Flury. I rest my case.


Victoria Moore
London

Prof Diana Donald
Buxton, Derbyshire

 French fishermen did blockade Mediterranean as well as Channel ports (Letters, September 2). Admittedly, you wouldn't know this from reading English papers.


Frank Winter
Gent, Belgium

fields.headline: Diary
fields.body:
When the histories of New Labour come to be written, the smear campaign against Mo Mowlam - one tolerated, if not actively commissioned, by that "pretty straight guy" Mr Tony Blair - will rank among the basest achievements of that poisonous little cabal. Whatever the reason for our most beloved Mo's departure, let's hope Mr T and the boys feel some residue of embarrassment. Yesterday, meanwhile, provided Nicky Campbell, presenter of Radio 5 Live's outstanding morning phone-in, with a journalistic triumph worthy of the Times' news editor Michael Govey. (It was Govey whose ground-breaking biography of Polly Portillo made no mention of his varsity experimentation, and Govey also missed the defection to Labour of Ivan Massow, his recent flatmate.) Even he would have been proud to have interviewed Mo's husband Jon Norton about his forthcoming art exhibition, without pressing him about the rumours. The interview ended at 11am - just as Downing Street made its announcement about Mo.

The News of the World political column of Sion Simon, who also writes in the Daily Telegraph and the Spectator, is a typically splendid read, not least for Sion's gift for reading the Labour leadership's thinking on every conceivable issue. Honestly, it's so uncanny one begins to suspect telepathy. One small point, though. To negate the risk that readers might be misled, wouldn't it be better if Sion considered changing his name by deed poll to Alastair Campbell?

I am surprised by the Bookseller's diary's response to the item here about Anthony Cheetham and the Fatty Cheetham song ... the ditty traditionally sung sotto voce to the tune of Chitty Chitty Bang Bang, whenever the much-loved head of Orion enters a party. "Wide, low, Fatty Fatty Cheetham, Fatty Fatty Cheetham we love you," goes the chorus. "And our Fatty Fatty Cheetham, Fatty Fatty Cheetham loves us too ... Bang, bang, Fatty Fatty Cheetham, our fine four-bellied friend," and so on. Mistaking our tone, my so-called rival accuses us of "sniping" and announces the Friends of Cheetham - a body set up "to lobby for, at the very least, a quiet life for this great bookman, and at best a knighthood". We're behind that, and to end the confusion will make the first donation.

A recent front-page report in the Yorkshire Post comes to our attention. "Ms Evans says her findings could prompt a revolution in traditional views about the British and their origins, although her views have been met by scepticism from scholars who believe her claims are based on scanty evidence," writes Mike Waites, "and that the Egyptians had neither the technology nor the desire to travel to Britain."

The time has come to say goodbye to that fecund August space-filler, the dangerously exciting tourist attraction. We all know the Keswick Pencil Museum and the Yelverton Paperweight Centre, but here is a name check for a few others that surely deserve a visit: the Cardew Teapottery ("Home of the World's Most Collectable Teapots!") in Devon; the Salt Museum ("Britain's only salt museum!") in Northwich; the House of Marbles ("masses of free parking"), another Devon corker; St Helens' World of Glass ("experience the mystery"); the Chess Museum on Grimsey Island, north of the Arctic Circle; and, finally, the Musée du Béret, "unique au monde", in Nay (Nay and thrice Nay), northwest of Lourdes.

It's also farewell to what was, I think, a very good inaugural Gerald Kaufman Month. Well, perhaps we can postpone it a little. Relentless plugging of Roger Law's forthcoming exhibition, in the hope that he will give us the Spitting Image Gerald as a competition prize, will ensue shortly. Meanwhile, we have done a deal with Cadbury's, and in pursuance of that the final picture of Gerald will appear tomorrow. Otherwise, that's it.

fields.headline: CBI issues red tape alert
fields.standfirst: Labour is warned to halt workplace legislation or lose support of business world
fields.trailText: Britain's leading employers' organisation is calling on the government to face down demands for paid parental leave and enhanced maternity rights, warning that the prospect of more employment red tape is the biggest single deterrent to investment in the UK.
fields.body:
Britain's leading employers' organisation is calling on the government to face down demands for paid parental leave and enhanced maternity rights, warning that the prospect of more employment red tape is the biggest single deterrent to investment in the UK.

Digby Jones, director general of the Confederation of British Industry, said that his members feared extra workers' rights legislation was being planned for the Queen's speech later this year in an attempt to woo Labour's core supporters in the run-up to the election.

"Enough is enough," Mr Jones said in an interview with the Guardian. "We have had 16 pieces of employment legislation in two years. I hope Tony Blair and Gordon Brown will behave like statesmen and put the country first."

Calls for further employment legislation, including paid leave for both parents and the right of women to return to work part time after maternity leave, will be on the agenda at next week's TUC conference in Glasgow and are also being pressed hard by grassroots campaigners inside the Labour party.

However, with the shadow chancellor, Michael Portillo, announcing last week that the Conservatives will make cutting the regulatory burden on business a main plank of their economic strategy, senior ministers are concerned that new laws could jeopardise their cordial relations with the CBI and other employers' groups.

In a clear effort to put pressure on the government to mothball any plans for further legislation, Mr Jones said that red tape was a common worry among CBI members and exacerbated the impact on busi ness competitiveness of the strong pound. Labour's attitude over the next six to nine months would be a test of its pro-business credentials.

"This government might talk about how it's business friendly, but they are coming into an election year and - notwithstanding a big majority and a big lead in the opinion polls - they are looking to their heartlands for support.

"The trade unions are saying that their support comes at a price and part of that price is more employment legislation."

Mr Jones said the CBI would be producing a business manifesto at its national confer ence in Birmingham in November that would outline what was needed from the next government.

He said that the CBI wanted assurances from Mr Portillo that the Conservatives would not renege on Labour's commitment to spend more on transport and to beef up regional development agencies, but that red tape was a key issue, particularly for small businesses and inward investors.

"I hope that the Queen's speech does not pander to Labour's core support and give away to the trade unions so many things in legislation, spending and tax that will do absolutely nothing for the competitiveness of Britain, nothing to create lasting jobs and nothing to show the boardrooms in Tokyo, Johannesburg and Detroit that we are the best place to do business.

"I fear there will be some parts of the government's legislative programme which will have some of the characteristics of their predecessors.

"The TUC has shown responsibility. It has dedicated itself to making Britain more competitive and we can see that coming through. I hope the unions don't lose the plot."

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Three sacked in Rover bribe row
fields.body:
Three sacked in Rover bribe row

Three managers at the Rover plant at Longbridge in Birmingham have been sacked after claims that they demanded more than £2,000 in bribes to sign redundancy applications. The three were suspended last week while an internal investigation was held.

Rover said yesterday that, following a "thorough investigation" into allegations of bribery in the paintshop, the three had been dismissed. "The investigation has shown that this was an isolated incident," said a Rover spokeswoman.

Rover has been seeking volunteers to trim the Longbridge workforce by up to 1,000 following the sale of the firm by German car firm BMW.

Highbury profit turns new page

British magazine publisher Highbury House Communications reported a sharp increase in first-half profits and said it expected further progress in the second half of the year.

The group said advertising sales continue to be buoyant and it expects a good performance from Nexus Media Communications, the company which was acquired in March for £39.3m. The group reported a 149% jump in pre-tax profits before reorganisation costs. The share price closed at 71.5p, up 3.75p.

Net firm gives Gunn a break

Former British & Commonwealth director John Gunn's resurrection in the City yesterday moved a significant step forward.

Mr Gunn will join the board of internet firm eVestment, following a £39m reverse takeover of Christows Group, a stockbroking firm of which he is a director. The enlarged group, which will be known as Christows, intends to become an online bank. Mr Gunn successfully defended an attempt by the DTI to bar him from being a director, following the collapse of leasing group British & Commonwealth in the late 1980s.

Tesco ignites Irish price war

Tesco triggered a price war in Ireland yesterday as it slashed grocery prices at its 75 Irish stores.

It cut prices on 52 lines of food, drink, and household goods by up to 37% in a move aimed at countering Ireland's soaring inflation rate.

Rival Irish chain, privately owned Dunnes Stores, joined the fray by matching Tesco's prices on staples such as milk, butter and bread and tripling the loyalty card points available on groceries for the rest of the week.

Maurice Pratt, managing director of Tesco Ireland, denied that Tesco had been forced to act following the recent arrival of German discounters, Aldi and Lidl.

fields.headline: Audrey Wise
fields.standfirst:
She was a feminist Labour MP whose work reformed maternity services and whose creative insights illuminated socialism
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The Labour MP Audrey Wise, who has died of a brain tumour aged 65, was a socialist, a feminist and a fighter.
fields.body:
The Labour MP Audrey Wise, who has died of a brain tumour aged 65, was a socialist, a feminist and a fighter.

She fought against whatever she felt was wrong and she thought that a great deal about the organisation of society was very wrong. She fought authority in general, oppression in capitalistic society in particular, and took on on all-comers.

Born in Newcastle, the daughter of a former Labour councillor, she lived and breathed politics every moment of her life. She grew up with a profound belief in the need to recognise the proper role of women in society. Proudly, she described herself as a "shorthand typist", and continued to use that description as an MP - partly in the apparent belief that it might encourage other shorthand typists that anything was possible and partly to demonstrate her support for all women workers.

At the age of 21, she became a Tottenham borough councillor in north London. In February 1974, she became Labour MP for Coventry South West, and soon attacked the authoritarian enemy on all fronts. She had already made a name as an opponent of the Vietnam war, and other foreign political causes she took up included Chile and Nicaragua.

At Westminster in the 1970s she was regarded as something of a left-wing nuisance , a state of affairs that she viewed as necessary and desirable. She was part of a delegation to meet a representative of the Official IRA, she often voted against the then Labour government's economic policies, and was arrested on the Grunwick picket line, in that struggle to establish trade union recognition.

Most significantly, with Jeff Rooker she co-authored the Rooker-Wise Amendment to Chancellor Denis Healey's 1977 finance bill. This introduced retrospective inflation-proofing on tax allowances, which led to £450m being handed back to taxpayers. It was an astonishing victory for two back-benchers and a testament to the power of a committed, hard-working, single-minded woman.

Her most important work was that for which Wise received the least recognition among her political peers. It was on the behalf of women, children and families and, most specifically, about the way in which women experience childbirth. She lost her Coventry seat in the 1979 general election and was out of parliament until 1987.

Once back, for Preston, she was made a member of the health select committee and persuaded her fellow members to hold an inquiry into maternity services. This led to a landmark 1992 report, which prompted the Conservative government to endorse the committee's findings and led to policies which offered women more choice and control of their circumstances during pregnancy, birth and post-natal care.

The National Childbirth Trust's head of policy research, Mary Newburn, said that it was the impact of Wise's approach that had changed maternity services to become "woman-centred" and which has since led to a change throughout the NHS: the lives of women everywhere have been touched by her campaigning.

From 1982 to 1987, Wise was a trouble-making Labour national executive committee member and a forceful figure in a number of the party's campaigning organisations. She was a member of the shopworkers' union, Usdaw - which was once her father's union - and was quietly proud of becoming its first woman president, from 1991 until 1997.

Fiercely protective of her close, fond family life, she married her husband, John, a dispensing optician in 1953.

When she found out about her illness last April, she was optimistic about the outcome and applied as much vigour to resisting it as she had all her life to her many political causes. As her family said yesterday: "This was one fight she did not win." Audrey Wise would have appreciated the irony.

Hilary Wainwright writes:

Audrey Wise's manner was that of a campaigner, an indefatigable activist, but many radical socialists, especially socialist feminists, will also remember her as a thinker of real insight. She listened.

In her early 1970s pamphlet, Women and Workers' Control, she describes how women who say they don't want equal pay are dismissed as "backward". Equal pay was being proposed on the basis that women should accept the same conditions as men; for example, working nights. She recalls such a "backward" woman saying to her: "If the economy wants women to work nights then I need a different kind of economy."

"We should encourage attitudes like that," said Audrey, who believed equal pay was important, but not enough.

Her life combined the per sonal with the political in an exemplary way. The creative humanism of her socialism was apparent in everything she wrote. For example, take her 1970s article, Trying to Stay Human, in the socialist feminist magazine Red Rag. If nurseries were really to meet the needs of women and children, she insisted, it was not enough to demand them from the state: the state should provide resources, but the management should be under community control. She had no faith in the existing state, but a profound belief in democracy and the capacities of ordinary people. A radical extension of democracy was a constant theme of her life.

I came to know her as one of the moving spirits behind the Institute for Workers' Control and because of her support for workers such as those at Lucas Aerospace who developed plans for saving jobs by turning arms factories over to the production of medical, environmental, transport and other socially necessary goods. But I was influenced by her through the bridging role she played between the women's liberation movement and the trade unions. Sheila Rowbotham invited her to speak at the first women's liberation conference at Ruskin College in 1970, and she stayed connected. The last time I heard her speak was at a meeting where she stressed the need for the left to take seriously the preservation of biological diversity.

She was one of the many people dismissed as "old Labour" who were always thinking creatively about the future. If modernisation meant all power to the corporations, she needed a very different kind of future. And she contributed much to achieving that future.

She is survived by her husband, son and daughter.
 Audrey Wise, politician, born January 4 1935; died September 2 2000

She recalls such a "backward" woman saying to her: "If the economy wants women to work nights then I need a different kind of economy." "We should encourage attitudes like that," said Audrey, who believed equal pay was important, but not enough. Her life combined the per sonal with the political in an exemplary way. The creative humanism of her socialism was apparent in everything she wrote. For example, take her 1970s article, Trying to Stay Human, in the socialist feminist magazine Red Rag. If nurseries were really to meet the needs of women and children, she insisted, it was not enough to demand them from the state: the state should provide resources, but the management should be under community control. She had no faith in the existing state, but a profound belief in democracy and the capacities of ordinary people. A radical extension of democracy was a constant theme of her life. I came to know her as one of the moving spirits behind the Institute for Workers' Control and because of her support for workers such as those at Lucas Aerospace who developed plans for saving jobs by turning arms factories over to the production of medical, environmental, transport and other socially necessary goods. But I was influenced by her through the bridging role she played between the women's liberation movement and the trade unions. Sheila Rowbotham invited her to speak at the first women's liberation conference at Ruskin College in 1970, and she stayed connected. The last time I heard her speak was at a meeting where she stressed the need for the left to take seriously the preservation of biological diversity. She was one of the many people dismissed as "old Labour" who were always thinking creatively about the future. If modernisation meant all power to the corporations, she needed a very different kind of future. And she contributed much to achieving that future. She is survived by her husband, son and daughter.  Audrey Wise, politician, born January 4 1935; died September 2 2000

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Serial Mom | Pleasantville | Mo' Better Blues | For A Few Dollars More
fields.body:
Serial Mom

(John Waters, 1994)
10pm, FilmFour

Kathleen Turner is a model American mum, cooking for husband Sam Waterston and their teenage sons. Then she starts murdering people. And this being the world of John "Pecker" Waters, she's punishing serious wrongs, such as failing to rewind video tapes. Her arrest and trial, and the attendant media frenzy, say a lot about America's fascination with violence. Turner is magnificent.

Pleasantville

(Gary Ross, 1998)
10pm, Sky Premier

Nineties siblings Jennifer (Reese Witherspoon) and David (Tobey Maguire) are whisked back through the television set to a 50s sitcom. There, life is happy, easy, but also monochrome and dull. It's a witty and affectionate satire of small-town family life, and essays a brilliant cinematic trick, the modern teenagers gradually infecting the black-and-white TV world with dreaded colour.

Mo' Better Blues

(Spike Lee, 1990)
10pm, Sky Cinema

Lee's jazz movie isn't in the Bird class, let alone Round Midnight. Having the admirable Denzel Washington as obsessive trumpet blower Bleek Gilliam is a big plus, except that the part's badly written and doesn't ring true. There are sparky support acts - Spike's sister Joie Lee and Cynda Williams as the women in the musician's life, Wesley Snipes as sax-playing Shadow Henderson, and Spike himself as a band manager - but with its top-10 jazz hits soundtrack, it's a shallow piece that misses the elusive blue note.

For A Few Dollars More

(Sergio Leone, 1964)
11.40pm, FilmFour

Leone's superior sequel to A Fistful Of Dollars, teaming Clint Eastwood's vagabond gunslinger, the Man With no Name (pictured), with Lee Van Cleef's dapper-in-black Colonel Mortimer. The bounty hunters form an uneasy alliance in their search for the psychopathic Indio (Gian Mario Volonte, the villain of the earlier film). Again, Leone turns horse opera into grand, if dusty, opera; there's another wonderful Morricone score and a loaded finale - the duellists waiting for the music box tune to stop.

webTitle: 10,000 jobs in P&O plan for new port

fields.headline: 10,000 jobs in P&O plan for new port
fields.trailText: P&O expects 10,000 jobs to be created through a £1bn plan to develop the biggest container port in Britain at a former Shell refinery site on the banks of the Thames.
fields.body:
P&O expects 10,000 jobs to be created through a £1bn plan to develop the biggest container port in Britain at a former Shell refinery site on the banks of the Thames.

The shipping company's scheme is likely to trigger a bruising battle of the dockyards with existing facilities, such as Felixstowe and Thamesport, but P&O insists container traffic is growing so quickly there is a need for additional capacity.

The first phase of operations will be ready in 2002 if planning consents are obtained for the 1,500-acre site of the old Shell Haven refinery at Thurrock in Essex, which ceased production nine months ago.

When complete the port will be capable of handling up to 3.5m twenty foot-equivalent (TEU) containers with 3,000m of quayside providing berths for up to 10 ships.

The port facilities will cost around £500m and employ 3,000 staff. A further £500m and 7,000 jobs are expected to be created through the development of transport infrastructure and light industry around the facility.

Lord Sterling, the P&O chairman, said that at current growth rates the existing container ports will have reached capacity in the next three to five years.

"For the country to continue to benefit from its position at the heart of world trade, we need a significant increase in container terminal facilities and Shell Haven has this potential," he said.

Under an agreement with Shell, P&O will buy the land it needs for the container port and will jointly develop the rest of the site with the oil company, which is already decommissioning and decontaminating the area for future use.

P&O, whose shares last night closed down 3p at 590p, part owns or operates facilities further up the Thames at Tilbury, where a new terminal is being created, and at Southampton, where its partner, Associated British Ports, has been trying to expand.

Chris Gray, chief executive of Hutchison Ports UK, said he was convinced container traffic in Britain was growing fast. But he pointed out that Felixstowe was planning to bring a further 500,000 TEU worth of capacity on stream and still had spare capacity at Thamesport, also controlled by his Hong Kong-owned group.

Thamesport had many acres of spare land which could be used for further development, according to Mr Gray. He declined to comment on the P&O plans directly, but said: "There is sufficient capacity to meet our (the UK's) needs for the forseeable future."

Industry experts said environmental opposition often made it difficult for existing docks to increase in size. ABP's hopes for Dibden Bay, opposite Southampton, are being threatened by planning consent difficulties.

P&O operates ports around the globe and is keen to expand this business, which will become more important to the bottom line after its cruise and bulk shipping arms are hived off.

 Motorola, the American electronics group, is to create 550 jobs in Scotland by 2005 through a scheme for a semiconductor research and development centre in the heart of Silicon Glen.

Politicians said the high-tech plant, needing top level engineering graduates, would help halt the "brain drain" to North America.

fields.headline: Was it meant to be like this?
fields.standfirst:
Tomorrow, Scotland's parliament reopens for business. But don't expect any triumphalism. For weeks the headlines have delivered depressing news of economic woe, spiralling waiting lists and exam chaos. So, one year after breaking with Westminster, Jim White asks, is Scotland capable of looking after itself?
Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: Tomorrow, Scotland's parliament reopens for business. But don't expect any triumphalism. For weeks the headlines have delivered depressing news of economic woe, spiralling waiting lists and exam chaos. So, one year after breaking with Westminster,  Jim White  asks, is Scotland capable of looking after itself?
fields.body:
At least the members of the Scottish parliament got the important legislation out of the way early. Last year, on the historic first day of sitting, the newly elected members of the newly devolved institution agreed on the following: that they should all receive a bronze commemorative medal to mark their role in history. Exhausted by the legislative process, they then took a two-month holiday. Though not before deciding it would be a fine idea to commission a £200m building in which to conduct their future activities.

Tomorrow, when they start their second year in business, the members of the Scottish parliament will have a somewhat more rigorous agenda. Over the summer, the political news has made alarming reading for them. Take these headlines from the Daily Record, Scotland's biggest-selling daily paper, last Wednesday: "Beleaguered ministers careers take turn for the worse; exam chaos spreads; waiting lists soar; union chiefs threaten autumn of discontent".

Meanwhile, Alex Salmond, the leader of the SNP, the official opposition party, has been spending the summer telling everyone who will listen that, technically, the Scottish economy is about to enter recession: receipts are below expenditure, imports above exports, with economic growth too low to mop up the difference. As birthday messages to mark the second year of devolved government go, the Scottish parliament could hardly have chosen a less complimentary one: much of the superficial evidence suggests this is a country which cannot rule itself.

In truth, walking round the streets last week, Scotland does not look on the verge of economic collapse. Edinburgh in particular, with its endless new bars and restaurants and a housing market approaching London levels of ludicrousness, looks in rude economic health. In Glasgow, too, the buoyant central business district is full of busy corporations such as Scottish Power, Scottish Widows and Scottish Gas, whose nomenclature identifies them firmly with the sort of self-confident nationalism which would be reckoned business suicide south of the border. And, since everyone living outside the central belt is always quick to point out that Glas gow and Edinburgh are not the real Scotland, it seems advisable to report that business-wise things are pretty cheery elsewhere too.

"Shell has just announced a big increase in investment up here," says Amanda Harvie, of the Aberdeen Chamber of Commerce. "Without wishing to suggest we are approaching boom times, I'd say there was overall an upturn in confidence at the sharp end. That is not to pretend there are not real challenges ahead."

As its defenders would point out, it is the challenges that the Scottish parliament has been set up to address. Success can get on by its own, it is failure that needs sorting out by government. And - impending recession or not - Scotland has enormous challenges beyond an apparent inability to mark examination papers properly. Bad health, bad housing, bad diet and drug abuse are endemic. It is a nation, too, identified by division: north/south; east/west; Lowland/Highland; rural/urban. Many of the divisions are even enshrined constitutionally: this is a country which still legislates to ensure Catholics and Protestants are educated separately.

And it doesn't seem as if its globally expansive corporations are keen to help. As Stagecoach, Scottish Media and Scottish Power colonise the corporate world with a voracity to match their empire building forebears, they seem to have all but forgotten the local community from which they draw their wealth and expertise. In the past, Scottish business success was characterised by huge public projects (Andrew Carnegie was the typical Scottish philanthropist). Now success is marked by the size of directors' remuneration. Tellingly, the lottery-funded Museum of Scotland which has just opened to great acclaim in Edinburgh, is the only grand cultural building to be built in this grandest cultural city in the last century. Unless you count Murrayfield.

Still, in case it may have forgotten the many challenges it faces, the Scottish parliament can always rely on its media to remind it. In an over-crowded newspaper market, Scottish papers seem to have decided that bad news sells. For his own political reasons, Andrew Neil has ensured his Scotsman keeps its teeth never far from the jugular. Even the traditionally Labour-supporting Daily Record has administered almost daily assaults on Donald Dewar and his team since the moment they took office. The failures of the examination system or fears of impending recession are given far greater prominence than the revelation that 29 new schools are being built in Glasgow alone. And always - with every piece of bad news - the new parliament is held accountable.

"There is a real schizophrenia in this country," says Frank McAveety MSP, the deputy minister for local government. "The Scottish press corps lobbied harder than anyone for a devolved parliament, now they've got it, they're queuing up to give it a good kicking."

For many observers of the Scottish scene - Billy Connolly for instance - there is nothing new in this symptom of a split national personality. In the new Gallery of Modern Art in Glasgow's Exchange Square, it is there for all to see. Housed in a glorious legacy from the city's mercantile past, the gallery is full, not of the art of a self-confident, newly semi-independent country, but of gloom and pessimism. Albeit producing fascinating, visually arresting work, young Scottish artists seem obsessed with national shortcomings, failure and self-loathing. In their view everything appears to be wrong with Scotland, from its housing to its way with sex. The misanthropic whole is summed up by Ron O'Donnell's brilliant painting featuring a man bedecked in tartan, sitting in a room decorated with the memorabilia of plastic patriotism. He is slumped in an armchair, can in hand, watching the big match on television. Instead of a head he has a football. The painting is called The Scotsman.

"I think that painting's got it right: football really is an important metaphor for Scottish life, not least because we are so obsessed with it," says Sandy Ross, managing director of Scottish Television. "For instance, you can't ignore the effect the 1978 World Cup had on the collective psyche. We went there saying we could beat the world and we were humiliated as only we Scots can be. I reckon Andrew Marr was right when he said this sense of 'we're crap and we know we are' which resulted from that campaign completely destroyed any chance of devolution the last time it was on the cards in 1979. We simply thought we weren't up to it."

And if it isn't football, it's Thatcher. The 80s were a bleak time for Scotland, battered by recession, steam-rollered by brutalist economic theories, then spat on as the laboratory of the poll tax. For many in Scotland, it was easy to point the finger for failings. Though to be fair, it is not just paranoia: the English really do appear to have little concern for what goes on over the garden wall.

"Since I came to Scotland 10 years ago," says Gavin Stamp, senior lecturer at the McIntosh School of Architecture in Glasgow, "I've become much more aware of English indifference to Scotland. I have friends who proudly tell me they have never visited Scotland in a way they would be ashamed to admit if they had never been to Paris."

However justified, loathing of English control over a land for which there was minimal interest became endemic; the manner in which the Scottish Office doled out the money in an unaccountable fashion from Westminster was identified as the root cause of every evil visited on the country.

"The country became irresponsible, plagued by a moaning, defeatist culture," says Andrew Jaspan, editor of the Herald on Sunday newspaper. "Every problem was blamed on London."

Blame: an important word in the Scottish vocabulary.

"Oh yes, we're always looking for someone to blame," says Sandy Ross. "The New Labour honeymoon was far shorter up here. We were already suspicious that Blair would desert us long before he was even elected."

For the Scottish politicians who arrived after devolution in 1999, getting to grips with blame is part of the new job description.

"The Thatcher years distorted politics in Scotland," says Frank McAveety. "It made it easy. We could all agree we hated her and she was to blame for everything. Now that's all over, there is a much more difficult job: deciding what we stand for and whether we can do it."

Not that there is a general faith abroad that the parliament is the body to sort much out at all. It is hard to find anyone - unless they are employed by Holyrood - who has a kind word to say about the new Scottish political institutions. If there is any feeling at all for the parliament on the streets, it is the one neatly summarised by Billy Connolly who calls it a "wee pretendy parliament". Yet for some observers, the very fact Scotland at last has a parliament to sneer at is a major step forward.

"We may have a mess now with all this summer's cock-ups," says Andrew Jaspan, "but at least it's Scotland's mess. For years it's been easy to say it's someone else's fault. Now people have to face up to it. And I think that's brilliant."

Jaspan points to the debate about Section 28 as a perfect example of what he calls a "growing-up process" instigated by the arrival of the parliament. The debate was an ugly, divisive one. The bus billionaire Brian Souter bankrolled a campaign against its abolition which quickly ran out of control. Posters suggested that if Section 28 was removed from the statute books, buggery would become part of the syllabus. With the willing endorsement of the Catholic church and parts of the Church of Scotland, the anti-abolitionists whipped up a virulently homophobic fervour.

"A lot of people said that the debate over Section 28 was a disaster," says Jaspan, "but I reckon it was probably the best debate Scotland's had for years. It challenged a lot of people who assumed we were a tolerant, liberal society to really look at themselves and defend the issues."

Gordon Macdougall, the political editor of Scottish Television, agrees.

"A lot of my English friends told me that the Section 28 business showed what a backward, ugly nation we really were," he says. "But at the end of it, Section 28 has been abolished up here and it is still on the statute books down south."

For all its symbolic importance, however, Section 28 was still, in essence, an intellectual issue. When it comes to the nitty-gritty of finance, health, housing and education, the parliament does not yet appear to have proved that it can run things better than Westminster.

"A year is too soon to tell," says Frank McAveety. "But I believe we are putting in place legislation which, in the long run, will change Scotland for the better. I think people had such high hopes of immediate change, there is inevitably a sense of anti-climax, but legislation takes time. I'm relaxed about the slagging off. It is a legitimate job of the press to examine. And you could say it's that good for the first time they really have something to examine."

It would help, some observers feel, if the parliament could get its own PR right. Not just stopping blunders such as its self-important first day in office, but being much more active in explaining to voters just what it is up to. But in the meantime, for the first time in Scotland's parliamentary history, the boys and girls returning to Holyrood for the new term tomorrow have to face up to this issue: a summer of relentless bad news has got to be resolved not at 400 miles distance, but by them, on their fellow citizens' doorstep.

"It is the big question: can the Scots govern themselves? and we shall have to wait for the answer," says Gavin Stamp. "Mind you, population of less than five million, edge of Europe, crap climate: the Norwegians seem to manage it."
