Gordon Macdougall, the political editor of Scottish Television, agrees. "A lot of my English friends told me that the Section 28 business showed what a backward, ugly nation we really were," he says. "But at the end of it, Section 28 has been abolished up here and it is still on the statute books down south." For all its symbolic importance, however, Section 28 was still, in essence, an intellectual issue. When it comes to the nitty-gritty of finance, health, housing and education, the parliament does not yet appear to have proved that it can run things better than Westminster. "A year is too soon to tell," says Frank McAveety. "But I believe we are putting in place legislation which, in the long run, will change Scotland for the better. I think people had such high hopes of immediate change, there is inevitably a sense of anti-climax, but legislation takes time. I'm relaxed about the slagging off. It is a legitimate job of the press to examine. And you could say it's that good for the first time they really have something to examine." It would help, some observers feel, if the parliament could get its own PR right. Not just stopping blunders such as its self-important first day in office, but being much more active in explaining to voters just what it is up to. But in the meantime, for the first time in Scotland's parliamentary history, the boys and girls returning to Holyrood for the new term tomorrow have to face up to this issue: a summer of relentless bad news has got to be resolved not at 400 miles distance, but by them, on their fellow citizens' doorstep. "It is the big question: can the Scots govern themselves? and we shall have to wait for the answer," says Gavin Stamp. "Mind you, population of less than five million, edge of Europe, crap climate: the Norwegians seem to manage it."

fields.headline: Pills, thrills and bellyaches
fields.trailText: Reputations | Waking The Dead
fields.body:
It would be reassuring to think that the President of the United States knew his ass from a hole in the ground, but according to Reputations (BBC 2), Richard Nixon, at the height of his power, was often dazed with prescription drugs and alcohol. I had not, until this moment, considered urine-testing politicians, but now you mention it...

The Secret Life Of Richard Nixon is in two parts. There are evidently more skeletons in the cupboard. Recently I opened a cupboard in a junk shop and there, sure enough, was a skeleton, swinging. This may have been a witticism on the part of the proprietor or it may have been the proprietor but, either way, it seemed a woeful conclusion to a hopeful life. Not unlike Richard Nixon's.

Dilantin is approved in the US for the treatment of epilepsy. Jack Dreyfus, described as a Wall Street tycoon, considered it a wonder drug and gave it to Nixon in 1,000-tablet bottles. Taken with other medication and alcohol, it can cause delirium, psychosis, slurred speech and mental confusion, as students picketing the White House noticed when Nixon drove out in the middle of the night to talk to them. They couldn't follow what he was saying. He then went to the deserted Senate, put his valet in the speaker's chair and applauded him. He lacked the season of all natures, sleep.

This disorientation was less catastrophic than you might expect, as his staff simply ignored his wilder orders. The Secretary of Defence, told to bomb Jordan, reported conveniently that the weather was too bad. Kissinger, told to bomb Damascus, decided that he would feel differently in the morning. The orange sky of evening now flooding the Oval Office looked like the open door of a crematorium.

The rather pitiful aspect of Nixon's case was that he had adopted a profession for which he was psychologically unsuited. He was painfully shy. As his speechwriter observed, "He could blush, and this is a remarkable quality in a mature politician." (Hands up all those who have seen a politician blush.) Kissinger noted he was more at ease with a crowd than an individual. "When you have a large crowd, you don't have to develop a direct relationship with anyone personally. He was not gregarious. For a politician, it's an unusual trait and he had to become a politician by enormous self-discipline and acting against his nature, which was reclusive." Casting about for a comparable British prime minister, you think of Edward Heath.

That self-discipline was iron. Rejected for the college football team, he persisted and got in. Rejected by the voters, he insisted and won. It is written in the American Constitution or, maybe, Bugsy Malone that you can be anything you want to be. You should, however, be careful what you want to be.

It was politically safer to take drugs for depression and stress than to see a psycho-therapist. As Dr Hutschnecker, whom he consulted, said, "It was safer for a politician to be going to a whore than to be involved with a psychiatrist." Which we know to be true. Hutschnecker's experience with Nixon led him to argue in the New York Times that before election, leaders should be given a clean bill of psychiatric health.

You do not, as a rule remember anything a politician says for a quarter of a century, but I remember Nixon's farewell speech to the White House staff well. As the UP White House correspondent said, it came from the soul, the gut, the heart. Sweat glistened on his upper lip and tears on his lower eyelid. He said, "My mother was a saint." And yet, it seems, he used to hit his wife, the slight and unobtrusive Pat.

Waking The Dead (BBC 1) is a potentially ingenious idea. Cold case cops pick up abandoned murder enquiries and, with the benefit of improved science or hindsight, solve them. Trevor Eve has recruited three women and one black man, which is taking political correctness to extremes. They are all excessively rude to each other. I feel there would be less temptation to shout if they didn't work in a warehouse. Poor Sue Johnston, the personality profiler, is given some intractable lumps of gristly dialogue to chew. Holly Aird, the forensic pathologist, has the air of a fairly furious cat, and no wonder.

If I may offer a suggestion? Have you tried looking for the murderer in the cast list? He is often there.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Please Tell Me Why It's Funny | Little Red Label
fields.body:
With a simultaneous series on how Hollywood traduces psychiatrists, did no one warn Dr Raj Persaud not to reinforce the film makers' prejudices? He should have realised he would trip on the first banana skin in trying to psychoanalyse humour, which is naturally what happens in Please Tell Me Why It's Funny (11.30am, Radio 4). Inviting a cognitive neurologist to explain why we can't tickle ourselves or, even worse, asking Norman Wisdom (pictured) if humour increases longevity smacks of desperation. So does inane giggling.

The history of Topic Records is one of those wholly unlikely success stories. Offering an unrelieved diet of British folk music it has now been in business for more than 60 years. It started in 1939 as an offshoot of the Workers' Musical Association, firmly dedicated to the revolutionary ideals of the period. Now, as Richard Coles discovers in Little Red Label (1.30pm, Radio 4), it is the oldest independent record company in the world.

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town and why
fields.body:
Man on the Moon...

You might assume that after skipping gaily through lunar craters and the Sea of Tranquility, the dusty corridors of London's Imperial College would seem strangely parochial. Dull even. Still, odd though the juxtaposition may be, that's exactly where you'll find erstwhile rock-hopping astronaut Buzz Aldrin this week, as he pitches up in the UK to appear at the Annual Festival of Science, being opened by Princess Anne at Imperial tomorrow afternoon. Appearing at the festival alongside the slightly less exotic likes of Tom Baker, Richard Dawkins and Beryl Bainbridge, Aldrin - forever known as the guy a couple of steps behind the guy taking a giant leap for mankind - will then be In Conversation at the Royal Geographic Society on Thursday evening, before jetting back to his presidency of (no lie) Starcraft Enterprises, Laguna Beach, shortly afterwards.

Happy days are here again...

Oh, and if should you notice a black cloud of eternal grumpiness hanging over you at any point in the near future, that'll be venerable art-rock icon Lou Reed. Having already played shows in Birmingham and Bristol in support of his comically titled new album Ecstasy, the ever-jovial Reed is in London this very moment, preparing to play the Shepherd's Bush Empire tonight. After disappearing - no doubt in a puff of transcendental joy - for another week, he then returns to these shores to play Portsmouth a week Thursday. All of which, coincidentally, means he may well run into the collective genius of unhinged pop maestros Ween as he wanders through customs, what with Gene, Mean and Dean arriving to play the Astoria on Thursday, where they will no doubt be airing selections from their latest opus, White Pepper.

fields.headline: Rainbow warrior
fields.standfirst: White galleries, white lofts, white studios, white walls - why is high culture so scared of colour?  Jonathan Jones  meets an artist determined to bring vibrancy in from the cold
fields.trailText: White galleries, white lofts, white studios, white walls - why is high culture so scared of colour? Jonathan Jones meets an artist determined to bring vibrancy in from the cold.
fields.body:
In late summer, in a long shed of a studio whose skylight lets in a slice of fresh sky, David Batchelor is enthusing about traffic lights. The green light isn't green, he says, it's more blueish. He's fiddling in a forest of cables tangled around the base of some steel shelves. On them stand metal boxes of the kind that contain "exit" signs in the cinema. These are abandoned commercial lightboxes that he has scavenged from skips and derelict shops. In each he has mounted a fluorescent light, and across the front he has fixed coloured panes of plastic. He switches it on and a seductive polychromatic light illuminates the chaotic space. Suddenly we are in a dream version of Piccadilly Circus or Times Square - a fantasia of modern urban colour. Electrified colours dance off each other; magenta, lime, amber.

Batchelor's Electric Colour Tower is a romantic monument to the modern city. Towers are the nuttiest architectural genre. From the Tower of Babel to the Watts Towers, which the untrained artist Simon Rodia built out of bits of wire and glass in South Central Los Angeles between 1921 and 1954, towers have been associated with folly, with hubris, and with the delight of building for its own sake. Batchelor's Electric Colour Tower immediately makes you think of such unnecessary architecture. It is gratuitous; who needs it?

Electric Colour Tower looks like a rough design for a skyscraper in a brightly lit Blade Runner city. Erected to the height of three floors at Sadler's Wells, London, as part of the theatre's programme of public art commissions, this is a rare thing: a contemporary art work that tries to give unalloyed pleasure. Batchelor believes conceptual art, the tradition in which he was trained, has become a repressive, joyless bar to visual delight. Electric Colour Tower is, he says, his "revenge" on conceptualism.

If so, it is a revenge from within rather than from without, more a case of the system being mutated than destroyed. David Batchelor's art negotiates sensual pleasure and conceptualist irony, perhaps too knowingly at times in his previous work. It quotes several modern traditions. In the first place there's monochrome painting, the painting of 60s artists such as Robert Ryman, Yves Klein and their imitators. Batchelor originally trained as a painter and, as you contemplate these sheets of glowing colour, it strikes you that he has found a way to paint by other means. All around his studio are sketches of coloured geometric shapes, fragments of coloured plastic and photographs of what he identifies as ready-made monochromes - painted white boards that he spots on his rambles around London back streets, faded signs that have turned into modernist paintings. He takes pictures of them and exhibits them as examples of the accidental art we see every day.

This quoting of traditions might seem a bit precious. Although Batchelor sees himself as subverting the high tradition of modern art, there is definitely some name-checking going on. He made a big impact a couple of years ago in an exhibition called Here and Now at London's Lisson Gallery, in which he exhibited a series of flat, low trolleys used for moving heavy objects he found discarded around King's Cross station. In the metal beds of these trolleys he put pools of gorgeous colour - blue, pink and yellow. They can be seen as horizontal, monochrome paintings on ready-made supports, dialogues between the world of art and the city streets. Students loved them and Batchelor is a cult figure for a young London art scene in which uninhibited visual pleasure has made a comeback.

Batchelor's explorations of colour in his art have gone along with his own art-historical research. He has just written a book, Chromophobia, about what he sees as the deadly hostility to colour in the modern western world. His sumptuous celebration of sensory experience in the Electric Colour Tower is in fact conceived as an answer to this anti-sensual, anti-pleasure tradition that he claims to identify.

Chromophobia, or fear of colour, runs through 20th-century high culture, he says, from Le Corbusier calling for all surfaces to be painted white in his 1925 manifesto The Decorative Art of Today, to the empty white spaces of modern loft interiors. Contemporary art is too often a snobbish accessory of the perfect white interior, a prissy conceptualist gesture in colourless space. Outside the white cube gallery, the city is all synthetic colour and artifice, all impurity. But inside the gallery, art is not taken quite seriously unless its colours are muted and its exuberance contained. This goes well beyond art, argues Batchelor. He cites the way calling someone in public life "colourful" - he quotes obituaries for Alan Clark - is to imply a tragic flakiness. Batchelor gets really angry about the western world's history of chromophobia. It is, he argues, related to homophobia, not to mention other fears - of the east, of cosmetics, of femininity.

But there is also a history of delirious uninhibited colour in European art, from the rich purples and greens of frescoes in Pompeii to the painted wooden sculpture in late medieval churches to Matisse's odalisques and Lucio Fontana's luxury monochromes. The question is: how does Batchelor's theory shape his own art?

It is unusual to find a contemporary artist whose art is openly engaged with art-historical ideas. But Batchelor's work is a delicious demonstration that thinking things through is healthy.

One idea that runs from his monochrome trolleys to his latest work is that people don't understand the minimalist art of the 60s; far from being a pristine art for white cube galleries - the realisation of Le Corbusier's purist dream - the art of minimalists such as Donald Judd and Dan Flavin was an attempt to vindicate everyday materials and participate in the energy of the modern city. It was closely related to its contemporary New York movement, pop art. And the minimalists revelled in colour: Judd, as you can see in his works in Tate Modern, juxtaposes blue Perspex and steel, red enamel and copper, with a stylishly restrained hedonism.

You can see this idea echoing through Batchelor's art and determining the discreetly flamboyant form of his Electric Colour Tower. In structure, this is a minimalist stack. The lightboxes are piled neatly one over the other in a potentially endless escalation. But they are all different sizes, and the wires show, and the materials are obviously battered and second-hand. Unlike the cool minimalism that, so the myth goes, can only function in a white space gallery, the Electric Colour Tower bears the signs of its origin in the city streets, in the piles of junk where Batchelor finds his materials. The light of this art is heavenly, it takes you out of yourself, and yet it reminds you constantly that it is no different from the lights you see flickering and flashing all around the city by night, the lights of kebab shops and ambulances.

Electric Colour Tower is a lovely folly, a dive into the city's world of synthetic colour. In the 20th century electricity and the chemical industry combined to make countless new colours available to the human eye: glowing reds, flickering blues, shiny greens. Yet art has been oddly indifferent to all this, incurious about the different bright colours you can savour every night in the city. Batchelor's invitation to chromophilia will have you looking again at traffic lights, at flashy hoardings, at the artificially lit and coloured world of the modern city; in short, seeing new beauty in the world around you. And there is nothing better you can say about art.

 Electric Colour Tower is at Sadler's Wells, London EC1 (020-7863 8000), from Thursday to January 28. Chromophobia is published by Reaktion Books at £12.95.

fields.headline: Keep it surreal
fields.standfirst: Judith Mackrell  on Nederlands Dance Theater's grandiose tribute to an eccentric Italian painter
fields.trailText: Judith Mackrell on Nederlands Dance Theater's grandiose tribute to an eccentric Italian painter.
fields.body:
Guiseppe Arcimboldo, maverick of the late Italian renaissance, was a painter famously addicted to the visual pun, a painter who saw one man's nose as a ripe zucchini, another man's hair as a coiffure of flame. He painted his visions with meticulous excess, detailing every dermatological oddity, every horticultural flourish, with extravagant accuracy. But he was also, less famously, a deviser of fantastical entertainments at the Hapsburg court, which is why his name has been given to the huge dance spectacle with which Jiri Kylian celebrates his retirement after 23 years as artistic director of Nederlands Dans Theater (NDT).

The scale of Arcimboldo 2000, at the Edinburgh Festival Theatre, is certainly grandiose, combining all three NDTcompanies; and it's also contrived as a surreal homage to the eccentricities of its namesake. As soon as we enter the theatre, black-suited "ushers" accost us with gibbering gestures, while a scarlet-frocked woman licks a pianist's skull. Pre-performance tours also take us backstage where dancers from the company pose like Arcimboldesque portraits. In one dark corner an angelic young man holds a stuffed peacock to his loins, while a woman stands in a drift of dead birds, holding a budgie to her mouth like a lace handkerchief.

These possess a kind of shop-window charm but their wit isn't developed once the company take to the stage. Arcimboldo 2000 (actually a rewrite of a show conceived three years ago) is a collage of new and old choreography, glued together with some slackly-realised fun and farce. The first section is presented as a prelude to a feast, with four dancers seated in expectation of a meal, much as we in the audience await the show. This might have developed into a neat conceit (court ballets often took place around feasting) had it not been realised in a manner so grimly suggestive of a senile Marcel Marceau. No sooner has the triumphal opening music got under way than the dancers launch into a caper of restaurant mayhem, waving their cutlery around in perky unison and ending up with their plastic cups clown-wise on their noses.

Humour has never been Kylian's strong point. It's a harsh thing to say about anyone's leaving party, but the aimlessness apparent in Arcimboldo is typical of the recent malaise that's afflicted the company's artistic policies. Kylian has, indisputably, built NDT into a world class company, and his performers are among the finest in Europe. Right now, though, it looks as if he himself needs to concentrate on making dances, and allow his successor at NDT to inject new vigour into the company's direction.

fields.headline: Life after birth
fields.standfirst: Over the past nine months  Kate Clanchy has shared her experience of pregnancy in her column on these pages. In her final instalment she describes the moment her son Michael came into the world and the weeks that followed
fields.trailText: Over the past nine months  Kate Clanchy has shared her experience of pregnancy in her column on these pages. In her final instalment she describes the moment her son Michael came into the world and the weeks that followed.
fields.body:
It's three weeks later. I'm more tired than I knew it was possible to be. The baby has been wrestled into a lunchtime nap, and I'm lying on my bed wondering if I have the energy to go to the National Childbirth Trust reunion. If I do, I'll have to tell my birth story - again.

Not that anything terrible happened. Actually, in the strange, masochistic world of natural childbirth, I may have scored maximum points. I had a water birth, complete with low lighting, sympathetic midwives and supportive husband. In fact, I have the material to be positively triumphalist - I happen to know that of all the women in my group, I was the only one who did not have medical intervention.

Ironically, I was also the only woman who did not go active birth classes (I've never liked gym). I must admit to feeling a bit gleeful about the last detail - but not about the rest. I'm glad I had a water birth, but don't think it indicates any special virtue on my part - I think it is more likely to be the result of genetics and substantial hips. Nor am I surprised that the other women had intervention.

The NCT is a middle class institution, and full of women coming to motherhood after having had established careers. Not only did most of my classmates probably look nice in jeans, but they were mostly over 30, and therefore likely to need help. I know that some of the women there this afternoon will try to apologise for "failing" to have an "active" birth, and that seems absurd. I wish I had a T-shirt that said: "I think modern obstetrics are great."

In fact, now my mind is so full of naps, nappies, crying and feeds, I wonder why we put so much emphasis on the birth in the first place. I understand why the natural birth movement had to happen - the over-medicalised, paternalistic births of the 50s and 60s were repressive and even cruel - but radical reactions are always full of over-statement. When Sheila Kitzinger claimed in 1962 that natural child birth using her "psychosexual" method "has a significance for both man and woman which reaches far beyond the act of birth itself, and through the family has its effect upon society as a whole", did she really expect it to become the orthodoxy?

Because orthodox it certainly is. My classmates will be apologising because they have to some extent accepted Kitzinger's idea that natural childbirth will somehow put everything else, especially breast-feeding, right. "Immediately after the birth, the baby will be passed to you for bonding," says my hospital leaflet. "Once you've achieved successful suckling in the celebratory atmosphere that surrounds birth, you will feel confident about future feeding" asserts Miriam Stoppard, a main-stream authority if ever there was one.

My water birth gave me a strong feeling of having given birth to my son and I value the experience. But it wasn't magic. It did not protect me from heavy bleeding and some very painful suturing.( The local anaesthetic didn't take. "She can't keep her feet still, can she?", the doctor kindly observed.) And it didn't preserve me from having to spend a night on the the maternity wards.

I'd been up for 36 hours when I was wheeled in there, 12 of them in labour. I was not going to be allowed to shut my eyes for the next 24. The lights were on continuously, and the temperature was tropical. There was no drinking water or anything to eat - in my time there I was offered one round of toast and one mini Bakewell tart. The ward was shared with three other women and their babies. There was a single midwife answering calls from this and two similar wards.

The baby next to me had had a painful ventouse delivery and screamed for most of the night. Under the curtain, I watched its mother's feet, clad in padded purple slippers in the shape of monsters, pad to and fro, and heard her start to weep. When my own baby cried, I had to crank the bed up to breast-feed. It made terrible squeaks, and the other babies started crying. At one point, I fell over my catheter bag. My baby wailed. I wailed too.

Of course, a large part of the reason that conditions are so distressing is because of year after year of NHS cuts. I believe the average food budget is £1.40 per patient per day. Midwifes are paid truly paltry sums to do a incredibly demanding job, so naturally there aren't very many of them. But ideology played a part too. Maternity ward nurseries have been abolished not just for economic reasons, but to allow more "bonding" for mother and baby .

"We believe that the best person to take care of your baby is you, and we will not take him/her away for any reason," said the leaflet by my bedside, which also instructed me to wheel the baby to the lavatory with me, in case he was snatched. Half-conscious, in a lot of pain, I didn't feel like the best person - but there was no option, because visiting hours ensured that the people who did want to help - my husband, above all - were kept away. I did not "bond" with my baby during those hours in hospital - I felt alienated, guilty, inadequate and horribly lonely.

Nor did my water birth set me up for breast-feeding. My baby failed to latch on joyously after birth, because, prosaically enough, he had swal lowed a lot of mucus in the birth canal. Not that I knew that. In fact, I was beginning to wonder if I was failing to feed him because of some of the "psychosexual" reasons Kitzinger suggests - "infantile sexuality" is particularly imponderable - when I was saved by a nursing auxiliary who matter-of-factly turned him over and and patted the mucus out of him.

The same nursing auxiliary did something else wonderful too. Like a glorious left-over from an old-fashioned maternity ward, she took the baby away for an hour so I could bath. The relief was immeasurable. Perhaps that makes me an unnatural mother - but I don't think so. Other great apes get over the difficulty of slowly maturing young by only having one baby every five to eight years. Human beings get round the difficulty by sharing parenting - except in modern maternity wards.

Out here in the world, I am just beginning to relax and allow other people - my husband, most of all - to help care for the baby. My hospital stay didn't just make me ill from sleep deprivation, it made me feel that I was the only person who should be taking care of my child, and that all other help, like ringing for the midwife, was a failure on my part and a favour on the helper's.

A good "birth story" certainly didn't save me from any of that. In fact, I think the emphasis on birth and the mother's individual experience isn't just sentimentalised - I think it stops us seeing babies for what they are - a collective enterprise. An old fashioned maternity ward with its nurseries, sleeping hours and matrons, ushered new mothers into a protected, ordered, if oppressive, community of women. The modern ward initiates them into a chaotic twilight where they alone are responsible for their child. If I do go to the NCT meeting, I want to talk about that, not the "quality" of my birth.

Infant by Kate Clanchy

In your frowning, fugitive days, small love,
your coracled, ecstatic nights,
possessed or at peace, hands clenched
on an unseen rope or raised in blessing
like the Pope, as your white etched feet
tread sooty roofs of canal tunnels
or lie released, stretched north in sleep

You seem to me an early saint, a Celt,
eyes fixed on a celestial light, patiently
setting the sextant straight
to follow your godsent map, now
braced against a baffling gale, now
becalmed, fingers barely sculling
through warm muddy tides

Soon, you will make your way out
of this estuary country, leave
the low farms and fog banks, tack through
the brackish channels and long
reed-clogged rivulets, reach
the last turn, the salt air and river mouth,
the wide grey sea of your life.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.trailText: Having failed to appreciate wholly the Hello!/bog off nexus that is the British Spice experience, in the US the term "Spice Girls" is being applied to an entirely different group of women.
fields.body:
Having failed to appreciate wholly the Hello!/bog off nexus that is the British Spice experience, in the US the term "Spice Girls" is being applied to an entirely different group of women. Three influential female reporters covering the Gore presidential campaign for the New York Times, the Washington Post and Associated Press are currently facing a barrage of criticism, derided by colleagues and commentators as nasty, snide, bitter and biased. While their collective track record is impressive, and suggests nothing to support the vitriol, "the bitches on the bus" are continuing to raise hackles. But one New Yorker writer offers a theory: "If Bob Woodward and Jeff Gerth wore high heels, they'd be called bitches too," she says, referring to two of the country's most highly respected investigative reporters.

We tend to cast our public lesbians in two types only: those who frighten schoolgirls with hard stares (remembers Radclyffe Hall first time around) or in a permanent state of lipsticky, strapped-on arousal (the rest) . So it's a joy to note that the nation has taken a gentle, guitar-strumming peacemaker to its collective bosom, in the shape of Anna, beloved of Big Brother. Is fancying Anna the new lesbian chic? Who cares, because what the nation doesn't know is that, on eviction, Anna will be taken to a specially-constructed surveillance tent in Sidelines' garden, where she can re-adjust to civilian life at leisure (current projected acclimatisation period: 10 years). Sidelines is presently expanding its harmonica repertoire in the hope of spending many happy hours under canvas making sweet music with the divine one.

According to one headache specialist, Picasso's paintings of fractured faces may have been inspired by the distorting visual effects of migraine. Sidelines would hereby like it to be known that this column is always brought to you via the distorting psychological prism that is being female.

webTitle: Milosevic rival still missing as poll nominations close

fields.headline: Milosevic rival still missing as poll nominations close
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Nominations have closed for Yugoslavia's presidential elections with still no word on the fate of Ivan Stambolic, a former President of Serbia, who could have been a challenger to President Slobodan Milosevic but disappeared 10 days ago.
fields.body:
Nominations have closed for Yugoslavia's presidential elections with still no word on the fate of Ivan Stambolic, a former President of Serbia, who could have been a challenger to President Slobodan Milosevic but disappeared 10 days ago.

Mr Stambolic - who was apparently abducted after jogging in a wood on the outskirts of Belgrade - had been urged by friends to put his hat in the ring. As a lifelong Titoist with a reputation for honesty, the former Communist leader was thought to have a chance of splitting Mr Milosevic's party and winning over older voters.

He had helped to promote Mr Milosevic in the Communist party until the latter took a nationalist turn in 1987 and organised an internal coup against him. His absence from politics since then has given him an image of being above the intrigues and in-fighting of the opposition parties.

Mr Stambolic repeatedly said he would not run in the presidential election on September 24, but he recently attacked Mr Milosevic in two blistering interviews broadcast in Serbia and Montenegro and may have been reconsidering.

"After Stambolic's disappearance, Serbia has gone deeply into dangerous violence and torture. When darkness begins to swallow people and police keep detaining them only because they are opponents of the regime, we all have reasons to fear," said a statement from the Democratic Alternative, a member of the main alliance of opposition parties.

"Stambolic was removed to prevent him running for Yugoslav president", claimed Vuk Draskovic, the head of the Serbian Renewal Movement, an independent opposition party. Mr Draskovic had urged Mr Stambolic to run. By contrast, the main alliance has been appealing for unity round its candidate, Vojislav Kostunica. Most analysts believe he has a better chance than the missing Mr Stambolic would.

A security guard at a restaurant near the wood where Mr Stambolic was seen resting on a bench after jogging said he saw a white van stop near him. When it moved off, the guard told an independent Belgrade paper, Mr Stambolic had disappeared. Neighbours claimed to have seen a similar vehicle outside his home lately.

State-run Serbian media ignored the story for five days, adding to the suspicions. Then the newspaper Politika criticised independent media and opposition parties for "malicious insinuations in suggesting political motives".

Politika said the police had a witness who saw an armed man step out of a white vehicle parked near where Mr Stambolic was resting, put a pistol to his head and force him into the vehicle. Politika linked the abduction to Mr Stambolic's role in running a bank.

The United Nations grudgingly agreed yesterday that Kosovo residents could vote in the presidential and parliamentary elections, as the region remains recognised as a province of Serbia. Among Kosovo's 2m ethnic Albanians, the Serb community numbers just tens of thousands.

Referring to Yugoslavia as a whole, meanwhile, the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) said the framework for the polls fell short of accepted standards of freedom and fairness.

webTitle: British banks the source of dictator's corrupt £84m

fields.headline: British banks the source of dictator's corrupt £84m
fields.trailText: Britain was the source of $123m (£84m) of Nigerian public assets laundered by Nigeria's former military dictator, General Sani Abacha, through Swiss banks during the 1990s, Switzerland's banking regulator said yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain was the source of $123m (£84m) of Nigerian public assets laundered by Nigeria's former military dictator, General Sani Abacha, through Swiss banks during the 1990s, Switzerland's banking regulator said yesterday.

It had been assumed that funds allegedly embezzled in the world's largest case of political corruption were sent from Nigeria to countries with tight banking secrecy regulations in an effort to conceal their origin before they reached mainstream financial centres like London or New York.

But an investigation by the Federal Banking Commission into the handling of Abacha assets by 19 banks in Switzerland shows that almost one-third of the $660m frozen here came from banks in Britain and the US.

At least $213m was also transferred from Swiss bank accounts to Britain during the 1990s, according to the banking commission's report. Other destinations included Liechtenstein, Luxembourg and the US. Britain is considering a formal request from Nigeria to freeze Abacha accounts.

The commission said six banks had violated money laundering guidelines and due diligence requirements by ignoring the origin of the funds or the "politically exposed" nature of their clients, including three within the Credit Suisse group - Credit Suisse Private Banking, Bank Hofmann and Bank Leu. Others were Union Bancaire Privé, and the Swiss subsidiaries of the French bank, Credit Agricole-Indosuez, and MM Warburg of Germany.

In most cases they dealt directly with Sani Abacha's sons, Ibrahim and Mohammed.

Two board members and a manager have been forced to leave MM Warburg under the regulator's pressure. "We were clearly under the impression that the people at the top there had to leave - at board and management levels," Daniel Zuberbuehler, the banking commission's secretary said. Other dismissals are expected.

The Swiss have also notified French, German and Luxembourg regulatory authorities of the identities of other bankers who have now left Switzerland.

Senior Credit Suisse staff are said to have escaped disciplinary measures mainly because most of the managers that dealt with Abacha funds have left the bank. CS was also able to prove that it had tightened up its internal procedures.

Six other banks have received a reprimand. It had been assumed that funds allegedly embezzled in the world's largest case of political corruption were sent from Nigeria to countries with tight banking secrecy regulations in an effort to conceal their origin before they reached mainstream financial centres like London or New York. But an investigation by the Federal Banking Commission into the handling of Abacha assets by 19 banks in Switzerland shows that almost one-third of the $660m frozen here came from banks in Britain and the US. At least $213m was also transferred from Swiss bank accounts to Britain during the 1990s, according to the banking commission's report. fields.headline: No: 1714
fields.standfirst: Rodrigues
fields.trailText: Rodrigues
fields.body:
Location:
405 miles to the east of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean.

Age:
Known for millennia to Arabs, but discovered by the Portuguese - who soon exterminated the local dodo bird - in 1528.

Nice island, is it?
It's a remote paradise, says the tourist blurb, "of beautiful beaches fringed with palm and casuarina trees, protected by a coral reef forming lagoons of crystal-clear water". The island is also an extinct volcano.

Ah - once powerful, now merely a tourist attraction, albeit one capable of the occasional splutter.
Which brings me neatly to the subject of the royal family. Prince William is spending a month on Rodrigues on an "educational study break" with the Royal Geographic Society.

Studying what?
The effects of ocean currents and the possibilities of setting up marine conservation areas.

That'll come in handy for his history of art degree, will it?
Probably not, but his eco-friendly dad will be pleased. Wills is thought to have got the idea for the jaunt off not-quite-stepmum Camilla, who holidayed in neighbouring Mauritius in April.

Mauritius a bit of a celeb hang-out, is it?
Think Sharon Stone, Sting, Princess Caroline of Monaco.

So what might Wills's, ahem, "study" actually consist of?
He is likely to be invited, as are most visitors, to take part in the island's traditional sega dance, which derives from the age of slavery and recalls Creole courtship rituals.

Has anyone told Britney Spears what she's missing?
The dance has been described as "the body language of slaves leaving pain and sorrow behind at the end of a hard day's work".

Something Prince William can relate to, then?
He paid for that C-grade in biology with sweat and tears, let me tell you.

Speaking of which - how did a recent school-leaver like Wills get the money together for a trip like this?
Perhaps he's been doing a paper round.

Not to be confused with:
Rhodri Morgan, St Andrews, a free holiday at the taxpayers' expense.

fields.headline: Dindo Yogo
fields.standfirst: Congolese composer and plaintive singer
fields.trailText: The dance music of Congo is best known for its mesmerising guitars, but the greatest respect and adulation usually goes to the singers. Dindo Yogo, who has died aged 45, was one those singers who moved people of all ages, social classes and ethnic allegiances with his plaintive, quivering voice, known as the  voix cassé .
fields.body:
The dance music of Congo is best known for its mesmerising guitars, but the greatest respect and adulation usually goes to the singers. Dindo Yogo, who has died aged 45, was one those singers who moved people of all ages, social classes and ethnic allegiances with his plaintive, quivering voice, known as the voix cassé .

Yogo also gained a large international following through the 1980s as lead vocalist with the top Congolese band, Zaiko Langa Langa.

Dindo Yogo was born in Lokutu, Equateur region. He was christened Théophile but later adopted the name Djangi Yogo. He grew up in Kinshasa, the music capital of Africa, during the heady days of independence, and joined his first group, Orchestre Machi, with his life-long friend, the guitarist Huit Kilos, scoring his first hit with Beyuna.

He then formed his own band Etumba Na Ngwaka (referring to the warrior qualities of his people), with whom he recorded the classic song Lola Muana. In 1979, he was invited to join Papa Wemba's Viva la Musica, establishing himself at the top of a highly competitive music scene. When the producer Verckys founded Langa Langa Stars in 1981, Yogo became one of the original "seven patrons". He recorded seven albums with that influential band. Two years later he joined Zaiko Langa Langa, the core group in what was then Zairean music.

Yogo collaborated on some of Zaiko's most emotionally charged works, harmonising with the higher voices of Lengi Lenga and Bimi Ombale and the more strident tones of leader Nyoka Longo.

In 1988, Zaiko split up into two competing bands, Yogo remaining with Nyoka Longo and the late Matima Mpiossa and at odds with his old mate Lengi Lenga, who died last year. An excellent album they had recorded together fell by the wayside as the two groups became instant adversaries.

Yogo was once sitting in a minibus taxi when his old colleague stepped in. They sat opposite each other all the way into town without speaking, something that always saddened Yogo, who was not one to make enemies. As well as a fine, soulful singer, Yogo was a sensitive composer, whose bluesy songs would explode into the most exciting dance music. He had too many compositions in his song book to fit into the repertoire of a 25-piece band, even recording three or four albums a year, so he regularly released solo albums outside his work with Zaiko. This freelancing led to suspension, although he was chef d'orchestre , and he missed out on Zaiko's 1991 UK tour.

In Kinshasa he reformed Etumba na Ngwaka with mixed success, but he was also invited by many artists to sing on their albums, often recorded in Europe. One week after returning to Kinshasa from the US, where he had been preparing for a tour in September, he collapsed with heart problems. He was married twice and is survived by several children.

 Dindo (Théophile) Djangi Yogo, musician, born December 30 1955; died August 23 2000

webTitle: Vivendi adds to Scoot's buying power

fields.headline: Vivendi adds to Scoot's buying power
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Scoot, the internet directory firm, yesterday played down speculation that it is about to be bought by Vivendi but indicated that the French conglomerate was prepared to use its financial firepower to back future acquisitions.
fields.body:
Scoot, the internet directory firm, yesterday played down speculation that it is about to be bought by Vivendi but indicated that the French conglomerate was prepared to use its financial firepower to back future acquisitions.

The carefully worded statement to the stock exchange followed weekend talk of a £1.7bn Vivendi bid and a subsequent 63% surge in Scoot's share price yesterday morning.

The statement said that although talks between the two parties about a variety of ventures "may result in an increase in Vivendi's equity interest in Scoot, there has been no suggestion to date that Vivendi wishes to make an offer for the whole of the issued share capital of Scoot".

At the end of July Vivendi increased its shareholding in Scoot from 11.5% to 22.4% and analysts have speculated the French company will soon take over the Oxfordshire-based firm.

Although yesterday's statement dampened takeover talk, Scoot shares closed up 21% at 152p after it said it was "actively pursuing a wide range of opportunities that can further accelerate the roll-out of Scoot services across Europe". Opportunities include strategic alliances, acquisitions and "other trading arrangements".

Analysts interpreted the statement as Scoot saying that if it wants to take over any rivals it will be able to turn to Vivendi for financial support, rather than having to depend on stock markets which have recently been shaken by the technology stocks sell-off.

Vivendi backed Scoot's £178m acquisition of Loot, the classified advertising group, by subscribing for new shares at up to 250p each.

The apparent strengthening of the Vivendi relationship has prompted speculation that the French group might seek to merge its Comareg local newspaper group with Scoot and take its stake to 29.9%, the maximum allowed before it has to make a full bid.

"Vivendi sees Scoot as a way of leveraging its media assets in France," said Nick Bubb, internet analyst at SG Securities.

Scoot also appears to have a bright future in Vizzavi, the internet portal being developed by Vivendi and Vodafone. Scoot already has agreements with Vodafone.

Robert Bonnier, chief executive of Scoot, has faced criticism from the City following several re-inventions of its business model. However, people close to the company believe he has now cemented a solid relationship with Vivendi, which buys into his ethos of connecting buyers with sellers. Under his stewardship the shares climbed to 374p before the sell-off in technology stocks.

Last week it said that subscriber numbers were rising and it was likely to reach positive cash flow earlier than expected.

However, new versions of its service have not been without technical problems and a fall in revenues has been attributed to that. Operating losses for the first nine months of the year rose 56% to £16.6m as revenues fell 38% to £8.2m.

Mr Bonnier believes Scoot's full potential will only be realised when the next generation of mobile phones are introduced and it makes a series of location-based mobile internet products available.

Users visiting a city for the first time will be able to dial up for details of a local restaurant, book a table and then be directed to the venue using a route planner sent straight to mobile phones.

fields.headline: £11,000 a week buys a bargain
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: A website dedicated to wealthy Londoners with up to £11,000 a week to spend on renting accommodation opened for business yesterday, claiming its service will make upmarket houses and flats cheaper and easier to find.
fields.body:
A website dedicated to wealthy Londoners with up to £11,000 a week to spend on renting accommodation opened for business yesterday, claiming its service will make upmarket houses and flats cheaper and easier to find.

Globalresident.com, set up by two former bankers, has targeted the financial community in search of accommodation in Central London.

Properties available on the website range from £11,000 a week for Mayfair apartments to £150 a week, for something a little less salubrious.

The company was set up after co-founder Sumir Bhardwaj had problems finding somewhere for his family to move to in central London.

"Everyone who is renting can relate to the fact that there are real inefficiencies in the market, there's a business problem that needs to be fixed," he said.

The company claims it overcomes problems of slow searching and scant choice faced by other such sites.

The system allows users to perform fast detailed searches and arrange viewings through its web-based messaging system, the company said.

The site provides photographs of properties and brief details of facilities provided.

Mr Bhardwaj and co-founder Jason Kushner left jobs at investment bank Merrill Lynch at the end of February and believe their business is unique because it focuses on rental properties in London.

"We are going to have one of the largest selection of quality rental properties in London. You can come to the site when you are sitting at home or in the office, do a very quick search and get a great selection of properties", Mr Bhardwaj said.

He believes the company will be profitable in a year because of its lean and cost-conscious approach, although he declined to specify the business's rate of cash burn.

The aim is to make 60% of income from commission on properties let, with 30% coming from its recommended service providers and 10% from advertising revenue.

fields.headline: Eight-year-old Joseph floats £1m idea
fields.trailText: Eight-year-old Joseph Allen visited the Ofex stock exchange yesterday to oversee preparations for flotation of his company.
fields.body:
Eight-year-old Joseph Allen visited the Ofex stock exchange yesterday to oversee preparations for flotation of his company.

Joseph 's £1-a-week pocket money is likely to be dwarfed by a shareholding worth more than £1m when online betting firm Betachance.com floats on September 8.

"Other children are interested in Legoland and Pokemon, but Joe likes to keep an eye on the stock market," said father, Chris.

Joseph came up with the idea at the age of six while in the bath at his home in Trowbridge, Wilts. His uncle, Godfrey Allen, a professional tipster, wanted to place a bet on the Grand National and Joseph suggested using the internet.

webTitle: It's all herd again, with very little seen

fields.headline: It's all herd again, with very little seen
fields.standfirst:
Notebook
Look warily at dot.com revival
Net news
fields.trailText: Suddenly internet stocks are back in fashion. The bubble which burst so spectacularly earlier in the year is showing signs of re-inflating. Fair enough, the extent to which the sector had fallen has pushed prices down to levels where some sort of bounce was to be expected. But there are worrying signs that the lessons which should have been learned last time round are being ignored.
fields.body:
Suddenly internet stocks are back in fashion. The bubble which burst so spectacularly earlier in the year is showing signs of re-inflating. Fair enough, the extent to which the sector had fallen has pushed prices down to levels where some sort of bounce was to be expected. But there are worrying signs that the lessons which should have been learned last time round are being ignored.

The rally is not driven entirely by sentiment. There is news around that might help to shift perceptions. Last week there was speculation of a merger between Italy's Tiscali and World Online, and the two are talking. Yesterday's trigger was a combination the purchase of Spanish portal operator Ya.com by T-Online, Deutsche Telekom's internet service provider, plus a suggestion that the German company is looking towards Britain and speculation that France's Vivendi was running the rule over UK online directory service Scoot.

But is one purchase plus several rumours sufficient to construct an industry consolidation theory that justifies a plunge back into the sector by cash-rich funds ? Hardly. And why should everyone decide almost overnight that discounts which have been around for months are now irresistible? The most likely explanation is that yesterday's surge was driven by the same kind of herd mentality that propelled the earlier boom in internet stocks.

Valuing internet stocks has always been tricky and has not become easier simply because prices have fallen. That said, investors need to do more than simply buy - or sell - the sector as if it were a single entity. It is made up of many companies with different strategies, managements and prospects. Investors need to differentiate between them. Otherwise the sector will remain fixed an a rollercoaster of boom and bust which will do little for companies or those who buy their shares.

Cross purposes

Privatised utilities have had mixed reviews over the years but the City is warming to Centrica. Yesterday the news that it is taking its British Gas brand into the home telecoms market gave the shares another healthy fillip.

The move is the latest extension of a strategy which is based on extracting maximum cross-selling from a brand portfolio which includes the AA and Goldfish credit cards, and which has seen the company make inroads into the electricity market.

Centrica has some ambitious targets for its telecoms venture. It wants to sign up 1m subscribers by the end of next year and with that in mind is promising some hefty discounts compared to BT's prices, for example.

That should be good news for customers. Whether or not Centrica meets its targets within the time frame it has set itself, the introduction of such a powerful player into the market is bound to exert downward pressure on prices.

True, inertia is still a powerful factor in the utilities market but its impact can be overestimated. More and more households are getting used to changing providers - be it for energy or email - and will increasingly shop around for the best deals.

But while Centrica is bringing welcome competition to a number of areas it is worth considering, if the process of utilities moving into new areas continues, whether there is a danger of replacing the old-style " natural monopolies" with a new breed of tough-to-take-on companies combining strong brands and millions of existing customers.

Fuelling debate

Ali Rodriguez, Venezuela's oil minister as well as president of Opec, showed a neat sense of timing yesterday.

Opec is under heavy pressure from the industrialised world to get the price of oil below the current $30-plus a barrel. But as he emerged from a meeting in Norway Mr Rodriguez sought to turn the tables on his critics. Industrialised countries should look to their own actions if they were so worried, he argued. Within the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, he said, tax accounted for 60% of the retail price of petrol, oil for 12%.

On a day when French truckers besieged refineries and Irish hauliers demanded urgent talks with government, his comments had more resonance that might normally have been the case.

But can governments in industrialised countries cut fuel taxes in the way Mr Rodriguez is suggesting? Despite generally buoyant government finances, the answer is probably not, though some countries may find a little room for manoeuvre. It is not just that oil taxes are a handy money spinner. Cutting the duty now would sit oddly with government initiatives to try to curb consumption and increase efficiency in the struggle against global warming.

Within the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, he said, tax accounted for 60% of the retail price of petrol, oil for 12%. On a day when French truckers besieged refineries and Irish hauliers demanded urgent talks with government, his comments had more resonance that might normally have been the case. But can governments in industrialised countries cut fuel taxes in the way Mr Rodriguez is suggesting? Despite generally buoyant government finances, the answer is probably not, though some countries may find a little room for manoeuvre. It is not just that oil taxes are a handy money spinner. Cutting the duty now would sit oddly with government initiatives to try to curb consumption and increase efficiency in the struggle against global warming.

webTitle: BT derides phones from British Gas

fields.headline: BT derides phones from British Gas
fields.trailText: British Telecom yesterday dismissed plans by British Gas to launch this autumn the most sustained assault on its dominance of the home phone market since privatisation more than 15 years ago.
fields.body:
British Telecom yesterday dismissed plans by British Gas to launch this autumn the most sustained assault on its dominance of the home phone market since privatisation more than 15 years ago.

It also criticised the price claims of British Gas, the former state monopoly owned by Centrica, which aims to capture 1m subscribers by the end of next year, in a market of 24m households of which BT holds around an 80% share.

Centrica, which holds 75% of the domestic gas supply market with 14m customers and has won 3m electricity customers, saw its shares rise 7p to close at 226p as analysts welcomed the latest weapon in its campaign to become the dominant UK multi-utility.

The group, which declares interim results on Thursday, contrasted 96% public awareness of competition in the home energy market two years after liberalisation with 66% in the telecoms market after 18 years of competition.

Centrica, which is investing £150m in a Manchester call centre employing 800, is teaming up with Cable & Wireless and Torch Telecom, part of Kingston Communications, to offer fixed line services and with Vodafone, the market leader, for mobile phones. It has no plans to create its own infrastructure.

It aims to reach its 1m target via its domestic energy consumers, the 9.5m members of the Automobile Association it bought last year, 1m holders of its Goldfish credit card and by offering what it claims are heavily discounted charges.

It said it would be the first to offer a full home phone service, including mobile, internet and family packages offering savings of up to 15% on home to mobile and mobile to mobile calls.

It also claimed to undercut BT's standard residential rates by 33% on local calls, 50% on national calls and up to 75% on international calls, with further discounts available to electricity customers.

All calls will be itemised on one bill but British Gas said it had no plans to put all utilities on one bill as customers did not like the idea.

Ian El-Mokadem, director of marketing and strategy, said 8m households were unaware of competition. "British Gas's arrival in the home phone market means competition and customer choice begins here."

BT, pointing out that Centrica was just one of 200 licensed telecoms operators, said: "This is nothing new to us in any sense. Clearly, we will be looking at their offering and making an appropriate response - depending on the reality of what ensues."

It accused its new rival, which launches next month, of making "highly selective" price comparisons, saying 6.5m of its domestic customers paid half the standard rate via its BT Together package with a further 10% saving on offer via Friends and Family.

fields.headline: At this price?  Rage Software
fields.trailText: Rage Software yesterday struck a distribution deal that will take its games into the vast US market and superstores like Wal-Mart and k-Mart.
fields.body:
Rage Software yesterday struck a distribution deal that will take its games into the vast US market and superstores like Wal-Mart and k-Mart.

The exclusive deal will see Interplay Entertainment Corporation pay Rage an initial royalty fee and then distribute several of its PC and next-generation console games. Analyst believe the deal could be the spur Rage shares need to get them heading back towards previous highs.

Between August last year and February this year Rage shares climbed from 14p to 76p, fuelled by a booming computer games sector and bulletin board support for the company.

Since then they have fallen almost continuously, in line with the downturn in sentiment towards tech stocks and tougher conditions in the games market.

The low point came 10 days ago when the shares fell a further 17% to 22.75p after the firm said a contract had been cancelled and profits would take a hit. Though the valuation was undoubtedly too high at the start of the year, the shares could now represent real value for those prepared to hold long-term.

As games industry executives say, it is the end of a cycle, not the end of the world. Rage is well positioned for the introduction of new platforms and mobile internet devices. Its history of designing high specification content will stand it in good stead for the broadband world.

Several mobile handset manufacturers are thought to be interested in formatting the Liverpool-based publisher's games for their next generation devices.

Judging by the crush to get into the Rage stand at the ECTS trade show in London yesterday, several others are keen.

Recent acquisitions have bedded down and, if anything, the foundations of the company are in better shape than at the start of the year.

The US deal yesterday helped Rage shares up 3% to 26.5p. Recovery prospects make them a long term buy.

webTitle: BT deal puts Motion's videophones on trial

fields.headline: BT deal puts Motion's videophones on trial
fields.trailText: Motion Media yesterday announced agreement to supply British Telecom with 360 videophones for a consumer trial.
fields.body:
Motion Media yesterday announced agreement to supply British Telecom with 360 videophones for a consumer trial.

The videophones, which cost around £1,000 and allow users to have face-to-face conversations, will be tested by householders across Britain.

Motion Media, which supplies video conferencing and surveillance equipment, hopes a successful trial will bolster its order books.

The company, announcing maiden interim results after floating on the stock exchange in May, said sales had been stable at £1.4m for the six months to June 30. But, it admitted, losses stood at £574,482, compared to £241,696 for the same period last year.

Rex Thorne, the chairman, hoped advertising in the UK and US would improve the outlook.

He said: "Our advertising campaigns started in May and therefore had minimal impact upon these figures, but should begin to have an effect in the second half of the year.

"Our order book is significantly stronger now and your board is confident the remaining part of the year will see a resumption of growth in sales."

The shares crept up by 2.5p to 168p last night, adrift of their 180p year high but comfortably ahead of the 58p low.

Technology developed by the company, previously quoted on Ofex, is being used in a £1m telehealth project in West Lothian.

The video systems allow carers to monitor elderly patients 24-hours-a-day with cameras rather than making regular visits to each home.

fields.headline: It's Reflec with a 'c'
fields.trailText: Retail investors love it, City market-makers hate it: Show Me the Money, the Channel 4 gameshow in which five teams of investors are given a virtual £100,000 to play with, returns for a second series next Monday.
fields.body:
Retail investors love it, City market-makers hate it: Show Me the Money, the Channel 4 gameshow in which five teams of investors are given a virtual £100,000 to play with, returns for a second series next Monday.

On its last run, the programme drove up the share prices of numerous companies and is already having an impact on trading in smaller company shares, according to market gossips.

They say Reflec, the inks and coatings specialist, could be making an appearance. Savvy market-makers are said to be loading their books with the stock just in case.

The shares yesterday closed 0.88p lower at 15p after a hefty 1.68m shares changed hands. Dealers hope there will be no repeat of the confusion after Reflec's last mention on the show. Then, a number of viewers misheard the tip and piled into Reflex, a supplier of data-processing facilities.

webTitle: Bridled farmers and drivers halt French petrol

fields.headline: Bridled farmers and drivers halt French petrol
fields.trailText: Panic buying began emptying French petrol stations yesterday before what threatens to be a long blockade of refineries and depots by hauliers, farmers and taxi drivers protesting at high fuel prices.
fields.body:
Panic buying began emptying French petrol stations yesterday before what threatens to be a long blockade of refineries and depots by hauliers, farmers and taxi drivers protesting at high fuel prices.

Late yesterday thousands of lorries, supported in many areas by taxis and tractors, were blocking an estimated 70 refineries and depots, sparing only the Paris region.

A blockade of ports which stranded thousands of British tourists last week ended only when the government agreed to compensate fishermen for a 75% rise in the cost of diesel fuel.

Inconclusive talks between the three main hauliers' unions and the transport minister, Jean-Claude Gayssot, seemed to offer little hope of an early settlement, despite a weekend promise by the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, to "study ways of easing" the impact of rising fuel costs on the industry.

Yvan Battisatel of the National Federation of Road Hauliers said: "We have had to endure rising social and other charges, and now we are struggling with the exorbitant price of diesel, which is climbing daily - we're talking 5, 6, 10 centimes a litre."

The hauliers, prepared for a "long and hard" protest, say diesel fuel has risen 40% in a year. They want fuel taxes cut by at least 20%.

Although the federation and petrol companies said they did not expect serious shortages for at least a week, the queuing began early and filling stations around Grenoble were said to have run dry.

webTitle: Bush proposals for TV debates would limit audiences

fields.headline: Bush proposals for TV debates would limit audiences
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: George W Bush's campaign managers have put forward a plan for three presidential election debates which, to judge by network television viewing figures, seem designed to reduce their candidate's exposure compared with similar debates in previous elections.
fields.body:
George W Bush's campaign managers have put forward a plan for three presidential election debates which, to judge by network television viewing figures, seem designed to reduce their candidate's exposure compared with similar debates in previous elections.

Spurning a scheme for three encounters put forward by the independent Commission on Presidential Debates - all of which would be broadcast live in evening prime time by the main US networks - the Republicans have announced that Mr Bush will take part in one debate on NBC, a second on the cable channel CNN, and only one of the three all-network debates proposed by the commission.

His Democratic rival, Al Gore, promptly rejected the proposal during a campaign stop in Philadelphia yesterday. "What's needed is to respect the rights of the American people to see the debates on all the networks in prime time," he said.

The commission's schedule is for a first all-networks debate in Boston on October 3, followed by one in North Carolina on October 11 and the third in St Louis, Missouri on October 17. In addition, it proposed an all-network debate between the vice-presidential nominees, Joe Lieberman for the Democrats and Dick Cheney for the Republicans, in Kentucky on October 5.

Mr Gore has accepted that schedule for him and Mr Lieberman, and a second vice-presidential debate suggested earlier by the Bush camp. And he has said that, providing Mr Bush accepts the commission schedule, he will meet him for further debate "any place, any time", including, in principle, more than 40 other proposals put forward by individual television shows and online organisations.

Mr Bush proposes an NBC studio debate presented by the anchorman Tim Russert on September 12, a CNN studio debate hosted by the interviewer Larry King on October 3, and the St Louis debate on October 17 under commission auspices.

Viewing figures strongly suggest that this schedule would reach much smaller audiences than all-network debates.

About 41m Americans saw Bill Clinton and Bob Dole debate in 1996. The NBC debate Mr Bush proposes would clash with America's most popular game show, Who Wants to be a Millionaire; no CNN programme has ever had more than 11.3m viewers.

Mr Bush was "talking out of both sides of his mouth" on the debates issue, the Gore campaign said yesterday. "He said he wants more viewers than before, but he put out a proposal clearly designed to minimise the TV audience."

 Mr Bush, who has promised to bring civility to politics, was doing little to prove it yesterday when a microphone caught his whispered description of a New York Times reporter as a "major league asshole".

fields.headline: Britain proposes sweeping UN reform
fields.trailText: The government proposed a thorough shake-up of the United Nations yesterday, including new guidelines allowing it to intervene quickly and with force in countries embroiled in humanitarian crises.
fields.body:
The government proposed a thorough shake-up of the United Nations yesterday, including new guidelines allowing it to intervene quickly and with force in countries embroiled in humanitarian crises.

In a joint statement with the Liberal Democrats, it said the UN security council should be enlarged to include Germany, Japan and representatives from Latin America, Africa, and Asia, joining the US, Russia, China, Britain, and France, as permanent members.

The joint statement from the Labour and Liberal Democrat joint consultative committee reflects the government's enthusiasm for intervening and its frustration at failing to secure international support.

After pointing to the 1994 Rwanda genocide and the 1995 Srebrenica massacre, and seizing on last year's statement by Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, that "no legal principle - not even sovereignty - can shield crimes against humanity" it said: "Our two parties believe profoundly that it is no longer acceptable at the beginning of the 21st century that massive human rights violations and genocide go unchallenged."

In what they called a "framework for intervention" they stated: "When a government has shown that it is palpably unwilling or unable to cope with an overwhelming humanitarian catastrophe, we believe that the international community has a duty to intervene."

They added: "The use of force must be collective and only in exceptional circumstances should it be undertaken without the express authority of the security council of the United Nations."

Challenges in the statement to existing notions of sovereignty were echoed yesterday by the international development secretary, Clare Short.

"The old idea of national sovereignty, of being an island unto yourself _ is gone. The world is one," she told the Royal Institute of International Affairs in London.

But the principle that intervention in a country's sovereign affairs could be justified on humanitarian or human rights grounds is unlikely to be accepted by China if only because of Taiwan and Tibet. Russia, faced with Chechen demands for independence, is also unlikely to welcome it.

Yesterday's statement conceded that UN reforms, including circumstances in which the UN's existing principle of sovereignty could be challenged, would require the unanimous agreement of the current five members of the UN security council.

The UN's inability to mount speedy and effective military and civilian peacekeeping operations - shown up in Sierra Leone and Kosovo - must be addressed by developing "standby arrangements" and better UN training and leadership programmes. "No longer must UN 'blue helmets' stand by while the most serious crimes against humanity are being committed," it said.

The joint statement urged all countries to ratify the statute setting up an international criminal court (opposed by the US), the international conven tions against torture and racial discrimination, and the treaty outlawing landmines.

It proposed a decommissioning body to control the destruction of small arms - responsible for more than 80% of casualties in modern warfare.

Patrick Wintour writes: Liberal Democrat activists claimed that the proposals to restructure the UN security council breached party policy and had been specifically re jected by the party. The Liberal Democrats have called for regional seats on the security council with the current British seat being handed to the EU. Donnachadh McCarthy, a federal executive member, claimed the party's foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, sought unsuccessfully to shift the party's policy towards Labour's.

webTitle: Grid swoops for NY power player

fields.headline: Grid swoops for NY power player
fields.standfirst: £2bn deal doubles group's US operations
fields.trailText: National Grid was last night tying up final details of a $3bn (£2bn) purchase of New York state electricity and gas supplier, Niagara Mohawk Holdings.
fields.body:
National Grid was last night tying up final details of a $3bn (£2bn) purchase of New York state electricity and gas supplier, Niagara Mohawk Holdings.

The deal, which should be finalised today, would be its third big US acquisition within two years and means that half of National Grid group profits would come from across the Atlantic.

Shares in the British group, which runs the UK electricity transmission network and was the first foreign company to take over a US utility, fell 13p to 560p as the City worried about the costs of the move.

Niagara Mohawk, a low growth stock, soared 8% on the New York stock exchange last Friday and rose a further $1 last night to $13.88.

Purchase of Niagara Mohawk would double the size of the National Grid's US operation which is comprised of neighbouring New England Electric System and Boston-based Eastern Utilities Associates acquired for £2.5bn collectively.

National Grid refused to comment on the latest moves but sources close to the talks confirmed that discussions had been going on all year and that an announcement should come today.

Niagara Mohawk supplies electricity to 1.5m people in Syracuse, where it is based, and Albany, the New York state capital.

It also provides gas to 540,000 customers but a welter of restructuring costs meant the company made a first loss of $5.2m in the first six months of the year on turnover of $2.2bn. Niagara Mohawk has a market capitalisation of $2.4bn and heavy long-term debt of about $5bn.

The Niagara deal is expected to be funded by a mixture of cash and equity. National Grid gearing is likely to soar and bring speculation that it will sell down further its 36% holding in its Energis telecoms operation.

National Grid has made no secret of its desire to expand further in North America where margins are considered better than in the UK. At the interim financial results National Grid said that it had achieved more savings than it expected from its US operations and estimated the return on capital would be 10.5% rather than the 8.3% expected. This compares with a 6.5% real return allowed in the UK by the regulator, it said.

National Grid was expected to buy GPU, the holding company for a range of utilities including the Pennsylvania Electric Company, but it was beaten to that deal by FirstEnergy.

When National Grid bought New England ES in December 1998 it said it would use the company as an acquisition platform to look at opportunities in the state and other parts of the north east, which leads the field in deregulation.

National Grid was considered to have paid a high price for New England but justified it by arguing it needed a quality company with top management that would help unlock other acquisitions in the US. Niagara is seen as a different animal with opportunities to make significant cost savings.

National Grid was expected to buy GPU, the holding company for a range of utilities including the Pennsylvania Electric Company, but it was beaten to that deal by FirstEnergy. When National Grid bought New England ES in December 1998 it said it would use the company as an acquisition platform to look at opportunities in the state and other parts of the north east, which leads the field in deregulation. National Grid was considered to have paid a high price for New England but justified it by arguing it needed a quality company with top management that would help unlock other acquisitions in the US. Niagara is seen as a different animal with opportunities to make significant cost savings.

fields.headline: Tom Cobleigh sent packing
fields.trailText: Rank called time on its disastrous four-year attempt to run pubs yesterday, selling its Tom Cobleigh chain to the Electra venture capital group at an exceptional loss of nearly £100m.
fields.body:
Rank called time on its disastrous four-year attempt to run pubs yesterday, selling its Tom Cobleigh chain to the Electra venture capital group at an exceptional loss of nearly £100m.

Electra is paying £90m for the 110-strong estate, which Rank bought for £123m in 1996. The leisure group will have to write off a big chunk of goodwill, having struggled to improve the performance of food-led, family-sized pubs.

Most of the Tom Cobleigh pubs are in the Midlands, where beer sales have been particularly slow. Electra has recruited a former Mansfield Brewery chief, Bill McCosh, to run the business.

Mr McCosh said: "There are some quite good sites in the portfolio, but they've been carrying the albatross of the earlier price that Rank paid for them."

The disposal is the latest step in the break-up of Rank by Mike Smith, the chief executive who is pointing the group towards gambling businesses; Rank owns Mecca bingo halls and Grosvenor casinos.

Mr Smith has already sold the group's nightclubs, Odeon cinemas, Pinewood film studio and a stake in a Universal Studios theme park for a total of £670m. Its holiday camps, which include Butlins, are likely to be next on the block, with caravan parks operator Bourne Leisure tipped to buy them for about £600m.

Rank still has the Hard Rock chain of upmarket burger bars and Deluxe, a video duplication business which has encoutered difficulties this summer due to a disagreement with Fox, one of its biggest clients. Both of these are likely to be sold in the long-term, but remain solid cash generators for a group with debts of close to £600m.

Rank's share rose 5.25p to 172.75p. Fraser Ramzan, an analyst at Lehman Brothers, said: "Gaming's where Mr Smith is putting his money. It was never his intention to be a publican."

webTitle: Pop culture: Avanti heads for the hills

fields.headline: Pop culture: Avanti heads for the hills
fields.trailText: An historic south Wales factory that once turned out bottles of pop has been given a new lease of life as a state of the art digital broadcasting and media complex.
fields.body:
An historic south Wales factory that once turned out bottles of pop has been given a new lease of life as a state of the art digital broadcasting and media complex.

The former Welsh Hills Works at Porth, where grocers Thomas and Evans developed their Corona brand, has been redeveloped as a hi-tech centre by the independent television production company Avanti with backing from the Welsh Development Agency and Rhondda Cynon Taff council.

Avanti, which made its name through its broadcasting and video work with top Welsh bands such as the Stereophonics and the Manic St Preachers, plans to relocate its exist ing 15 staff to the site from Cardiff but hopes new job opportunities will also be created by the £1.3 million development in an area not previously associated with the glitz of the music and broadcast industry.
