fields.headline: PizzaExpress to serve overseas
fields.trailText: PizzaExpress boss David Page said he wanted the chain to "follow in the footsteps of McDonald's" as he announced plans to accelerate its international expansion by opening 15 overseas restaurants over the next year.
fields.body:
PizzaExpress boss David Page said he wanted the chain to "follow in the footsteps of McDonald's" as he announced plans to accelerate its international expansion by opening 15 overseas restaurants over the next year.

The company's shares have been weak due to worries about the risk of its foreign escapades. However, Mr Page struck a confident note yesterday as he served up a 12% increase in annual pre-tax profits to £32.2m.

He said: "We could eventually have thousands of branches overseas. We want to be a slightly more sophisticated version of McDonald's - we'll be where people gravitate to when they've grown up a bit."

Among the target countries in PizzaExpress's sights is Japan, where Mr Page said that pizzas with fish toppings are particularly popular. The company will also open restaurants in Poland, France and Spain, although the US is not a priority - Mr Page said the American market was "terribly aggressive". He admitted: "Half of our shareholders are saying international growth is a great idea, and half of them are very nervous."

The shares, which touched 875p in February, fell 6.5p to 653.5p.

At present, PizzaExpress has 256 restaurants in the British Isles and 24 elsewhere. The company plans 35 openings at home this year and reckons there is scope for more than 450 across the country.

Like-for-like sales rose 3%, despite disappointing high-street trading, helped by changes to the chain's menus and a policy of minimising price rises.

The figures were in line with forecasts but analysts expressed some caution. James Wheatcroft of WestLB Panmure said: "Everyone can see the end of the UK roll-out in sight and the risk profile's changed quite a lot. It's still early days overseas, although the early signs are pretty encouraging."

fields.headline: GP's failure 'cost woman her leg'
fields.trailText: An elderly woman had her right leg amputated above the knee after a doctor failed to diagnose gangrene in her foot, the General Medical Council heard yesterday.
fields.body:
An elderly woman had her right leg amputated above the knee after a doctor failed to diagnose gangrene in her foot, the General Medical Council heard yesterday.

Ndalai Majiyebo Abaniwo saw June Cockburn, then 65, in his surgery and at her home but gave no indication of the seriousness of her condition, the GMC's professional conduct committee heard.

Zoe Johnson, for the GMC, said Dr Abaniwo, a GP at the Five Elms Surgery in Dagenham, Essex, had put her discoloured big toe down to poor circulation and advised her to get more exercise. He did not get her to make a follow-up appointment.

Dr Abaniwo's notes of the appointment on March 31 1998 suggested he had diagnosed peripheral vascular disease but had not informed Mrs Cockburn or her husband.

Mrs Cockburn continued to experience severe pain and the discolouration spread. Two weeks later her husband, Robert, called Dr Abaniwo to their home. Ms Johnson said: "Despite the obvious deterioration in her condition, Dr Abaniwo ... failed to explain the potential seriousness of her condition."

Four days later Mrs Cockburn's daughter-in-law, Sherie, called the surgery and Dr Abaniwo said he had done all he could and that Mrs Cockburn needed to go to hospital.

Ms Johnson said this was the first mention of the need for hospital treatment and of the possibility of gangrene.

Mrs Cockburn went to the accident and emergency department of Oldchurch hospital and three days later her right leg was amputated.

Dr Abaniwo denies serious professional misconduct and failing to safeguard his patient's best medical interests. He rejects failing to indicate how serious Mrs Cockburn's condition was. He also denies that the record of his home visit was "confusing, and untruthful".

Dr Abaniwo told the hearing he had warned Mrs Cockburn at his surgery that if she did not stop smoking she would end up with complications and this could lead to amputation of the toes. He told her and her husband to make an appointment to see him again if there was no improvement.

On his home visit, he said: "I asked about going to the hospital but she refused."

The hearing continues today.

webTitle: Blameless Hirohito 'was a cold war myth'

fields.headline: Blameless Hirohito 'was a cold war myth'
fields.standfirst: US historian redefines Japanese emperor as a keen warrior
fields.trailText: Emperor Hirohito was not the unworldly figurehead and reluctant warrior that he was painted by Japanese and western leaders after 1945, a new American book claims.
fields.body:
Emperor Hirohito was not the unworldly figurehead and reluctant warrior that he was painted by Japanese and western leaders after 1945, a new American book claims.

Rather, he was a much more enthusiastic supporter of expansionism and military aggression than it suited either Japanese or American interests to acknowledge, then or since.

From the end of the second world war until his death in 1989, the American historian Herbert Bix writes, Hirohito was at the centre of an assiduous effort to present him as a remote leader who bore no personal responsibility for Japan's war aims and deeds, against China in the 1930s and the US and its allies in 1941-45.

This version of history is little more than myth, he says. Hirohito's role in defining, urging and supporting Japanese war aims, and the active part he played as commander-in-chief of the armed forces in wars which cost the lives of 20m Asians and more than 3m Japanese, make him "the central symbol of his people's repression of their wartime past".

In Hirohito and the Making of Modern Japan Mr Bix argues that "secrecy, myth and gross misrepresentation" surrounded the emperor, above all in the attempts to depict him as a constitutional monarch with little direct role in policy making, and in the creation of the fiction that he was a pacifist who opposed the attack on Pearl Harbour in 1941 and was eager for a dignified surrender in 1945.

Conservative Japanese and American cold-war interests converged in the effort to establish this version, the book argues. General Douglas MacArthur, who headed the US occupation after atom bombs were dropped on Japan in 1945, persistently argued to Washington that the emperor must remain on the throne if the US was ever to bring its forces home again.

Much of the basis of the post-war myths, says Mr Bix, a professor at Hitotsubashi university in Tokyo, is in the "Monologue" on his wartime role which Hirohito dictated to MacArthur's aides in March 1946. It was not published until after Hirohito's death.

He wrote that "as a constitutional monarch under a constitutional government" he "could not avoid" approving the decision to go to war. Elsewhere he described himself as "virtually a prisoner and powerless" in his dealings with "the militarists".

But, Mr Bix writes: "Hirohito omitted mention of how he and his aides had helped the military to become an enormously powerful political force pushing for arms expansion.

"He ignored the many times he and his entourage has made use of the Meiji system of government by consensus to stifle a more democratic, less militarised political process.

"He intentionally fudged the details about his role as both a military leader and a head of state, blurred his motives, and obfuscated the timing of his actions and the logic that informed them.

"He was silent too about how he had encouraged the belligerency of his people by serving as an active ideological focus of a new emperor-centred nationalism that had grown up around him."

Hirohito was "smarter and shrewder than most people gave him credit for". Never was his cunning used more effectively than in the last 40 years of his life, when he became the only wartime enemy leader to retain his post and to be rehabilitated both at home and in the west.

But the image of the remote poet-emperor and marine biologist which preceded his visits to Europe and the US in the 70s was classic spin doctoring.

From late 1937 onward Hirohito became "a real war leader," Mr Bix writes, influencing strategy and helping to appoint commanders.

The history of his rule before 1945 is "inextricably bound up with the history of Japanese militarism and fascism".

After 1945, "it is connected to efforts by ruling elites to roll back [American] occupation reforms, check Japanese pacifism, and regain the attributes of a great-power state."

fields.headline: Lennon's killer applies for parole
fields.trailText: Mark Chapman, who shot dead John Lennon 20 years ago to draw attention to himself, is applying for parole.
fields.body:
Mark Chapman, who shot dead John Lennon 20 years ago to draw attention to himself, is applying for parole.

The 45-year-old, who is now said to be a model prisoner and a born-again Christian, is to have a hearing next month and could be free before the end of the year, though this is considered unlikely.

Yoko Ono, the former Beatle's widow, will draw up a statement before the hearing at Attica prison in upstate New York, where Chapman is segregated from other inmates and works as a library clerk.

"I'm sure she'll have something to say on the subject," said Elliot Mintz, Ono's spokesman. "Before she makes her feelings known she wants to follow whatever the appropriate protocol is."

Ono said this year that she would do nothing to help the man who shot her husband four times outside their building in Manhattan. "I have to really be concerned about the safety of Julian and Sean [Lennon's sons] and myself."

Jack Jones, who wrote the book Let Me Take You Down about Chapman, said the killer was giving nothing away about how he saw his chances of freedom. "He's keeping his feelings about that pretty much to himself."

But Robert Gangi, the lawyer who heads the Correctional Association of New York, said: "There's not a chance he is going to get parole. Each case should be handled individually, but anyone convicted of the murder of a famous person is probably unlikely ever to get parole."

Chapman has said that he killed Lennon to be famous. "I had to usurp someone else's importance, someone else's success," he said. "I was Mr Nobody until I killed the biggest somebody on earth."

webTitle: Yellow brick estate could make grade as listed area

fields.headline: Yellow brick estate could make grade as listed area
fields.trailText: A modest yellow brick and red tiled housing estate in Bristol which was completed in 1974 has been put forward for listed building status.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A modest yellow brick and red tiled housing estate in Bristol which was completed in 1974 has been put forward for listed building status.

Normally buildings are only eligible for listing after 30 years, but the date is taken from the time the first concrete was poured, which should make the the High Kingsdown estate eligible by a matter of months. The most modern listed estate is Alexander Road, in north London, begun in 1972 but completed in 1978, which was granted emergency Grade II* listed status to protect it from development.

The Bristol scheme was seen as a pioneer of dense but low-rise inner city development but it is the dumpiness of the yellow brick and red concrete tile town houses which makes High Kingsdown exceptional.

Although the government has listed several other housing estates from the 1960s and early 1970s, on the advice of English Heritage, they are almost all towers or hulking blocks of flats. The contrast with the hundred modest terraced houses, just north of Bristol city centre, is striking.

"It's their scale that makes them so unusual for their date," Kingsley Fullbrook, Bristol council's conservation officer who is recommending that the council apply to the government for listing, said yesterday. "In many ways this was a forward looking design."

Robert Goard, of the architects Whicheloe Macfarlane, said the scheme marked a turning point in Bristol.

"We prepared the scheme to a brief from the city council, and I think they were expecting more tower blocks, which were then seen as an acceptable answer to achieving urban population density. We were able to show that you could achieve the same density without going above two stories. It spelled the end of high rise in Bristol."

The estate was built with cars kept on the perimeter, and the main windows looking into courtyards and gardens, linked by pedestrian lanes. A Victorian pub on the site was preserved - again in contrast with the scorched earth approach of most1960s and early 70s development.

Opinions are mixed on the estate. Noela O'Shea said the estate was unique, and deserved the protection of listing. However student Joel Lewis thought the idea ridiculous: "I think it's a bit of a laugh. The estate looks like a load of breeze blocks were just dropped from the sky."

English Heritage's listings officer Elain Harwood, an authority on 20th century architecture, said: "I'd be very happy to consider it. I haven't seen it since I stayed there when I was a student 20 years ago."

webTitle: Debris found near Kursk linked to British and US submarines

fields.headline: Debris found near Kursk linked to British and US submarines
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Russian salvage teams at the scene of the Kursk submarine disaster have found an object resembling part of the conning tower of a British or American nuclear submarine, a senior Russian officer said yesterday.
fields.body:
Russian salvage teams at the scene of the Kursk submarine disaster have found an object resembling part of the conning tower of a British or American nuclear submarine, a senior Russian officer said yesterday.

Reiterating the Russian navy line that the most likely explanation for the sudden sinking of the Kursk on August 12 was a collision with a foreign vessel, Colonel General Valery Manilov, the deputy chief of the general staff, told a press conference in Moscow that the object was lying at the bottom of the Barents sea, off the coast of Murmansk, and was being guarded by Russian warships.

The Russian top brass continued to believe that the likeliest cause of the Kursk disaster was a collision with "an other large underwater object", Gen Manilov declared.

Norwegian, British, and American experts have all queried the plausibility of the collision theory. US intelligence last week made it plain that it believed a torpedo explosion in the Kursk had ripped open the hull of the 152-metre (500ft) submarine and precipitated its instant flooding and sinking, killing 118 seamen.

The Americans confirmed that the US navy had two submarines and a spy ship in the Barents sea monitoring the Russian naval exercises at the time of the disaster, though leaked information in Washington named only one of the submarines. The Russians later named the mystery submarine as the Toledo and said it was now at the Faslane nuclear submarine base in Scotland.

There were several pieces of indirect evidence to support the collision scenario, Gen Manilov said. "The Kursk probably collided with another submarine whose keel cut open the nose of the [Kursk] submarine and possibly damaged the hull. The collision version is also confirmed by the nature of the other damage to the Kursk - the damage to the tower and the fact that its railings were removed."

Only 50 metres from the sunken Kursk, Russian rescue vessels had found "something resembling the railings of a conning tower similar to those fitted on American and British nuclear submarines", the general went on.

The mystery object could not be raised from the seabed and so the area was being guarded by Russian battleships, he said.

The Russian rescue teams and monitors had also located a raised area on the seabed 500 metres from the Kursk, but this "hillock" subsequently disappeared.

From the very start of the Kursk crisis, senior officers such as Igor Sergeyev, the defence minister, and Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov, the navy commander, have pushed the theory that the Kursk was downed by a Nato vessel.

Gen Manilov said yesterday that the collision then triggered the explosion of pressurised cylinders on the Kursk.

Norwegian, American, and British services who monitored the disaster heard two explosions on the morning of August 12, two and a half minutes apart and the second much louder than the first.

Reiterating the Russian navy line that the most likely explanation for the sudden sinking of the Kursk on August 12 was a collision with a foreign vessel, Colonel General Valery Manilov, the deputy chief of the general staff, told a press conference in Moscow that the object was lying at the bottom of the Barents sea, off the coast of Murmansk, and was being guarded by Russian warships. The Russian top brass continued to believe that the likeliest cause of the Kursk disaster was a collision with "an other large underwater object", Gen Manilov declared. Norwegian, British, and American experts have all queried the plausibility of the collision theory. US intelligence last week made it plain that it believed a torpedo explosion in the Kursk had ripped open the hull of the 152-metre (500ft) submarine and precipitated its instant flooding and sinking, killing 118 seamen. The Americans confirmed that the US navy had two submarines and a spy ship in the Barents sea monitoring the Russian naval exercises at the time of the disaster, though leaked information in Washington named only one of the submarines. The Russians later named the mystery submarine as the Toledo and said it was now at the Faslane nuclear submarine base in Scotland. There were several pieces of indirect evidence to support the collision scenario, Gen Manilov said. "The Kursk probably collided with another submarine whose keel cut open the nose of the [Kursk] submarine and possibly damaged the hull. The collision version is also confirmed by the nature of the other damage to the Kursk - the damage to the tower and the fact that its railings were removed." Only 50 metres from the sunken Kursk, Russian rescue vessels had found "something resembling the railings of a conning tower similar to those fitted on American and British nuclear submarines", the general went on. The mystery object could not be raised from the seabed and so the area was being guarded by Russian battleships, he said. The Russian rescue teams and monitors had also located a raised area on the seabed 500 metres from the Kursk, but this "hillock" subsequently disappeared. From the very start of the Kursk crisis, senior officers such as Igor Sergeyev, the defence minister, and Admiral Vladimir Kuroyedov, the navy commander, have pushed the theory that the Kursk was downed by a Nato vessel. Gen Manilov said yesterday that the collision then triggered the explosion of pressurised cylinders on the Kursk. Norwegian, American, and British services who monitored the disaster heard two explosions on the morning of August 12, two and a half minutes apart and the second much louder than the first.

fields.headline: Estate for sale at £18.5m
fields.trailText: Being a squire is far from a common fantasy, but the owners of a 5,000 acre Hampshire country estate hope that someone will want to make it a reality when it goes on sale today.
fields.body:
Being a squire is far from a common fantasy, but the owners of a 5,000 acre Hampshire country estate hope that someone will want to make it a reality when it goes on sale today.

The potential lord or lady of the Hursley estate near Winchester will need £18.5m to buy the five acre hamlet, a cricket ground, more than 1,000 acres of woodland and the opportunity to create a pheasant and partridge shoot.

Smiths Gore, the chartered surveyors handling the sale, expect interest to come from the world's mega-rich. "We expect it to go to one purchaser. The types of people we anticipate being able to buy it are pop stars, financiers, sheikhs or dot.com millionaires. Inquires from over-seas have been made," a spokeswoman said. "There are people who want a secure investment as well as the beauty of the rolling woodlands and chocolate box cottages that are quintessentially English."

But any buyer envisaging a manor house should budget for building it. Although the working estate includes 23 cottages, three farm houses and a 12th century ruined castle, the principal house, Park House, was sold to IBM in 1961.

The new owner will, however, receive income from the rent of the cottages, and the lease of Merdon castle and Farley Mount, one of the highest views in Hampshire, to Hampshire county council.

"The new owners could terminate the short-lets and move their whole family in," the spokeswoman said.

She added that it was very rare that an entire working estate such as Hursley comes on the market. "It's causing a sensation in the farming community," she said.

Some of the buildings, which date from the 18th century to the present day, house the estate's 12 employees. The working estate includes arable, sheep and dairy farming.

The sale of Hursley, which has been owned by St Martin's Property since 1982, is the biggest single area of commercial farmland to come on the market in the south of England this year.

The estate owes its origins to the bishops of Winchester who controlled the land for more than 900 years before surrendering it to the crown in 1552. In 1638 it came under the ownership of Richard Major, a member of Oliver Cromwell's privy council.

fields.headline: DC-10 shed Concorde's fatal strip
fields.standfirst: Special report: the Concorde crash
fields.trailText: Investigators looking into the Air France Concorde crash outside Paris on July 25 said yesterday that the 41cm (16in) strip of metal which almost certainly caused the accident seemed identical to one missing from a Continental Airlines DC-10 which took off minutes earlier.
fields.body:
Investigators looking into the Air France Concorde crash outside Paris on July 25 said yesterday that the 41cm (16in) strip of metal which almost certainly caused the accident seemed identical to one missing from a Continental Airlines DC-10 which took off minutes earlier.

The French accident investigation bureau (BEA) said the strip found on the runway appeared to come from the cowling of the fan reverser on the DC-10's right engine.

Continental said the twisted, epoxy-coated strip was the same shape as a piece missing from the engine of flight COA 55. It was not there when officials of the airline, the BEA, the US federal aviation administration and the national transportation and safety board inspected the plane in Houston on Saturday, it said.

The strip had been replaced on July 9 during a routine engine inspection.

Because the investigation was continuing it was "inappropriate to comment further," the company added.

The French investigators' interim report published last week suggested that the strip probably caused a tyre to explode, sending heavy chunks of rubber into the unprotected wings and puncturing one or more of the fuel tanks.

The resulting fire sent the plane plunging into a hotel, killing all 109 people on board and another four on the ground.

A spokesman for Aéroports de Paris, which runs Roissy-Charles de Gaulle airport, said yesterday that it was "a little too simplistic" to blame the crash on the postponement of a routine runway inspection due an hour or so before the Concorde took off.

The BEA report said the inspection was delayed to allow time for a 35-minute fire drill, leaving the runway from which the Concorde took off unchecked for more than 12 hours.

"No one can say whether an inspection would have uncovered anything untoward," the spokesman, Didier Hamon, said. "And if the firemen who were on the runway had seen a foreign object they would have recovered it or reported it."

A pilot and BEA expert, François Grangier, said the postponed inspection was unimportant from a technical viewpoint.

"Between each take-off you have six or seven aircraft crossing the runway," he said.

"Potentially, the risk of debris falling off is considerable. What is important is that aircraft have tyres that can withstand this kind of incident."

The president of Air France, Pierre-Henri Gourgeon, said yesterday that he could not see Concorde resuming service - if at all - before next April.

webTitle: Victory for Putin in battle for 'Russia's BBC1'

fields.headline: Victory for Putin in battle for 'Russia's BBC1'
fields.trailText: Russia's summer-long struggle for control of national television turned sharply towards victory for President Vladimir Putin yesterday when the influential Russian media mogul, Boris Berezovsky, announced that he was surrendering control of Russia's main state channel.
fields.body:
Russia's summer-long struggle for control of national television turned sharply towards victory for President Vladimir Putin yesterday when the influential Russian media mogul, Boris Berezovsky, announced that he was surrendering control of Russia's main state channel.

The concession, coupled with a searing attack on Mr Putin's campaign to tame the free media, left the Kremlin confident that the two most important television channels in Russia and the most formidable sources of opposition were being brought to heel.

In what was seen as a big victory for Mr Putin, who has made control of the media, particularly national television, a central plank in his campaign to entrench his political power, Mr Berezovsky said he was surrendering his 49% share of ORT, the main state television channel, to "journalists and intellectuals" after coming under intense pressure from the Kremlin and being presented with an ultimatum.

In a letter to Mr Putin, leaked to the Interfax news agency, Mr Berezovsky said one of the president's most senior aides had told him he had a fortnight to get rid of the ORT shares. Mr Berezovsky alleged he was threatened with imprisonment if he continued to defy Mr Putin.

While Mr Berezovsky stressed he was surrendering his shares into the care of ORT journalists, his letter appeared to be an admission of defeat, crowning a summer of media wars between the Kremlin and the two big national television channels.

ORT, meaning "public Russian television", is the equivalent of BBC1 and the only Russian channel broadcasting to the entire country.

Vladimir Gusinsky, Mr Berezovsky's rival and the owner of NTV, the country's biggest private channel, is in exile in Spain after being briefly jailed, having his offices raided, and being pressured to transfer control of the station to Gazprom, the gas monopoly which is acting as a proxy for the Kremlin.

"We share Berezovsky's concern for the future of the freedom of the press in Russia," Mr Gusinsky's Media-Most company said in a statement last night.

In an outspoken attack a fortnight ago, Mr Putin accused both magnates of being liars and thieves and rounded on both stations for their coverage of the Kursk submarine tragedy.

Mr Berezovsky's letter stressed that he was forced to surrender control of ORT, arguing that Mr Putin had confronted the public with "a very important question - whether or not non-state mass media have the right to exist in Russia".

He said the Kremlin aide presented the ultimatum last week. "I should either transfer my ORT shares to the state within two weeks or follow Gusinsky" - he was obviously referring to prison.

Mr Berezovsky pointed out that if he accepted the ultimatum, "television information will come to a halt in Russia, to be replaced by television propaganda controlled by your advisers".

Mr Berezovsky has exploited his control of ORT to promote his political agenda, which last year included putting Mr Putin in power. He has since fallen out with the Putin administration, resigned his Duma seat, and launched a new movement of "constructive opposition" to the Kremlin.

Both Mr Berezovsky and Mr Gusinsky are widely reviled as super-wealthy "oligarchs" by the public and Mr Putin remains hugely popular among Russians.

The rise and fall of a media mogul:
 In a Byzantine political culture where backroom dealing is the preferred modus operandi, Boris Berezovsky, left, is Russia's foremost schemer

 He rose to prominence in the early 90s following the collapse of communism by diligently cultivating Boris Yeltsin and his influential daughter Tatyana Dyachenko

 He built his fortune in the car and oil industries, benefiting from the corrupt privatisation process in Russia in the early 90s and the "loans-for shares" arrangements agreed between Russia's political and business elites in the mid-90s

 As part of the partial privatisation of ORT, the main state television channel, Berezovsky acquired a 49% share of the only broadcaster with a nationwide reach and used that clout to promote first Yeltsin and then Putin. He also extended his media empire to ownership of several newspapers

 With Yeltsin trailing in the polls in 1996, Berezovsky and his media rival Gusinsky joined forces to put the two big channels at Yeltsin's disposal and win him a second term against the odds

 Last year he performed the same trick for Putin, destroying the president's rivals through a vicious television campaign of character assassination

 A Swiss inquiry into claims that two of his companies were siphoning hundreds of millions of dollars from the national carrier, Aeroflot, have been repeatedly stymied and last month the Russian prosecutor investigating the allegations was sacked

 Berezovsky and Putin have increasingly been at loggerheads since March. Berezovsky appears peeved at losing his place in the Kremlin inner circle and has been using his media to attack Putin on Chechnya, policy toward the regions, big business, and on the handling of the Kursk tragedy

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bomb reminder for Russians
fields.body:
Bomb reminder for Russians

An explosion in St Petersburg and another in the provincial city of Ryazan yesterday raised Russian fears of a repeat of last September's bombing mayhem which left 300 people dead, but officials were quick to blame criminal feuding rather than political terror.

The interior minister, Vladimir Rushailo, said there was no evidence of "terrorism as it is understood in Russia".

He meant that the blast was not caused by Chechen rebels at war with Russia for the past year. September's bombings were used by President Vladimir Putin to justify his war in Chechnya. [Ian Traynor, Moscow]

Swiss name Abacha banks

Switzerland's regulators criticised six banks under their jurisdiction yesterday for accepting dubious holdings from sources close to the late Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha - but it stressed that other countries' banks, too, were involved.

Switzerland has frozen some $670m (£446m) suspected of being stashed there by Abacha, who died in office in 1998.

Named for inadequate vigilance by the Federal Banking Commission were three units of the Credit Suisse Group, as well as Credit Agricole Indosuez, Union Bancaire Privée and MM Warburg Bank.

But, the report said, banks in Britain, the US, Austria, France, Luxembourg and Liechtenstein were involved in transfers. [AP, Geneva]

£77m payout for radiation

A Japanese uranium-processing firm, JCO Co, said yesterday it agreed to pay a total of 12.66bn yen in compensation to settle 6,875 claims arising from Japan's worst nuclear accident in September last year.

At least 150 cases remain involving radiation harm to people and businesses. Workers at the JCO plant in Tokaimura, 70 miles north-east of Tokyo, mixed nitric acid and enriched uranium in buckets, setting off an uncontrolled atomic reaction. [AP, Tokyo]

Nile vision

A reported apparition of the Virgin Mary on the dome of a church has been drawing crowds to the city of Assiut, in central Egypt since the first reported sighting on August17.

Church authorities have made no claims, but issued a statement saying that some neighbours around the church of St Mark said they had seen a flock of exceptionally white and large pigeons, accompanied by a shining light and an apparition of what was held to be Mary. [AP, Assiut]

webTitle: Tamil Tigers take pounding from army's big guns

fields.headline: Tamil Tigers take pounding from army's big guns
fields.trailText: The Sri Lankan army says that its forces have launched a counter-offensive in the north, using new heavy artillery and other weapons to give "a real pounding" to positions held by the Tamil Tiger rebels in the Jaffna peninsula.
fields.body:
The Sri Lankan army says that its forces have launched a counter-offensive in the north, using new heavy artillery and other weapons to give "a real pounding" to positions held by the Tamil Tiger rebels in the Jaffna peninsula.

A military spokesman said that 106 soldiers and eight officers were killed yesterday and Sunday in operations around the town of Jaffna. Located in the south-west of the peninsula, it has been surrounded by the Tamil Tigers since they captured large swaths of territory from the army earlier this year.

The government says that it has been using a variety of new weapons in the offensive, including multi-barrel rocket launchers, mortars and heavy artillery. "We are pleased that with these recently acquired armaments we have been able to subject Tamil Tigers positions in the south-west of the Jaffna peninsula to a real pounding," a spokesman in the defence ministry said, "in some cases subjecting them to over 48 hours of constant bombardment."

The army said that hundreds of rebels had been killed in the latest fighting. A statement from the Tamil Tigers' office in London said the heaviest casualties were on the government side, whose territorial gains were small. Independent verification of either side's claims is all but impossible.

One diplomat argued that the fact that the army had to follow its bombardment with hand to hand fighting showed the resilience of the Tigers.

"They are a kind of trinity," the diplomat said, "capable of launching terrorist attacks in the form of suicide bombings, hit-and-run guerrilla attacks in the jungle and full scale offensive and defensive actions which normally are the preserve of fully trained armies.

"The fact that the army has encountered such vigorous resisitance in this latest action shows just how stong and well trained the guerrillas are."

For the Sri Lankan army, the offensive is the first since a series of defeats that began in November. In April the Tigers captured Elephant Pass, the only gateway to the northern Jaffna peninsula, forcing the government to abandon any hope it had of establishing a land route to around 40,000 troops based there.

Since then, a stand-off has largely prevailed, with occasional skirmishes. Critics of President Chandrika Kumaratunga - who also holds the defence portfolio - say that the army's new offensive was in part started to boost her People's Alliance coalition before parliamentary elections on October 10.

President Kumaratunga has denied this, saying that her aim has always been to defeat the Tigers militarily before beginning any peace talks.

webTitle: Lebanon votes back ousted PM Hariri

fields.headline: Lebanon votes back ousted PM Hariri
fields.trailText: Rafic Hariri, the former prime minister who dominated Lebanese politics for most of the 90s, has returned to power in a spectacular reversal of fortunes.
fields.body:
Rafic Hariri, the former prime minister who dominated Lebanese politics for most of the 90s, has returned to power in a spectacular reversal of fortunes.

The billionaire tycoon, who fell from power less than two years ago, has emerged victorious from the general election. It is a blow to the regime of President Emile Lahoud, his personal foe, and, by implication, a signal to Syria that its influence over Lebanon is now liable to be steadily eroded.

Mr Hariri and most of his allies are just as pro-Syrian as most of their defeated rivals. But one of the staunchest of them, the Druze leader Walid Jumblatt, has begun calling for a "readjustment" of Syrian-Lebanese relations.

Despite all Mr Lahoud 's efforts to thwart Mr Hariri's comeback, it has been the most remarkable one in the history of Lebanese elections. It was already clear from the first stage a week ago that he and his allies were on the way to a resounding success, but in Sunday's second stage, when voting took place in Beirut, Mr Hariri's stronghold, they surpassed all expectations, taking 18 of the capital's 19 seats.

Mr Hariri now controls the biggest block in parliament, 26 seats, and with his allies he can rely on the support of 92 of the 128 deputies. He needs only a two thirds majority to be designated prime minister. Despite his personal antipathy, the president has implied that he will let him return to power.

Before the voting many commentators dismissed the elections as a masquerade: the electoral lists had been more or less remote-controlled from Damascus; the electoral districts had been re-drawn at the expense of the opposition; the regime accused Mr Hariri of buying votes; and the opposition accused the intelligence services of pressure, manipulation and harassment.

It is the first time an incumbent prime minister has been defeated in an election: the widely respected academic Salim al-Hoss got 11,000 votes less than the only woman candidate elected in Beirut.

Mr Hariri left office under heavy criticism. He came to power in 1992 as a potential "saviour" who would restore Lebanon to its pre-war ascendancy as the business capital of the Middle East, but for all his wealth and dynamism the vast infrastructural projects he undertook brought little benefit to the people, whose living standards continued to fall. Corruption was rampant.

Given that record, his comeback is perhaps less a triumph for himself than a defeat for President Lahoud, who appointed Mr Hoss in his place.

The billionaire tycoon, who fell from power less than two years ago, has emerged victorious from the general election. It is a blow to the regime of President Emile Lahoud, his personal foe, and, by implication, a signal to Syria that its influence over Lebanon is now liable to be steadily eroded. Mr Hariri and most of his allies are just as pro-Syrian as most of their defeated rivals. But one of the staunchest of them, the Druze leader Walid Jumblatt, has begun calling for a "readjustment" of Syrian-Lebanese relations. It was already clear from the first stage a week ago that he and his allies were on the way to a resounding success, but in Sunday's second stage, when voting took place in Beirut, Mr Hariri's stronghold, they surpassed all expectations, taking 18 of the capital's 19 seats. fields.headline: Latvian in for injured Adams
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger moved quickly yesterday to fill the gap left by the injury to Tony Adams - who will miss Arsenal's next two Premiership matches and is struggling to be fit for England's opening World Cup qualifier against Germany on October 7 - by signing the Latvian international Igor Stepanovs for £1m.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger moved quickly yesterday to fill the gap left by the injury to Tony Adams - who will miss Arsenal's next two Premiership matches and is struggling to be fit for England's opening World Cup qualifier against Germany on October 7 - by signing the Latvian international Igor Stepanovs for £1m.

Wenger put an optimistic gloss on the damage the 33-year-old defender sustained against France at the weekend, which included a hurt back in addition to the ankle he twisted after a challenge by Marcel Desailly.

"Happily it looks like only a short-term problem," the Arsenal manager said yesterday.

"It is sad for Tony and a huge blow for us to be without him because he is such an influential player. But physically he is very sharp and although he won't play in our next two Premiership games there is still the slight possibility that he might be available for the match in Prague [against Sparta in the Champions League next Tuesday]. At the moment that looks a little early for him but after that I believe he has a good chance to come back."

Arsenal have secured a work permit for Stepanovs, who has won 37 caps for Latvia, though the 24-year-old has signed from the Latvian side Skonto too late to be eligible for this stage of the Champions League. "He is an experienced international and a very competent defender who will prove to be a great asset to the club," said Wenger.

Meanwhile, the Arsenal striker Nwankwo Kanu is set to miss the Olympics after he wrote to the Nigeria Football Association asking to be left out of the squad .The rest of the squad has arrived in Australia and Nigeria's sports ambassador John Fashanu said: "If he does not go to the Olympics I do not think there is any point in him going back to Nigeria for his holidays for the next 20 years."

Huddersfield's Dutch striker Clyde Wijnhard, 26, is in hospital with a compound fracture of his arm after his car crashed on the A1.

Aston Villa have been fined £5,200 by Uefa for the team's "improper conduct" in the InterToto Cup matches with Celta Vigo. Ugo Ehiogu and Alan Thompson were sent off in the second leg at Villa Park.

Celtic have confirmed that their chief executive Allan MacDonald is leaving the club.

Jesper Blomqvist faces another lengthy spell on Manchester United's sidelines after Sir Alex Ferguson revealed that the winger has suffered a fresh knee injury.

Manchester United's Henning Berg and Liverpool's Rigobert Song are wanted by Blackburn, said Rovers' chief executive John Williams.

Fulham's Jean Tigana has won the season's first Nationwide manager of the month award.

webTitle: Leeds fans risk being thrown out of Turkey

fields.headline: Leeds fans risk being thrown out of Turkey
fields.trailText: Leeds emerged from long and delicate negotiations with Besiktas last night to announce that they would take 500 supporters to next month's Champions League game in Istanbul, but that anyone travelling independently would be thrown out of Turkey.
fields.body:
Leeds emerged from long and delicate negotiations with Besiktas last night to announce that they would take 500 supporters to next month's Champions League game in Istanbul, but that anyone travelling independently would be thrown out of Turkey.

Concern will be heightened by Besiktas being fined yesterday by Uefa for misbehaviour by their fans in a recent home Champions League qualifier, especially as the Leeds chairman Peter Ridsdale revealed that 500 Turkish supporters would be given tickets for the potentially volatile match at Elland Road on September 26.

Both clubs have pledged to ensure travelling fans are strictly vetted to weed out anyone with a criminal conviction. Leeds have also been assured that any fans travelling to Istanbul apart from on the club's official trip will be deported immediately.

"In our view anyone else who goes to Turkey with the intentions of watching the game without our supervision will not be there for the right reasons," said Ridsdale. "As such we will be asking the authorities to send them straight home."

The Yorkshire club have advised the FA of their plans after talks with the Foreign Office, West Yorkshire police and the families of Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight, the two fans killed in Istanbul on the eve of Leeds's Uefa Cup semi-final against Galatasaray in April.

The Besiktas president Serdar Bilgili will be a special guest at Elland Road tonight for the game against Manchester City before flying to Geneva with Ridsdale tomorrow for a meeting with Uefa's chief executive Gerhard Aigner at which they expect to have their proposals sanctioned.

But immediate concerns about Leeds fans travelling to the 45,000-capacity Inonu stadium on October 18 were raised as Uefa fined Beskitas £3,200 because fireworks were set off and missiles thrown in the qualifier against Levski Sofia.

Rangers will take 250 fans to their Champions League game against Galatasaray on September 27. Only season-ticket holders and registered members of their supporters' clubs will be allowed.

webTitle: Testing times ahead for the old crocks

fields.headline: Testing times ahead for the old crocks
fields.standfirst: Are today's fitness tests as rigorous as some would have us believe or are the players just a bunch of pansies?
fields.trailText: Are today's fitness tests as rigorous as some would have us believe or are the players just a bunch of pansies?
fields.body:
At one time, passing the medical examination before a big-money transfer was nothing more than a formality for the British professional footballer. Of the stars of yesteryear only the lank-haired 70s maverick Frank Worthington truly botched one, missing out on a move from Leicester City to Liverpool because of high blood pressure.

In Worthington's estimable autobiography One Hump Or Two, the elegant striker puts his condition down to overexcitement created by a week of sensual excess in southern Spain. A look at the book's photo section suggests another possible cause: over-tight knitwear. When you've an orange-and-brown striped tank-top cutting off the circulation to your arms, doing The Bump in a Malaga nightspot is likely to send all that displaced haemoglobin shooting out of your ears.

Alas, such easy-going attitudes to transfers are now a thing of the past, as John Hartson discovered on Thursday at Ibrox when he flunked his second high-profile fitness test of the past six months. On the previous occasion this happened, last season at White Hart Lane, a £7m move collapsed as the result. On that occasion the chunky Welshman's agent Jonathan Barnett commented bitterly: "Even Mother Teresa would have failed that fitness test."

No wonder Barnett was disappointed. Though George Graham's insistence that new signings have a thorough knowledge of theology and are willing to sacrifice personal comfort to minister to the sick (insert your own Darren Anderton joke here) is commendable, it speaks volumes for the insane world of modern football that the game's rulers now expect the honest British pro to display more stamina and athleticism than a dead Albanian nun.

In the days of Worthington and Co things were very different. Fitness tests were less sophisticated. Character was the thing, the ability to withstand pain, hardship and the interminable Norman Wisdom impressions of the team's dressing-room joker. Usually the prospective new signing was simply shown a picture of the Scandinavian sex bomb Britt Ekland in a bikini and if he responded with a hoarse "Phwoar!" he was considered to have all the attributes necessary for the red-blooded hurly-burly of the Football League.

After all, when centre-backs trundled about the pitch like runaway traction engines and referees displayed as much compassion towards the victims of violence as Caligula, fitness was a transient thing. There was little point in wasting a doctor's fee to find out a player was in prime condition when two weeks later he was likely to be lying in a hospital bed contemplating a career as a publican with an ankle joint that offered a more accurate prediction of coming damp spells than Bill Giles at the London Weather Centre.

Players were cheaper too. In those days purchasing a pre-owned centre-forward was a bit like buying a used car. You approach the motor with a look on your face that you hope conveys a mixture of steely toughness and extensive mechanical knowledge. You lift the bonnet, scratch your head, kick the tyres and if no bits fall off you cross your fingers and hand over the cash. Now signing a player is more like investing in a house. You have to have a thorough independent survey before the bank will advance the money.

Insurance is the key, of course. Terms and premiums are based on risk. If Fifa hadn't outlawed the tackle from behind, forwards might all have become as hard to secure cover for as a firework factory on the slopes of Mount Etna. As it is the expensive but fragile likes of Ruud van Nistelrooy still put the wind up the insurers.

It is possible that all this effort might end up working in the clubs' favour in an unexpected way, of course. After all, now that Uefa seems about to scrap transfer fees for players over the age of 24, big-money buys such as Luis Figo will be allowed to simply walk away from a club after 12 months. In this situation the club becomes like a householder with negative equity. An insurance settlement may be the only way to recoup an investment.

A couple of likely lads, the keys left in an obvious place and the next thing you know your expensive playmaker's been left a burnt-out shell. Or been clattered from behind by an uncompromising No5 in exchange for a backhander. Either way it's the kind of pay-off that will keep those shareholders happy.

fields.headline: England bask in champagne moment
fields.trailText: After 31 years of torment, of battered bodies, broken limbs and humiliation, English cricket finally enjoyed its day of days against West Indies yesterday.
fields.body:
After 31 years of torment, of battered bodies, broken limbs and humiliation, English cricket finally enjoyed its day of days against West Indies yesterday.

Victory by 158 runs, achieved 12 minutes into the final session and in front of a full house on the fifth day of a Test for the first time in living memory, was as emphatic as it was sweet. Seeking to make an improbable 374 to win, from 33 without loss overnight, West Indies lost wickets steadily throughout the day against the ebullient England pace attack, led thrillingly once more by Darren Gough, who finished with three for 64, and Andy Caddick, four for 54. Those two shared seven of the first eight wickets before stepping aside for Dominic Cork to finish it off with two wickets in three balls.

Only while Brian Lara was at the crease did West Indies harbour even a minuscule hope of achieving the win they needed to level the series. But he was leg-before, unluckily perhaps, to Gough for a brilliant 47, and that effectively was that.

West Indies, to put things in perspective, had fallen short of their victory target by precisely the number of runs Mike Atherton and Marcus Trescothick had put on for the first wicket of the match after Jimmy Adams had put England in.

Twenty minutes after the stumps had been grabbed and the England team had sprinted off, Nasser Hussain, finally, lifted the Wisden Trophy to mass acclaim on the same balcony where last summer he was booed after defeat by New Zealand.

Hussain has led the side with increasing authority this summer but he is level-headed enough to know that once the celebrations have died down there is work to be done. By the time they reach the Oval again 12 months hence England will have played winter series in Pakistan and Sri Lanka and home series against Pakistan once more and Australia. It is feasible that they will play very well in each of those and yet lose. True progress will only be measured by consistency.

Yesterday's attendance of 18,000-odd was a revelation. Before play the queues stretched down the Harleyford Road, and by midday the gates were closed and the empty hospitality boxes had been opened up as overspill areas.

The crowd saw Sherwin Campbell and Adrian Griffith continue their flyer of the previous evening, taking the score to 50 before Campbell, who had been dropped at second slip by Graeme Hick the previous ball, edged a lifter fast to the same fielder, who clung on in front of his face and not without relief. In the following over Griffith edged Caddick low to Alec Stewart and England were away.

Lara would always be the stumbling block. On Sunday evening, as the players left the field, he emerged to hammer throwdowns into the boundary boards, perhaps as a statement. Yesterday he moved up the order to three. At the start he laboured, pinned down by the accuracy and purpose of Gough and Caddick.

At the other end Wavell Hinds had been missed at slip, again by Hick, before becoming another lbw victim - one of 14 in the match - this time to Caddick's inswinging yorker.
A double bowling change, with Cork and Craig White replacing the two opening bowlers, let Lara slip the leash as he swivelled on his left leg to pull both to the fence for his first boundaries. He and Adams added 36 for the fourth wicket either side of lunch before Hussain, perceptively, moved White a little finer at leg gully to where the West Indies captain immediately flicked a low catch.

The best batting came now with Lara and the young right-hander Ramnaresh Sarwan attacking with relish, Lara hitting Gough from the attack and Sarwan leathering Cork.

Their stand of 46, in only eight overs, came to a sorry and painful end, however, as Sarwan, sent back by Lara, was run out by Graham Thorpe's underarm throw and accidentally kicked in the head by the fielder for good measure. After some minutes on the deck, and given out by the third umpire, Sarwan recovered sufficiently to wander off dazed.

When Ridley Jacobs was caught at second slip in the following over and Lara followed in the one after that, England were unstoppable and West Indies consigned to their fifth consecutive defeat on the road.

The celebrations were held up only by a cameo innings of 28 from Curtly Ambrose, who had reached the crease through a guard of honour formed by the England players. Later, when Courtney Walsh replaced Ambrose, he was accorded the same treatment.

In the champagne aftermath of the match came the awards. On a pitch that had made batting a trial throughout, there was little doubt that the man of the match would be Atherton, whose total contribution of 191 runs in a low-scoring game proved the difference.

England's man of the series award went to Gough, whose incisive new-ball bowling all summer has made him a player of genuine world stature. For West Indies this has been Walsh's series, taking twice as many wickets, 34, as his partner Ambrose and the inaugural Malcolm Marshall trophy for leading wicket-taker in an Anglo-Caribbean series.

Walsh is going home to Jamaica now to put his feet up and contemplate his future and, no doubt, the 17 Test wickets he would need in Australia to reach 500.

On a pitch that had made batting a trial throughout, there was little doubt that the man of the match would be Atherton, whose total contribution of 191 runs in a low-scoring game proved the difference. England's man of the series award went to Gough, whose incisive new-ball bowling all summer has made him a player of genuine world stature. For West Indies this has been Walsh's series, taking twice as many wickets, 34, as his partner Ambrose and the inaugural Malcolm Marshall trophy for leading wicket-taker in an Anglo-Caribbean series. webTitle: Hussain finally finds a place in the sun

fields.headline: Hussain finally finds a place in the sun
fields.standfirst: England's captain tells of his obsessive quest to turn the tide of history
fields.trailText: England's captain tells of his obsessive quest to turn the tide of history
fields.body:
Nasser Hussain looked exhausted. His face was drawn, his eyes more hollow than anyone could remember. England's captain had admitted, with the final Test in the balance, to sleeping badly for weeks, but when he finally fell into an alcohol-induced slumber last night, the Wisden Trophy safely gathered in, all the indications were that he would not wake again for days.

The moment that Hussain realised, in midsummer, that England had not beaten the West Indies for 31 years was the moment that he succumbed to obsession. His life became consumed by a single objective. Nothing else mattered.

"I felt that we had a wonderful opportunity to end that record, and I haven't thought about anything else for months," he said. "I'm sorry if it sounds a little bit sad or cricket-nerdish but that's how it is. Now we've done it, I'm completely drained."

Even yesterday afternoon, as a festive Oval crowd presumptuously awaited certain victory, Hussain's outward calm disguised his inner agitation. Call this a winning margin of 158 runs, but never in Hussain's earshot describe it as comfortable.

"When Lara and Sarwan were playing well in the afternoon, my heart began to beat a little," he said. "Outwardly I had to stay calm, because there are always TV cameras and 10 other players looking at you and expecting you to seem settled. But with Lara around, you can never be sure. The difference between a 3-1 series win and finishing 2-2 is miles apart."

In the three weeks' grace before England fly to Kenya for the ICC Trophy, Hussain will have a holiday (can someone make sure he does not pack his cricket videos?) and then work upon a batting technique in need of remedial action. He possesses the skill to bounce back quickly this winter.

"I've been overly tense, inwardly, and that has rubbed off on my batting," said. "Even selection for this Test was so difficult. I knew there were good reasons not to play a spinner because the ball has swung at the Oval, and the West Indies have struggled against that this summer, but it was still a gamble and I spent six days worrying that it might turn out to be the wrong decision."

For English cricket, this has been a summer of reawakening; for Hussain, a summer of sleep deprivation. In common with his team-mates, he expected the series's last gasp to be played out before a few thousand spectators. To find that many fans had been locked out was timely proof that he had not been alone in his longing. "They are grateful for a side to take pride in," he said.

Hussain has not been the only England captain to despair of Andy Caddick's highs and lows, but this summer the Caddick barometer has told time and again of fair weather ahead.

"The time that Andy Caddick got out of bed at Lord's and decided to bowl for us," Hussain identified as the turning point of the series. "We bowled them out for 54 and that turned the series round.

"This series will help our self-belief. We had a chance of doing something very special this summer and we took it. Not all the series will be played on pitches like these, or against sides with the West Indies' particular batting weaknesses, but they are confident, and they are playing good cricket.

"We realise that the task ahead in Pakistan and Sri Lanka this winter is huge. We need to achieve when the wickets are flat. Perhaps the wheels will come off - who knows?

Jimmy Adams, the West Indies captain, faces an enormous task. A side that had lost their previous 10 overseas Tests - in New Zealand, Pakistan and South Africa - had again showed their fragility overseas. A forthcoming five-Test tour in Australia, with Curtly Ambrose retired, is a callous fixture programme.

Adams is convinced that popular social theories of the gradual and irreversible decline of West Indian cricket, as the influence of the United States becomes ever stronger, have been overplayed.

"There is still so much talent in the Caribbean," he said. "I'm convinced of that. The onus is on us to develop this talent more attentively over the next five years. There are more choices for youngsters than there were 20 years ago.

"We can no longer just sit around and expect the kids to come to us. The onus is upon West Indies cricket to motivate kids to play the game. The West Indies will come again."

webTitle: Now cricket's come home, after 31 years

fields.headline: Now cricket's come home, after 31 years
fields.trailText: Twelve months after the England cricket team achieved universal derision, losing to New Zealand and being branded the worst team in the world, their captain, Nasser Hussain, lifted the Wisden Trophy yesterday to the delight of a full house at The Oval.
fields.body:
Twelve months after the England cricket team achieved universal derision, losing to New Zealand and being branded the worst team in the world, their captain, Nasser Hussain, lifted the Wisden Trophy yesterday to the delight of a full house at The Oval.

England thrashed West Indies by 158 runs to take the five-match series 3-1. They had not won the trophy by beating West Indies in a series through 31 years and 13 attempts, dating back to the days before decimal currency and the first moon landing.

The result was no surprise in the end. The public response, however, was amazing. Crowds began gathering at breakfast time and the gates were locked at midday with 18,500 inside, making this perhaps the first ever totally sold-out Test in England. This was wonderful news for the cricket authorities, searching for a new Test sponsor to replace Cornhill Insurance, which has withdrawn after 23 years. Of ficials yesterday claimed to have "12 to 15" possible replacements. Rumours of the death of English cricket have always been exaggerated. It turns out that the English public's affection for it is surprisingly resilient as well.

Most of the crowd stormed on to the pitch when the last man, Courtney Walsh, was dismissed. Half the huge Oval playing surface was covered with supporters chanting "Inger-lund" and "Wisden's Coming Home".

"I'm absolutely drained," Hussain said afterwards. "Ever since I realised we had a chance and we hadn't won it for 30 years, I haven't thought about anything else and I've hardly slept. Whatever happens in the future, I'm immensely proud of what we've achieved."

Jimmy Adams, the West Indies captain, said 3-1 was a fair reflection of the series: "England played the most consistent cricket."

It also reflects the growing professionalism of the English set-up and the selectors' discovery - through a mixture of good luck and good judgment - of various young cricketers with far better temperament for Test cricket than some of their predecessors.

In the unofficial world championship, England have climbed to sixth out of nine - but they have to face mighty Australia next summer.

Blasts from the past

What previous losing England captains think of it all

Graham Gooch 1989-90 lost 2-1. 1991 drew 2-2

It's nice to be on top because I played in a lot of two-horse races when we came third. We were capable of beating anybody, but we lacked consistency. This team has been consistent for four successive games and has got the result they deserve. The scenes here at 10.30 were unbelievable. The crowds were five or six thick outside the ground. It just shows the interest that is still bubbling under the surface.

David Gower 1984 lost 5-0. 1985-86 lost 5-0

In the first Test at Edgbaston, in 1984, I nicked one off Michael Holding to get out in the first innings. As I walked off, a West Indian in the pavilion suggested that I might never see the day when we would beat the West Indies. Less than two years later, when we were being beaten in the West Indies, I thought he might be right. It was the great era of West Indies cricket and they were just too good for us. Today has been a reward for an England team which has shown great unity and sense of purpose. It has brought a smile to all of us who suffered so much.

Derek Pringle 1988 (unofficial captain for two sessions)

The teams I played in sniffed leather and chased it. The great days have largely gone in West Indies cricket, but nevertheless the end of all the one-way traffic must be deeply satisfying for all those of us who suffered. It was a painful time, but it was sweet pain because the sides we faced were so awesome.

webTitle: Gloucestershire hit high note on way to treble

fields.headline: Gloucestershire hit high note on way to treble
fields.standfirst:
Lancashire 157
Gloucestershire 160-5
Gloucestershire win by five wickets
fields.trailText:
Lancashire 157
Gloucestershire 160-5
Gloucestershire win by five wickets
fields.body:
Gloucestershire moved into second place in the National League First Division after beating Lancashire by five wickets with more than six overs left. They will play Sussex today chasing another one-day trophy to go with their stunning conquests in the Benson & Hedges and NatWest competitions.

They have already defeated Lancashire in two semi-finals this season. Yesterday they never looked in much danger of ending the sequence as, with the calculated resolve that has typified their unrivalled limited-overs style, they cruised home against a side who looked weary in the field.

Tim Hancock, Kim Barnett, an aggressive Ian Harvey and Jeremy Snape, in calm rotation, approached and eventually overwhelmed the modest target.

Lancashire's innings offered nothing much apart from a fifth-wicket stand between Neil Fairbrother and Graham Lloyd. Mark Chilton went in the second over, Sourav Ganguly fell to a needless skier and John Crawley to a superb full-length catch, one-handed down the leg side by Jack Russell off James Averis, who had already dismissed Andrew Flintoff in the latter's last game of the season for Lancashire.

Fairbrother was then beaten as he tried to work a turning ball from Martyn Ball. Lloyd's determined batting in a season which for him has been bereft of runs or form finished with a catch at the wicket.

Gloucestershire's bowling was typically geared to one-day combat. Mike Smith's nine overs brought him two for 13. There has again been no tour place and in the view of west country partisans he was criminally overlooked in the NatWest final as man of the match. Remember too that cursory glimpse he was once given of the England dressing room. What else has this talented left-arm swinger to do to earn proper recognition?

fields.headline: England bask in champagne moment
fields.standfirst:
England 281 & 217
West Indies 125 & 215
England win by 158 runs to take series 3-1
fields.trailText:
England 281 & 217
West Indies 125 & 215
England win by 158 runs to take series 3-1
fields.body:
After 31 years of torment, of battered bodies, broken limbs and humiliation, English cricket finally enjoyed its day of days against West Indies yesterday.

Victory by 158 runs, achieved 12 minutes into the final session and in front of a full house on the fifth day of a Test for the first time in living memory, was as emphatic as it was sweet. Seeking to make an improbable 374 to win, from 33 without loss overnight, West Indies lost wickets steadily throughout the day against the ebullient England pace attack, led thrillingly once more by Darren Gough, who finished with three for 64, and Andy Caddick, four for 54. Those two shared seven of the first eight wickets before stepping aside for Dominic Cork to finish it off with two wickets in three balls.

Only while Brian Lara was at the crease did West Indies harbour even a minuscule hope of achieving the win they needed to level the series. But he was leg-before, unluckily perhaps, to Gough for a brilliant 47, and that effectively was that.

West Indies, to put things in perspective, had fallen short of their victory target by precisely the number of runs Mike Atherton and Marcus Trescothick had put on for the first wicket of the match after Jimmy Adams had put England in.

Twenty minutes after the stumps had been grabbed and the England team had sprinted off, Nasser Hussain, finally, lifted the Wisden Trophy to mass acclaim on the same balcony where last summer he was booed after defeat by New Zealand.

Hussain has led the side with increasing authority this summer but he is level-headed enough to know that once the celebrations have died down there is work to be done. By the time they reach the Oval again 12 months hence England will have played winter series in Pakistan and Sri Lanka and home series against Pakistan once more and Australia. It is feasible that they will play very well in each of those and yet lose. True progress will only be measured by consistency.

Yesterday's attendance of 18,000-odd was a revelation. Before play the queues stretched down the Harleyford Road, and by midday the gates were closed and the empty hospitality boxes had been opened up as overspill areas.

The crowd saw Sherwin Campbell and Adrian Griffith continue their flyer of the previous evening, taking the score to 50 before Campbell, who had been dropped at second slip by Graeme Hick the previous ball, edged a lifter fast to the same fielder, who clung on in front of his face and not without relief. In the following over Griffith edged Caddick low to Alec Stewart and England were away.

Lara would always be the stumbling block. On Sunday evening, as the players left the field, he emerged to hammer throwdowns into the boundary boards, perhaps as a statement. Yesterday he moved up the order to three. At the start he laboured, pinned down by the accuracy and purpose of Gough and Caddick.

At the other end Wavell Hinds had been missed at slip, again by Hick, before becoming another lbw victim - one of 14 in the match - this time to Caddick's inswinging yorker.
A double bowling change, with Cork and Craig White replacing the two opening bowlers, let Lara slip the leash as he swivelled on his left leg to pull both to the fence for his first boundaries. He and Adams added 36 for the fourth wicket either side of lunch before Hussain, perceptively, moved White a little finer at leg gully to where the West Indies captain immediately flicked a low catch.

The best batting came now with Lara and the young right-hander Ramnaresh Sarwan attacking with relish, Lara hitting Gough from the attack and Sarwan leathering Cork.

Their stand of 46, in only eight overs, came to a sorry and painful end, however, as Sarwan, sent back by Lara, was run out by Graham Thorpe's underarm throw and accidentally kicked in the head by the fielder for good measure. After some minutes on the deck, and given out by the third umpire, Sarwan recovered sufficiently to wander off dazed.

When Ridley Jacobs was caught at second slip in the following over and Lara followed in the one after that, England were unstoppable and West Indies consigned to their fifth consecutive defeat on the road.

The celebrations were held up only by a cameo innings of 28 from Curtly Ambrose, who had reached the crease through a guard of honour formed by the England players. Later, when Courtney Walsh replaced Ambrose, he was accorded the same treatment.

In the champagne aftermath of the match came the awards. On a pitch that had made batting a trial throughout, there was little doubt that the man of the match would be Atherton, whose total contribution of 191 runs in a low-scoring game proved the difference.

fields.bodyText: After 31 years of torment, of battered bodies, broken limbs and humiliation, English cricket finally enjoyed its day of days against West Indies yesterday. Victory by 158 runs, achieved 12 minutes into the final session and in front of a full house on the fifth day of a Test for the first time in living memory, was as emphatic as it was sweet. Seeking to make an improbable 374 to win, from 33 without loss overnight, West Indies lost wickets steadily throughout the day against the ebullient England pace attack, led thrillingly once more by Darren Gough, who finished with three for 64, and Andy Caddick, four for 54. Those two shared seven of the first eight wickets before stepping aside for Dominic Cork to finish it off with two wickets in three balls. Only while Brian Lara was at the crease did West Indies harbour even a minuscule hope of achieving the win they needed to level the series. But he was leg-before, unluckily perhaps, to Gough for a brilliant 47, and that effectively was that. West Indies, to put things in perspective, had fallen short of their victory target by precisely the number of runs Mike Atherton and Marcus Trescothick had put on for the first wicket of the match after Jimmy Adams had put England in. Twenty minutes after the stumps had been grabbed and the England team had sprinted off, Nasser Hussain, finally, lifted the Wisden Trophy to mass acclaim on the same balcony where last summer he was booed after defeat by New Zealand. Hussain has led the side with increasing authority this summer but he is level-headed enough to know that once the celebrations have died down there is work to be done. By the time they reach the Oval again 12 months hence England will have played winter series in Pakistan and Sri Lanka and home series against Pakistan once more and Australia. It is feasible that they will play very well in each of those and yet lose. True progress will only be measured by consistency. Yesterday's attendance of 18,000-odd was a revelation. Before play the queues stretched down the Harleyford Road, and by midday the gates were closed and the empty hospitality boxes had been opened up as overspill areas. The crowd saw Sherwin Campbell and Adrian Griffith continue their flyer of the previous evening, taking the score to 50 before Campbell, who had been dropped at second slip by Graeme Hick the previous ball, edged a lifter fast to the same fielder, who clung on in front of his face and not without relief. In the following over Griffith edged Caddick low to Alec Stewart and England were away. Lara would always be the stumbling block. On Sunday evening, as the players left the field, he emerged to hammer throwdowns into the boundary boards, perhaps as a statement. Yesterday he moved up the order to three. At the start he laboured, pinned down by the accuracy and purpose of Gough and Caddick. At the other end Wavell Hinds had been missed at slip, again by Hick, before becoming another lbw victim - one of 14 in the match - this time to Caddick's inswinging yorker. A double bowling change, with Cork and Craig White replacing the two opening bowlers, let Lara slip the leash as he swivelled on his left leg to pull both to the fence for his first boundaries. He and Adams added 36 for the fourth wicket either side of lunch before Hussain, perceptively, moved White a little finer at leg gully to where the West Indies captain immediately flicked a low catch. The best batting came now with Lara and the young right-hander Ramnaresh Sarwan attacking with relish, Lara hitting Gough from the attack and Sarwan leathering Cork. Their stand of 46, in only eight overs, came to a sorry and painful end, however, as Sarwan, sent back by Lara, was run out by Graham Thorpe's underarm throw and accidentally kicked in the head by the fielder for good measure. After some minutes on the deck, and given out by the third umpire, Sarwan recovered sufficiently to wander off dazed. When Ridley Jacobs was caught at second slip in the following over and Lara followed in the one after that, England were unstoppable and West Indies consigned to their fifth consecutive defeat on the road. The celebrations were held up only by a cameo innings of 28 from Curtly Ambrose, who had reached the crease through a guard of honour formed by the England players. Later, when Courtney Walsh replaced Ambrose, he was accorded the same treatment. In the champagne aftermath of the match came the awards. On a pitch that had made batting a trial throughout, there was little doubt that the man of the match would be Atherton, whose total contribution of 191 runs in a low-scoring game proved the difference. For West Indies this has been Walsh's series, taking twice as many wickets, 34, as his partner Ambrose and the inaugural Malcolm Marshall trophy for leading wicket-taker in an Anglo-Caribbean series. Walsh is going home to Jamaica now to put his feet up and contemplate his future and, no doubt, the 17 Test wickets he would need in Australia to reach 500.
